questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department with profuse, watery diarrhea, severe dehydration, and vomiting for the past 24 hours. Physical examination reveals signs of dehydration, including dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor. Stool examination confirms the presence of Vibrio cholerae. Which of the following cellular structures is disrupted by the cholera toxin to cause watery diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zonula occludens

 

  • Cholera toxin, produced by Vibrio cholerae, binds to the GM1 ganglioside receptor on intestinal epithelial cells (enterocytes), initiating endocytosis of the toxin.
  • The enzymatic A1 subunit activates adenylate cyclase through ADP-ribosylation, leading to increased cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels.
  • This results in activation of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), which promotes a dramatic efflux of chloride ions and water, leading to watery diarrhea.
  • Additionally, Zona occludens toxin (Zot) disrupts the zonula occludens, which are the tight junctions between enterocytes, leading to reduced intestinal barrier function and increased intestinal permeability, further contributing to fluid loss.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intercalated discs: These are specialized connections found in cardiac muscle cells and are unrelated to the pathogenesis of cholera.

 

Option B. Macula densa: This structure is part of the nephron and plays a role in regulating renal blood flow and filtration rate. It is not involved in the pathophysiology of cholera.

 

Option D. Hemidesmosomes: These structures connect epithelial cells to the basement membrane. They are not involved in cholera toxin-induced diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cholera toxin acts by increasing cAMP in intestinal cells, leading to chloride and water secretion.
  • The zonula occludens (tight junctions) are disrupted, contributing to increased intestinal permeability and profuse, watery diarrhea.
  • Preventing dehydration is crucial in the management of cholera.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is experiencing frequent multifocal seizures and has a characteristic <2.5 Hz spike-and-wave pattern on EEG. The neurologist decides to start an antiepileptic medication that can also be used for migraine prophylaxis and for managing alcohol cravings in adults. Which of the following drug is the neurologist thinking to start?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Topiramate

 

  • Topiramate is an antiepileptic medication that is FDA-approved for treating Lennox-Gastaut syndrome.
  • In addition to its anticonvulsant properties, topiramate is also used for migraine prophylaxis and has been shown to reduce alcohol cravings in adults.
  • These multiple therapeutic effects make it an attractive option for conditions requiring diverse treatment approaches.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Valproate: Valproate is another antiepileptic that is effective for Lennox-Gastaut syndrome and other seizure types. It is also used for migraine prophylaxis, but it is not commonly used for managing alcohol cravings.

 

Option B. Ethosuximide: Ethosuximide is effective for absence seizures, but it is not typically used for Lennox-Gastaut syndrome and does not have applications for migraine prophylaxis or alcohol cravings.

 

Option D. Rufinamide: Rufinamide is FDA-approved for Lennox-Gastaut syndrome but does not have indications for migraine prophylaxis or alcohol craving management, unlike topiramate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Topiramate is effective in treating Lennox-Gastaut syndrome and is also used for migraine prophylaxis and to reduce alcohol cravings.
  • While valproate is also used in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome and migraine prevention, it is not typically used for managing alcohol cravings.
  • Ethosuximide is primarily for absence seizures, and rufinamide is limited to seizures without additional benefits for migraines or alcohol use disorders.

questions.text: Match the following drugs with its corresponding mechanisms of action:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1

 

The correct matches for the drugs and their mechanisms of action are:

 

A. Adalimumab - 3. TNF-alpha antagonist: Adalimumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets and neutralizes tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha), reducing inflammation in conditions like rheumatoid arthritis.

 

B. Albiglutide - 4. GLP-1 agonist: Albiglutide is a glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) agonist used in type 2 diabetes to stimulate insulin release in response to meals, helping to control blood glucose levels.

 

C. Alogliptin - 2. DPP-4 inhibitor: Alogliptin inhibits dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4), prolonging the action of incretin hormones, which helps to lower blood glucose levels in type 2 diabetes.

 

D. Apremilast - 1. PDE-4 inhibitor: Apremilast inhibits phosphodiesterase-4 (PDE-4), decreasing the production of inflammatory cytokines, and is used in the treatment of psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Adalimumab is a TNF-alpha antagonist used in autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Albiglutide is a GLP-1 agonist used for glycemic control in type 2 diabetes.
  • Alogliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor that prolongs incretin activity to manage diabetes.
  • Apremilast is a PDE-4 inhibitor used to reduce inflammation in psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis.

choices.text: Absent end diastolic flow in the umbilical artery
Reversal of a wave in the ductus venosus
Decreased pulsatility index (PI) of the uterine artery

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman at 33 weeks gestation presents for a routine ultrasound. The ultrasound shows fetal growth restriction, and Doppler studies are performed. Which of the following Doppler findings is not an indication for immediate delivery in a fetus with growth restriction?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Decreased pulsatility index (PI) of the uterine artery

 

  • A decreased pulsatility index (PI) of the uterine artery is associated with better maternal blood flow to the placenta and is not an indication for delivery in cases of fetal growth restriction (FGR).
  • The pulsatility index assesses resistance in blood flow, and a decreased PI generally suggests lower resistance, which can be seen in a well-functioning placental circulation.
  • It is not a critical finding that would indicate the need for immediate delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Absent end diastolic flow in the umbilical artery: Incorrect. Absent end diastolic flow is a serious finding that indicates increased placental resistance and impaired fetal blood flow. This is an indication for close monitoring and often immediate delivery if the condition worsens.

 

Option B. Reversal of a wave in the ductus venosus: Incorrect. Reversal of the a-wave in the ductus venosus is a late sign of fetal compromise and impending fetal demise. This finding typically indicates the need for immediate delivery.

 

Option C. Pulsatility of the umbilical vein: Incorrect. Pulsatility of the umbilical vein is a sign of impending fetal heart failure and is an indication for urgent delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In fetal growth restriction (FGR), decreased pulsatility index (PI) of the uterine artery is not an indication for immediate delivery.
  • Critical Doppler findings that do suggest the need for immediate delivery include absent end diastolic flow in the umbilical artery, reversal of a wave in the ductus venosus, and pulsatility of the umbilical vein, all of which indicate significant fetal compromise.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is scheduled for elective surgery and requires a blood transfusion. To ensure the availability of compatible blood, the blood bank must store the donated blood units for several weeks before the procedure. The staff chooses a preservative solution that allows the blood to be stored for up to 35 days while maintaining cell viability. Which of the following preservatives is most appropriate for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Citrate Phosphate Dextrose Adenine-1 (CPDA-1)

 

  • CPDA-1 is the most suitable preservative solution for storing whole blood for up to 35 days. 
  • Adenine: maintain ATP levels in the stored red blood cells
  • Citrate: an anticoagulant, Phosphate: maintain the pH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acid Citrate Dextrose: ACD lacks adenine and phosphate, limiting RBC storage to about 21 days, which is too short for this case.

 

Option B. Citrate Phosphate Double Dextrose: CP2D lacks adenine, restricting blood storage to around 21 days, unsuitable for extended storage.

 

Option C. Lithium Heparin: Used for laboratory testing, not for blood preservation, as it does not support RBC metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CPDA-1 allows blood storage for up to 35 days by maintaining red blood cell viability and ATP levels.
  • Preservative solution must:
    • Prevent clotting
    • Maintain ATP levels in RBCs (to support membrane integrity and ion balance)
    • Prevent hemolysis
    • Minimize biochemical changes over time ("storage lesions")
    • Allow storage for ≥ 35 days

 

Summary

choices.text: Recent cesarean delivery in a lactating woman

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with one previous live birth presents to your clinic inquiring about the contraceptive implant, Implanon NXT, for long-term contraception. Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to using this contraceptive method?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Breast cancer

 

  • Breast cancer is an absolute contraindication for the use of hormonal contraceptives, including Implanon NXT, which releases etonogestrel (a progestin).
  • Hormonal contraceptives can potentially stimulate the growth of hormone-sensitive tumors, such as breast cancer, making it unsafe for patients with a current or past history of breast cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thromboembolic disease: Incorrect. While thromboembolic disease is a contraindication for estrogen-containing contraceptives, it is not an absolute contraindication for progestin-only methods like Implanon NXT.

 

Option C. Cervical cancer: Incorrect. Cervical cancer is not an absolute contraindication to the use of progestin-only contraceptives. Other factors would need to be evaluated, but Implanon NXT can generally be used.

 

Option D. Recent cesarean delivery in a lactating woman: Incorrect. Progestin-only contraceptives like Implanon NXT can be safely used in lactating women and immediately postpartum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Breast cancer is an absolute contraindication to the use of hormonal contraceptives, including Implanon NXT, because of the potential for hormone-driven tumor growth.
  • Progestin-only contraceptives are generally safe in patients without contraindications like breast cancer.

choices.text: Protects the acid-labile drug from gastric acidity
Protects the gastric mucosa from irritant effects of certain drugs
Prolongs the half-life of the drug
Delivers drugs distal to the stomach

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is prescribed a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) for chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). The medication is provided as an enteric-coated tablet to ensure proper absorption. Which of the following is not an advantage of using enteric-coated tablets for drug delivery?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prolongs the half-life of the drug

 

  • Enteric coating is designed to protect the drug from the acidic environment of the stomach or to protect the gastric mucosa from the irritant effects of the drug.
  • It also ensures that the drug is released in the intestine rather than in the stomach, which is useful for drugs that need to act distally or those that are acid-labile.
  • However, enteric coating does not affect the half-life of a drug. The half-life is determined by metabolism and elimination processes in the body, such as liver metabolism and kidney excretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protects the acid-labile drug from gastric acidity: This is true. Enteric coating shields acid-labile drugs, like omeprazole, from being degraded in the acidic environment of the stomach.

 

Option B. Protects the gastric mucosa from irritant effects of certain drugs: This is true. For drugs that can irritate the gastric lining (e.g., NSAIDs), enteric coating can help minimize direct exposure to the stomach, reducing the risk of gastritis or ulceration.

 

Option D. Delivers drugs distal to the stomach: This is true. Enteric-coated drugs are designed to bypass the stomach and release the active ingredient in the small intestine or beyond, ensuring that the drug reaches its intended site of action without being degraded by stomach acid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Enteric coating is used to protect acid-labile drugs from gastric acidity, protect the stomach lining, and target drug delivery to the intestine.
  • Enteric coating does not affect the drug’s half-life, which is influenced by metabolic and elimination pathways in the body.

choices.text: Type I - IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation
Type IV - T-cell mediated activation of macrophages and cytotoxic T cells

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient develops skin rashes after coming into contact with poison ivy while hiking. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is most likely responsible for his symptoms, and what is the primary mechanism involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Type IV - T-cell mediated activation of macrophages and cytotoxic T cells

 

  • The patient's skin rash following contact with poison ivy is a classic example of contact dermatitis, which is caused by a Type IV hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Type IV hypersensitivity is mediated by T cells rather than antibodies.
  • In this case, TH1 cells secrete cytokines, which activate macrophages and cytotoxic T cells, leading to an inflammatory response in the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I - IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation: Type I hypersensitivity involves allergens binding to IgE bound to mast cells, which leads to degranulation. This type of hypersensitivity is responsible for conditions like anaphylaxis and allergic rhinitis, not contact dermatitis.

 

Option B. Type II - Antibody-dependent cell lysis: Type II hypersensitivity involves IgG or IgM binding to cell-bound antigens, leading to cell destruction via complement or ADCC (antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity). Examples include hemolytic disease of the newborn and transfusion reactions.

 

Option C. Type III - Immune complex deposition: Type III hypersensitivity involves antigen-antibody complexes that deposit in tissues and trigger an inflammatory response. Examples include systemic lupus erythematosus and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) presents with new-onset headaches, blurred vision, and hypertension. Fundoscopic examination shows flame-shaped hemorrhages and cotton-wool spots consistent with hypertensive retinopathy. She has previously been treated with corticosteroids for lupus nephritis, but her renal function has worsened. A renal biopsy shows wire-loop lesions and extensive immune complex deposition in the glomeruli. Which of the following autoantibodies is most specific for this patient’s lupus-related renal pathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-double-stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA) antibody

 

  • This patient has severe lupus nephritis, a complication of SLE characterized by immune complex deposition in the kidneys.
  • The presence of wire-loop lesions on renal biopsy indicates diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis, a severe form of lupus nephritis.
  • Anti-double-stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA) antibodies are highly specific for SLE and are closely associated with lupus nephritis, correlating with disease activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA): Incorrect. ANA is sensitive but not specific for SLE, and while it is commonly positive in lupus, it is not specific for lupus nephritis.

 

Option B. Anti-Ro/SSA antibody: Incorrect. Anti-Ro/SSA antibodies are seen in some patients with SLE but are more commonly associated with subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus and Sjögren's syndrome. They are not specific for lupus nephritis.

 

Option D. Anti-histone antibody: Incorrect. Anti-histone antibodies are commonly associated with drug-induced lupus, not lupus nephritis or severe SLE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anti-double-stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA) antibodies are highly specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and are strongly associated with lupus nephritis, making them a key marker for renal involvement in SLE.

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain. An abdominal ultrasound reveals the presence of multiple gallstones with no evidence of wall thickening. The bile duct (BD) diameter is measured at 12 mm, and serum bilirubin levels are elevated at 2.8. The patient's alkaline phosphatase levels are significantly elevated at 380. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MRCP

 

  • Given the patient's presentation of multiple gallstones, an enlarged bile duct diameter, and elevated liver enzymes, there is a high suspicion of choledocholithiasis (stones in the common bile duct).
  • An MRCP is the most appropriate initial investigation to visualize and confirm the presence of common bile duct stones without subjecting the patient to an invasive procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography): ERCP is an invasive procedure that allows both the visualization and treatment of biliary and pancreatic duct abnormalities. While it can be used to diagnose and treat choledocholithiasis, it is generally reserved for therapeutic interventions after the diagnosis has been established, given the risks associated with the procedure.

 

Option C. Endoscopic ultrasound: This technique can be very sensitive for detecting common bile duct stones and other biliary pathologies. However, in the context of a patient with an enlarged bile duct and elevated liver enzymes suggestive of choledocholithiasis, MRCP would be the preferred initial diagnostic tool.

 

Option D. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy: While the patient may ultimately require a cholecystectomy, especially if the gallstones are the cause of her symptoms, it's crucial to first assess and manage any potential common bile duct stones. Directly proceeding to cholecystectomy without addressing potential common bile duct stones could lead to complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In summary, given the patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings suggesting the presence of common bile duct stones, an MRCP is the most appropriate initial step to visualize the biliary system and confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman at 28 weeks gestation presents for a routine prenatal visit. On physical examination, the fundal height is measured at 24 cm. An ultrasound reveals oligohydramnios with absent amniotic fluid. The fetus is noted to have normal cardiac activity. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's oligohydramnios?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fetal posterior urethral valve

 

  • Fetal posterior urethral valves are a common cause of oligohydramnios in male fetuses.
  • This condition occurs due to a congenital obstruction of the urethra, preventing the fetus from properly emptying its bladder.
  • Since fetal urine is a major component of amniotic fluid, this obstruction leads to a reduction or absence of amniotic fluid (oligohydramnios).
  • In this case, the ultrasound findings of absent liquor (amniotic fluid) and a discrepancy between gestational age and uterine size strongly suggest oligohydramnios caused by a lower urinary tract obstruction such as posterior urethral valves.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tracheo-esophageal fistula: Incorrect. Tracheo-esophageal fistula is associated with polyhydramnios (excess amniotic fluid) because the fetus cannot swallow amniotic fluid properly. It does not cause oligohydramnios.

 

Option C. Diaphragmatic hernia: Incorrect. A diaphragmatic hernia can lead to pulmonary hypoplasia and respiratory issues at birth but is not a direct cause of oligohydramnios.

 

Option D. Congenital heart disease: Incorrect. Congenital heart disease generally does not affect the production or regulation of amniotic fluid, making it an unlikely cause of oligohydramnios.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Posterior urethral valves cause oligohydramnios due to obstruction of fetal urine outflow.
  • Fetal urine production is essential for maintaining normal amniotic fluid levels, and obstruction leads to low or absent amniotic fluid, contributing to complications like pulmonary hypoplasia and other fetal abnormalities.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe headache, nausea, and visual disturbances. She has a known history of a pituitary adenoma. On examination, she has reduced visual acuity and bitemporal hemianopsia. A CT scan of the head reveals a hemorrhagic mass in the sella turcica. Her blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg, and laboratory tests reveal hyponatremia. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dexamethasone

 

  • Dexamethasone or another high-dose corticosteroid is the most important first step to address adrenal insufficiency caused by ACTH deficiency, which leads to hypotension and potential shock. This is a life-threatening situation that requires prompt intervention.
  • After corticosteroid administration, urgent surgery will likely be required to decompress the optic chiasm and relieve the mass effect causing visual disturbances, but surgery should be delayed until the patient is hemodynamically stable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI of the pituitary: While MRI provides better soft tissue detail and will confirm the diagnosis, it is not the immediate next step. Stabilization with steroids comes first.

 

Option B. CECT Head: A CT scan has already shown a hemorrhagic mass. An MRI could follow after stabilization, but CT imaging is not the priority at this point.

 

Option D. Urgent surgery: Surgery is essential, but after stabilizing the patient with corticosteroids to prevent further adrenal crisis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In pituitary apoplexy, the immediate treatment with dexamethasone (or other steroids) is the priority to correct adrenal insufficiency, followed by further imaging and surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with a history of open-angle glaucoma visits her ophthalmologist for follow-up. She is being treated with various medications to lower her intraocular pressure (IOP). The physician wants to add a drug that specifically increases trabecular outflow to help manage her condition. Which of the following medications has this mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Netarsudil

 

  • Netarsudil is a Rho-kinase inhibitor used in the treatment of glaucoma.
  • It works by increasing trabecular outflow, thereby reducing intraocular pressure (IOP).
  • Rho-kinase inhibition leads to changes in the cytoskeleton of the trabecular meshwork, which enhances the outflow of aqueous humor through this pathway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: Timolol is a beta-blocker that reduces intraocular pressure by decreasing the production of aqueous humor from the ciliary body. It does not increase trabecular outflow.

 

Option C. Brimonidine: Brimonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that reduces aqueous humor production and also increases uveoscleral outflow, but it does not specifically increase trabecular outflow.

 

Option D. Acetazolamide: Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that reduces the production of aqueous humor by the ciliary body, leading to decreased intraocular pressure. It does not affect trabecular outflow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Netarsudil increases trabecular outflow by inhibiting Rho-kinase, making it effective in lowering intraocular pressure in glaucoma.
  • Timolol and acetazolamide decrease aqueous humor production, while brimonidine affects uveoscleral outflow.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male is admitted to the ICU after a traumatic head injury. The clinician wants to assess the oculocephalic reflex, as part of the neurological evaluation. The test is performed by rapidly rotating the patient's head from side to side while observing eye movements. Which of the following cranial nerves are involved in the oculocephalic reflex?

 

  1. III
  2. IV
  3. VI
  4. VIII
  5. VII
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3 and 4
 

  • The oculocephalic reflex, also known as the doll’s eye reflex, assesses the integrity of several cranial nerves to determine brainstem function. The cranial nerves involved include:
    • Cranial Nerve III (Oculomotor Nerve): This nerve controls the medial rectus and other muscles, allowing the eyes to move.
    • Cranial Nerve VI (Abducens Nerve): The lateral rectus muscle is controlled by this nerve, which abducts the eye.
    • Cranial Nerve VIII (Vestibulocochlear Nerve): This nerve is involved in sensing head position and relaying this information to the brainstem to adjust eye movements appropriately.
  • When the examiner moves the patient's head rapidly from side to side, the eyes should move in the opposite direction to maintain visual fixation—this is a positive doll's eye reflex, indicating intact brainstem function involving cranial nerves III, VI, and VIII.

 

 

Other Options:

 

2. Cranial Nerve IV (Trochlear Nerve) - This nerve controls the superior oblique muscle, which is involved in some eye movements, but it does not play a significant role in the doll’s eye reflex.

 

5. Cranial Nerve VII (Facial Nerve) - This nerve is responsible for facial expression and is not involved in the oculocephalic reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The oculocephalic reflex tests the integrity of cranial nerves III (Oculomotor), VI (Abducens), and VIII (Vestibulocochlear).
  • It is used to assess brainstem function, especially in unconscious patients.
  • A positive reflex indicates that the brainstem pathways are intact and capable of coordinating eye movements in response to head movement.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the clinic with her mother due to concerns about primary amenorrhea. On examination, she has normal secondary sexual characteristics, including breast development and normal pubic and axillary hair. Her LH and FSH levels are normal, and a pelvic ultrasound reveals an absent uterus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome

 

  • Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome is characterized by the congenital absence of the uterus and part or all of the vaginal canal in women with a normal 46,XX karyotype.
  • These patients typically present with primary amenorrhea but have normal secondary sexual development, such as breast and pubic/axillary hair development, because their ovaries are functional and produce normal hormone levels.
  • Ultrasound typically shows an absent or rudimentary uterus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS): Incorrect. Individuals with AIS have a 46,XY karyotype and are genetically male but are resistant to androgens, leading to female external genitalia. However, these patients typically lack pubic and axillary hair and have elevated LH and FSH levels, which is inconsistent with this patient’s normal hormone levels and secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Option B. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH): Incorrect. CAH is a group of disorders that result from enzyme deficiencies in the adrenal steroid synthesis pathway, leading to excess androgen production. Although CAH can cause amenorrhea, it is typically associated with ambiguous genitalia and elevated androgen levels, which are not seen in this patient.

 

Option C. Primary ovarian insufficiency: Incorrect. Primary ovarian insufficiency is characterized by ovarian failure before the age of 40, leading to low estrogen levels and elevated FSH and LH levels. Patients with this condition usually do not have normal secondary sexual development, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome is a congenital disorder characterized by the absence of the uterus and upper vaginal canal, leading to primary amenorrhea in women with normal secondary sexual development.
  • These patients have normal ovarian function and normal hormone levels, with a 46,XX karyotype.

questions.text: Moynihan’s hump is an anatomical variation usually associated with which of the below structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Right hepatic artery

 

  • The right hepatic artery can be tortuous (caterpillar turn/ Moynihan’s hump) and may lie very close to the gallbladder and the cystic duct before giving off a short cystic artery.

 

 

(b) Tortuous CHA and (c) Tortuous RHA are examples of the ‘caterpillar turn’ or ‘Moynihan’s hump’, which can lead to inadvertent arterial injury or bleeding during cholecystectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Moynihan’s hump is an abnormally located Right/common hepatic artery on to the Calot’s triangle.

choices.text: Calculating the ratio of maternal deaths to the number of married women alive during the study period.
Expressing maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, including deaths up to 14 days after pregnancy termination.
Dividing the annual number of maternal deaths by the total number of women aged 15-49 years during the study period.
Expressing maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, including deaths up to 42 days after pregnancy termination.

questions.text: A researcher is analyzing maternal health outcomes in a developing country. To measure the risk of maternal death relative to the number of live births in the area, the researcher needs to calculate a key indicator. Which of the following best describes this indicator?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Expressing maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, including deaths up to 42 days after pregnancy termination.

 

  • The indicator described is the Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR).
  • It measures the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, where a maternal death is defined as a death that occurs during pregnancy, delivery, or within 42 days after the end of pregnancy, due to complications related to the pregnancy or its management.
  • This indicator helps assess the safety of maternal health services and is crucial for monitoring progress in maternal care.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) reflects the risk of maternal death in relation to live births, considering deaths occurring during pregnancy or within 42 days post-pregnancy.
  • It is a critical measure of the quality of maternal healthcare and is used for tracking improvements in maternal health services.

choices.text: Decreased food intake via stimulation of the anorexigenic pathway
Inhibition of melanocortin receptors, leading to increased appetite
Activation of the satiety center in the hypothalamus

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with recent weight gain and increased appetite is found to have elevated Agouti-related peptide (AgRP) levels in the hypothalamus. Which of the following best explains the physiological effect of increased AgRP activity?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inhibition of melanocortin receptors, leading to increased appetite

 

  • Agouti-related peptide (AgRP) is a neuropeptide produced in the hypothalamus that plays a crucial role in regulating appetite and energy balance.
  • It functions primarily by inhibiting melanocortin-4 receptors (MC4R), which are part of the pathway responsible for suppressing appetite. By blocking these receptors, AgRP counteracts their anorexigenic (appetite-suppressing) effect, thus promoting increased appetite and food intake.
  • This mechanism is associated with the patient’s increased appetite and recent weight gain.
  • AgRP is an important regulator of feeding behavior and energy conservation, particularly during periods of energy deficit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased leptin sensitivity: Incorrect. AgRP acts as an antagonist to the melanocortin receptors and promotes feeding behavior, but it does not directly increase leptin sensitivity. Leptin is a hormone that inhibits appetite, and increased AgRP would oppose this action, promoting hunger instead.

 

Option B. Decreased food intake via stimulation of the anorexigenic pathway: Incorrect. AgRP actually inhibits the anorexigenic pathway (the pathway that reduces appetite), leading to increased food intake. It promotes feeding behavior rather than suppressing it.

 

Option D. Activation of the satiety center in the hypothalamus: Incorrect. AgRP promotes hunger by inhibiting the melanocortin system, which reduces the activity of the satiety center rather than activating it. AgRP increases food-seeking behavior, not satiety.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Agouti-related peptide (AgRP) inhibits melanocortin receptors in the hypothalamus, leading to increased appetite and reduced energy expenditure.
  • This pathway is essential in the regulation of feeding behavior and energy balance.

choices.text: Lymphatic filariasis caused by Brugia malayi
Chagas disease caused by Trypanosoma cruzi
African trypanosomiasis caused by Trypanosoma brucei

questions.text: A Transmission Assessment Survey (TAS) is planned in a region that has recently undergone mass drug administration (MDA) to prevent the spread of a specific parasitic disease. For which of the following parasitic diseases is this survey method primarily used?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymphatic filariasis caused by Brugia malayi

 

  • The Transmission Assessment Survey (TAS) is specifically designed to assess whether mass drug administration (MDA) has successfully reduced lymphatic filariasis transmission to levels where further MDA is no longer required.
  • It is used to monitor the prevalence of microfilariae in the population to ensure that the disease is no longer being transmitted at a level that could sustain new infections.
  • This applies to lymphatic filariasis caused by both Wuchereria bancrofti and Brugia malayi.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chagas disease caused by Trypanosoma cruzi: Incorrect. Chagas disease is not addressed through mass drug administration (MDA) and therefore does not use TAS. It is typically controlled through vector control measures (targeting the kissing bug) and screening of blood transfusions. TAS is irrelevant for evaluating transmission in Chagas disease.

 

Option C. African trypanosomiasis caused by Trypanosoma brucei: Incorrect. African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness) is controlled through active case detection, treatment, and vector control (such as reducing the tsetse fly population). Mass drug administration is not a strategy used in its elimination, making TAS an inappropriate tool for this disease.

 

Option D. Leishmaniasis caused by Leishmania donovani: Incorrect. Leishmaniasis is typically managed through vector control (targeting sandflies), early diagnosis, and prompt treatment. Mass drug administration is not part of the standard approach for leishmaniasis control, so TAS is not applicable for monitoring its transmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transmission assessment survey (TAS) for Filariasis

 

  • Importance: Helps us evaluate if transmission is not sustainable (at a quite low level) enough guiding us to stop MDA, to check for recrudescence
  • Criteria: Mf prevalence <1% even after 5th MDA, >65% in coverage in each MDA
  • TAS carried out at: Schools 1st/2nd year primary children (If enrolment is >75%), Community 6–7 years old children (If enrolment is <75%)
  • Methods used: Cluster survey, Systematic sampling
  • Major diagnostic tools: Immunochromatographic test (ICT), Brugia rapid (and Blood films, PCR)

choices.text: Increase the rate of positive pressure ventilation
Reposition the head and continue ventilations
Administer a second dose of surfactant

questions.text: A 2-minute-old newborn has a heart rate of 50 beats/min despite receiving effective positive pressure ventilation (PPV) with a bag and mask. The healthcare team initiates chest compressions and continues ventilation, but the heart rate remains below 60 beats/min after 30 seconds of effective compressions and ventilation. What is the next best step in the management of this newborn?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Administer intravenous epinephrine

 

  • If a newborn's heart rate remains below 60 beats per minute after 30 seconds of effective chest compressions and ventilation, the administration of epinephrine is indicated as the next step.
  • Epinephrine is administered to improve cardiac output when compressions and ventilations alone are insufficient.
  • The preferred route is intravenous through the umbilical vein, and it can also be given via endotracheal tube if IV access is not immediately available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase the rate of positive pressure ventilation: This is incorrect as increasing the rate of PPV is not indicated when compressions are already being performed.

 

Option C. Reposition the head and continue ventilations: This is incorrect as repositioning the head is part of the initial steps of resuscitation to ensure adequate airway and ventilation before starting compressions.

 

Option D. Administer a second dose of surfactant: This is incorrect as surfactant therapy is used for respiratory distress syndrome but is not part of the acute steps in neonatal resuscitation when the heart rate is below 60 beats per minute.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In neonatal resuscitation, if a newborn's heart rate remains below 60 beats per minute despite 30 seconds of effective chest compressions and ventilation, epinephrine should be administered immediately.

questions.text: A term male infant is born via cesarean section to a 27-year-old G1P1 mother after an uncomplicated pregnancy. The baby develops tachypnea, grunting, and mild chest retractions within an hour of birth. Oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. A chest x-ray reveals hyperinflation with fluid in the interlobar fissures and no mediastinal shift. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transient tachypnea of the newborn

 

  • Transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN) is a common cause of respiratory distress in full-term infants, especially those born by cesarean section without labor.
  • It results from delayed clearance of lung fluid, leading to tachypnea shortly after birth.
  • Chest x-ray typically shows hyperinflation, perihilar streaking, and fluid in the fissures without mediastinal shift.
  • Symptoms often improve within 24 to 72 hours with supportive care, such as oxygen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neonatal pulmonary alveolar proteinosis: This condition presents with progressive respiratory distress and diffuse ground-glass opacities on chest x-ray. It is rare in neonates and associated with mutations affecting surfactant metabolism or macrophage function. The clinical course is more severe and does not resolve quickly as in TTN.

 

Option B. Meconium aspiration syndrome: Typically occurs in term or post-term infants who experience fetal distress or hypoxia during delivery, leading to meconium-stained amniotic fluid and aspiration. Chest x-ray shows patchy infiltrates and areas of consolidation. It is often associated with hyperinflation and air trapping but usually not isolated fluid in the fissures.

 

Option C. Hyaline membrane disease: This is a condition of preterm infants due to surfactant deficiency, resulting in respiratory distress within minutes to hours of birth. Chest x-ray shows diffuse ground-glass opacities and air bronchograms. It is less common in full-term infants and presents earlier than TTN.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Transient tachypnea of the newborn is characterized by delayed resorption of lung fluid, leading to respiratory distress soon after birth in term infants, especially following cesarean delivery without labor.
  • The chest x-ray findings include hyperinflation and fluid in the interlobar fissures. Symptoms resolve with supportive care within 24 to 72 hours.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man is brought to the emergency department unconscious. He exhibits no spontaneous movement of his extremities and does not respond to voice or painful stimuli. However, he is able to blink and move his eyes in the vertical plane. Based on these physical exam findings, which of the following would be revealed in FDG PET?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Normal cerebral metabolism

 

  • In patients with locked-in syndrome, despite the lack of movement or verbal response, the cerebral metabolism remains relatively intact, especially in areas responsible for cognitive function. 
  • This is reflected in FDG PET scans, which typically show normal metabolic activity in these patients, as they are conscious and aware.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Absent cerebral metabolism: This would indicate complete lack of brain activity, which is not the case here since the patient retains consciousness.

 

Option C. Reduced cerebral metabolism: While motor pathways may show reduced activity due to paralysis, overall cerebral metabolism related to awareness and cognition remains normal.

 

Option D. Increased cerebral metabolism: This option would imply heightened brain activity, which does not apply in the context of a patient who cannot respond or move.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In locked-in syndrome, although motor functions are severely compromised, cognitive functions are preserved, leading to normal cerebral metabolism as observed on FDG PET scans.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with hypertension and angina has been on metoprolol for several months, but his blood pressure remains inadequately controlled. His physician adds verapamil to his regimen. Which of the following adverse effects is most likely to occur due to this combination?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bradycardia with AV block

 

  • The combination of metoprolol, a beta-blocker, and verapamil, a calcium channel blocker, can significantly impact the heart rate and AV nodal conduction due to their overlapping effects on the cardiac conduction system.
  • Metoprolol slows the heart rate and decreases myocardial contractility by blocking beta-adrenergic receptors.
  • Verapamil is a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker that also slows heart rate and AV nodal conduction by inhibiting calcium influx in cardiac cells.
  • When used together, they can have additive effects on the AV node, leading to bradycardia and AV block, which is a delay or complete block of electrical conduction through the AV node.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Torsades de pointes: This is typically associated with drugs that prolong the QT interval, such as certain antiarrhythmics (e.g., sotalol) or macrolide antibiotics. Metoprolol and verapamil are not known to cause QT prolongation.

 

Option C. Tachycardia: This is incorrect. Both metoprolol and verapamil slow the heart rate, and their combination is more likely to cause bradycardia, not tachycardia.

 

Option D. Ventricular fibrillation: This is incorrect. Ventricular fibrillation is a life-threatening arrhythmia that is not directly caused by the combination of metoprolol and verapamil. The primary risk with this combination is a slowed heart rate or AV block, rather than ventricular arrhythmias.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Metoprolol and verapamil have additive effects on slowing heart rate and AV nodal conduction.
  • Combining a beta-blocker with a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker like verapamil increases the risk of bradycardia and AV block.

choices.text: Dys β-lipoproteinemia

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with xanthomas on his palms and premature coronary artery disease. Laboratory tests reveal elevated total cholesterol and triglyceride levels. Further lipid panel analysis shows high levels of chylomicron remnants and intermediate-density lipoproteins (IDLs). Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the ApoE gene. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dys β-lipoproteinemia

 

  • Dys β-lipoproteinemia, also known as Type III hyperlipoproteinemia, is characterized by a mutation in the ApoE gene, which impairs the clearance of chylomicron remnants and intermediate-density lipoproteins (IDLs).
  • This condition leads to elevated levels of total cholesterol and triglycerides, resulting in the accumulation of these lipoproteins in the blood.
  • Clinically, patients present with palmar xanthomas (yellowish deposits on the palms) and premature atherosclerosis, leading to coronary artery disease.
  • The defective ApoE impairs the ability of the liver to uptake these lipoproteins, causing their buildup in the bloodstream.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Familial hypercholesterolemia: Incorrect. Familial hypercholesterolemia is due to a mutation in the LDL receptor or ApoB gene, leading to high levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL). It is characterized by elevated LDL cholesterol, tendon xanthomas, and premature coronary artery disease, but it does not typically involve elevated triglycerides or chylomicron remnants.

 

Option C. Hypertriglyceridemia: Incorrect. Hypertriglyceridemia refers to elevated levels of triglycerides without a significant increase in cholesterol levels or chylomicron remnants. It is often related to increased very-low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) production and is associated with pancreatitis rather than premature coronary artery disease.

 

Option D. Abetalipoproteinemia: It is caused by mutations in the MTTP gene, which encodes the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein. This protein is essential for the assembly and secretion of apolipoprotein B-containing lipoproteins (chylomicrons, VLDL, LDL) from the liver and intestines.

 

Key Features: Fat malabsorption, Neurological problems, Retinal degeneration, Acanthocytosis, Diarrhea and steatorrhea

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dys β-lipoproteinemia (Type III hyperlipoproteinemia) is characterized by elevated chylomicron remnants and IDLs due to a mutation in the ApoE gene.
  • This condition leads to elevated total cholesterol and triglycerides, palmar xanthomas, and premature atherosclerosis, making early diagnosis and management crucial to prevent cardiovascular complications.

questions.text: A pharmaceutical company has developed a new medication and has successfully completed several stages of clinical trials. They are now ready to submit a New Drug Application (NDA) to the FDA for approval to market the drug. This application is typically filed after completing which phase of clinical trials?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phase 3

 

  • A New Drug Application (NDA) is submitted to the FDA (or equivalent regulatory body) after the completion of Phase 3 clinical trials.
  • Phase 3 trials involve large-scale testing in patients to evaluate the drug’s efficacy and safety compared to the current standard of care.
  • If the drug demonstrates a favorable balance of efficacy and safety during Phase 3 trials, the company submits an NDA to seek approval for marketing the drug to the public.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phase 4: Phase 4 trials occur after the drug is approved and released on the market. These involve post-marketing surveillance to monitor long-term safety and rare adverse effects.

 

Option C. Phase 2: Phase 2 trials are initial efficacy studies conducted in a small group of patients with the disease of interest to assess whether the drug works and to further assess safety. Filing for an NDA does not occur after this phase.

 

Option D. Phase 1: Phase 1 trials focus on safety, dosage, and pharmacokinetics in healthy volunteers or patients and are not sufficient for an NDA filing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Phase 1 trials assess safety and dosing
  • Phase 2 trials are smaller studies aimed at determining the efficacy of a drug.
  • New Drug Application (NDA) is submitted after Phase 3 trials, which assess the drug’s efficacy and safety in a large patient population.
  • Phase 4 trials involve post-marketing surveillance to monitor long-term side effects.

questions.text: A 30-year-old athlete sustains an injury to his Achilles tendon and requires surgical repair using a tendon graft. The surgeon selects a tendon that is commonly harvested for grafting procedures in the lower limb due to its small size and minimal impact on function. Which of the following tendons is most likely used for grafting in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plantaris

 

  • The plantaris tendon is often used in tendon grafting procedures, particularly for lower limb reconstructions like Achilles tendon repairs.
  • The plantaris is a small, thin muscle with a long tendon that runs alongside the Achilles tendon. It is easily harvested and can be used as a graft due to its length and strength.
  • Its removal typically has minimal impact on the function of the lower limb because the plantaris muscle is considered vestigial and contributes little to overall movement.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gracilis: Incorrect. The gracilis tendon, located in the medial thigh, is sometimes used as a graft, particularly in conjunction with the semitendinosus tendon for procedures like ACL reconstruction. However, it is not the preferred choice for smaller grafting needs, such as those involving the Achilles tendon, where the plantaris tendon is more suitable.

 

Option C. Tibialis posterior: Incorrect. The tibialis posterior is a major muscle of the lower leg that plays a critical role in supporting the arch of the foot and in plantarflexion. Its tendon is not typically harvested for grafting due to its essential role in foot stability and movement.

 

Option D. Palmaris longus: Incorrect. The palmaris longus is a tendon located in the forearm and is often used for grafting in upper limb procedures, such as hand and wrist reconstructions. It is not typically used in lower limb grafting procedures like those involving the Achilles tendon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The plantaris tendon is commonly used for tendon grafting in lower limb surgical procedures, such as Achilles tendon repair, due to its accessibility and minimal impact on function.
  • Its role as a vestigial muscle makes it a good choice for small grafting needs without compromising lower limb movement.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease and hypertension presents with sudden onset of chest pain, dyspnea, and diaphoresis. He is found to have an acute myocardial infarction affecting the posterior wall of the left ventricle. Angiography reveals that the artery supplying the posterior interventricular septum and posterior wall of the heart is occluded. Given this information, which of the following arteries is most likely responsible for the blood supply to this region?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior descending artery (PDA)

 

  • The posterior descending artery (PDA) is the primary vessel responsible for supplying the posterior third of the interventricular septum and parts of the posterior wall of the left ventricle.
  • The PDA typically arises from the right coronary artery (RCA) in about 85% of individuals with right-dominant circulation.
  • In these individuals, occlusion of the RCA will affect the PDA, leading to ischemia in the posterior wall of the left ventricle and posterior septum, resulting in a posterior myocardial infarction.
  • In the remaining 15% of individuals with left-dominant circulation, the PDA arises from the left circumflex artery (LCX).
  • However, since the question specifies that the artery supplying the posterior wall and septum is occluded, it points to the PDA as the direct vessel involved.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left anterior descending artery (LAD): The LAD supplies the anterior wall of the left ventricle, the anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum, and part of the apex of the heart. Occlusion of the LAD would result in an anterior or anteroseptal myocardial infarction, not a posterior infarction.

 

Option B. Left circumflex artery (LCX): The LCX primarily supplies the lateral and posterior aspects of the left ventricle in left-dominant circulation. However, unless the PDA arises from the LCX in left-dominant circulation, the LCX alone does not directly supply the posterior interventricular septum and posterior left ventricle. Since the PDA is mentioned as supplying the posterior septum and wall, LCX is not the best choice in this case.

 

Option C. Right coronary artery (RCA): While the RCA often gives rise to the PDA in right-dominant circulation, it is not the RCA itself that directly supplies the posterior wall of the left ventricle. The PDA, which arises from the RCA in right-dominant circulation, is the more precise answer to the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The posterior descending artery (PDA) is responsible for supplying the posterior interventricular septum and the posterior wall of the left ventricle.
  • In the majority of individuals with right-dominant circulation, the PDA arises from the right coronary artery (RCA).
  • Occlusion of the PDA leads to ischemia in the posterior aspects of the heart.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman is diagnosed with stage IB1 cervical cancer after a biopsy reveals a 2 cm lesion confined to the cervix. She is otherwise healthy and is considering surgical options for treatment. Which of the following is the most appropriate surgical management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type 3 hysterectomy

 

  • For a patient with stage IB1 cervical cancer (a lesion confined to the cervix that is ≤4 cm), the most appropriate surgical management is a Type 3 hysterectomy, also known as a radical hysterectomy.
  • This procedure involves removing the uterus, cervix, the upper part of the vagina, and surrounding parametrial tissue.
  • It also typically includes pelvic lymph node dissection.
  • This approach is essential for achieving local control of the tumor and ensuring that any potential spread to surrounding tissues is addressed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 4 hysterectomy: Incorrect. A Type 4 hysterectomy is a more extensive procedure, used for more advanced cervical cancer, which involves the removal of even more surrounding tissue, including portions of the ureters and bladder, beyond what is necessary for a stage IB1 tumor.

 

Option C. Type 1 hysterectomy: Incorrect. A Type 1 hysterectomy (simple hysterectomy) involves only the removal of the uterus and cervix without the removal of parametrial tissue or vaginal tissue. This is not sufficient for the treatment of stage IB1 cervical cancer.

 

Option D. Type 2 hysterectomy: Incorrect. A Type 2 hysterectomy (modified radical hysterectomy) removes less parametrial tissue than a Type 3 hysterectomy, making it less suitable for stage IB1 cervical cancer, which requires a more extensive resection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For patients with stage IB1 cervical cancer, the most appropriate surgical management is a Type 3 (radical) hysterectomy, which includes the removal of the uterus, cervix, upper vagina, parametrial tissue, and often a pelvic lymph node dissection to ensure complete removal of cancerous tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with the leftward shift of the pressure-volume loop?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortic stenosis

 

  • A leftward shift of the pressure-volume loop indicates that the heart is working at a lower end-diastolic volume and higher pressures, consistent with aortic stenosis.
  • In aortic stenosis, the left ventricle must generate significantly higher pressures to overcome the narrowed aortic valve, resulting in a taller and narrower loop.
  • The ventricle's ability to fill may also be reduced, leading to a smaller end-diastolic volume, causing the loop to shift leftward.
  • The narrowed aortic valve increases afterload, which is the hallmark of aortic stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic regurgitation: Incorrect. Aortic regurgitation results in an increase in left ventricular volume due to the backflow of blood into the ventricle during diastole, leading to a rightward and widened loop, not a leftward shift. The loop also shows increased stroke volume due to the extra volume regurgitated back into the ventricle.

 

Option B. Mitral regurgitation: Incorrect. Mitral regurgitation is characterized by an increase in left ventricular volume due to backflow of blood from the ventricle into the left atrium during systole, causing a rightward shift in the loop. The loop becomes wider due to the increased volume in the ventricle, but there is no leftward shift.

 

Option D. Congestive cardiac failure: Incorrect. Congestive cardiac failure typically leads to a downward and rightward shift of the loop due to reduced contractility and higher end-diastolic volumes, not a leftward shift. The loop reflects impaired systolic function and reduced ejection fraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A leftward shift of the pressure-volume loop is indicative of aortic stenosis, where the heart generates higher pressures at lower volumes due to increased afterload from the stenotic aortic valve.
  • The ventricle must work harder to pump blood through the narrowed valve, leading to this characteristic change in the loop.

questions.text: An 84-year-old woman presented with weakness and altered sensorium. Her CT is shown. Which of the following interventions would not be effective?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glucocorticoids 

 

  • Glucocorticoids are typically not effective in managing elevated intracranial pressure (ICP) in cases of non-tumor-related causes, such as traumatic brain injury, stroke, or cerebral hemorrhage.
  • Their use is reserved for vasogenic edema due to brain tumors or certain types of inflammatory brain diseases, such as meningitis or autoimmune encephalitis.
  • In this scenario, the CT likely suggests an acute cause of intracranial hypertension, such as hemorrhage or stroke, where glucocorticoids would not help.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mannitol infusion: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that reduces intracranial pressure by drawing water out of the brain tissue and into the bloodstream, reducing cerebral edema and decreasing pressure on the brain.

 

Option B. Mechanical hyperventilation: Hyperventilation can lower intracranial pressure by reducing carbon dioxide levels, which causes cerebral vasoconstriction and reduces cerebral blood flow and volume, lowering ICP.

 

Option C. Head of bed elevation: Raising the head of the bed to 30 degrees is a non-invasive method to enhance venous drainage from the brain, reducing intracranial pressure without additional medication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glucocorticoids are not effective in managing elevated intracranial pressure in acute conditions like traumatic brain injury or stroke but are more useful in reducing vasogenic edema from brain tumors. 
  • Effective interventions for reducing ICP in acute settings include mannitol, hyperventilation, and elevating the head of the bed.

questions.text: Which of the following repair mechanisms is most likely involved in the repair of double-stranded DNA breaks created by CRISPR-Cas9?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-homologous end joining

 

  • CRISPR-Cas9 is a gene-editing technology that introduces double-stranded DNA breaks at specific locations within the genome.
  • The repair of these breaks is most commonly achieved through non-homologous end joining (NHEJ).
  • NHEJ is a DNA repair mechanism that directly joins the ends of double-stranded breaks without the need for a homologous template.
  • This process is often error-prone and can result in small insertions or deletions at the site of the break, potentially disrupting the target gene.
  • This characteristic makes NHEJ a valuable mechanism in gene-editing techniques where the goal is to knock out a gene or create mutations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nucleotide excision repair: Incorrect. Nucleotide excision repair (NER) is involved in the repair of bulky DNA lesions, such as those caused by UV light and chemical damage. It is not the primary mechanism for repairing double-stranded breaks caused by CRISPR-Cas9.

 

Option B. Mismatch repair: Incorrect. Mismatch repair (MMR) is responsible for correcting base mismatches and small insertion-deletion loops that occur during DNA replication. It does not play a significant role in the repair of double-stranded DNA breaks created by gene-editing technologies like CRISPR-Cas9.

 

Option D. Base excision repair: Incorrect. Base excision repair (BER) is involved in repairing single-base lesions or small non-bulky damage to DNA, such as those caused by oxidative damage. It is not involved in repairing double-stranded DNA breaks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CRISPR-Cas9 introduces double-stranded DNA breaks at specific genomic sites, which are most commonly repaired through non-homologous end joining (NHEJ).
  • This repair mechanism can introduce small insertions or deletions at the target site, making it a crucial aspect of gene-editing techniques.

choices.text: To correct fetal presentation from breech to cephalic

questions.text: A 34-year-old pregnant woman at 32 weeks gestation is brought to the emergency department after collapsing at home. Upon arrival, she is unconscious. The medical team performs uterine displacement during the initial resuscitation efforts. What is the significance of this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To relieve aortocaval compression

 

  • In late pregnancy, the large gravid uterus can compress the inferior vena cava and aorta when the patient is lying on her back, causing decreased venous return and hypotension, known as aortocaval compression syndrome.
  • This can lead to reduced cardiac output and may worsen the condition of an unconscious or critically ill pregnant woman.
  • Uterine displacement involves manually shifting the uterus or tilting the patient to the left side, which helps relieve the pressure on these major blood vessels, improving venous return and stabilizing maternal blood flow.
  • This maneuver is crucial in the resuscitation of unconscious pregnant patients to prevent hemodynamic instability due to compression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To correct fetal presentation from breech to cephalic: Incorrect. Correcting fetal presentation from breech to cephalic requires a different procedure, known as external cephalic version, which is typically performed later in pregnancy but is unrelated to uterine displacement.

 

Option C. To assess fetal position: Incorrect. Uterine displacement is not used to assess fetal position. Fetal position is determined through palpation (Leopold maneuvers) or ultrasound.

 

Option D. To correct uterine dextroversion: Incorrect. Uterine dextroversion is a natural rightward displacement of the uterus during pregnancy and does not require correction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Uterine displacement is performed to relieve aortocaval compression during resuscitation in pregnant women.
  • By reducing pressure on the inferior vena cava and aorta, it improves maternal venous return and stabilizes circulation, which is critical in the management of unconscious or trauma patients in late pregnancy.

choices.text: Perform a vaginal examination to determine fetal presentation
Manually elevate the presenting fetal part and prepare for urgent cesarean delivery
Place the patient in the Trendelenburg position and observe
Gently attempt to replace the umbilical cord back inside the vagina

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman in active labor is being examined, and the midwife notes a visible umbilical cord prolapse. The fetal heart rate shows decelerations. What is the next immediate step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Manually elevate the presenting fetal part and prepare for urgent cesarean delivery

 

  • Umbilical cord prolapse is an obstetric emergency where the umbilical cord descends through the cervix alongside or past the presenting fetal part, leading to the risk of cord compression and compromised fetal oxygenation.
  • The immediate goal is to relieve pressure on the umbilical cord and ensure adequate fetal perfusion until delivery.
  • The most effective immediate action is to manually elevate the presenting fetal part to relieve pressure on the cord while preparing for an urgent cesarean delivery, as this is the definitive treatment.
  • The patient should also be positioned to maximize relief of cord compression, such as in Trendelenburg or knee-chest position, but the most critical intervention is manual elevation of the presenting part.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perform a vaginal examination to determine fetal presentation: Incorrect. While determining fetal presentation is important in labor, once a cord prolapse is diagnosed, the priority is to relieve cord compression and expedite delivery. Vaginal examination can exacerbate cord compression and delay necessary intervention.

 

Option C. Place the patient in the Trendelenburg position and observe: Incorrect. While the Trendelenburg position can help reduce pressure on the umbilical cord, it is not sufficient on its own. Immediate intervention is needed to relieve pressure on the cord, and observation alone is not appropriate.

 

Option D. Gently attempt to replace the umbilical cord back inside the vagina: Incorrect. Attempting to replace the cord can further compromise blood flow through the cord and risk injury to the fetus. The focus should be on relieving compression, not replacing the cord.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of umbilical cord prolapse, immediate management involves manually elevating the presenting fetal part to relieve pressure on the umbilical cord and preparing for urgent cesarean delivery.
  • Cord prolapse can result in fetal hypoxia, and timely intervention is critical for fetal survival.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with generalized swelling and frothy urine. He was diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome three months ago and started on corticosteroids, but his proteinuria has not improved. His urine protein excretion is 5 g/day, and a renal biopsy shows effacement of podocyte foot processes on electron microscopy, with no immune deposits. The patient is negative for hepatitis and HIV infections. Which of the following mutations is most likely responsible for this patient’s steroid-resistant condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NPHS1 (nephrin) gene mutation

 

  • Mutation causes defects in nephrin, leading to disruption of the podocyte slit diaphragm, resulting in proteinuria and steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome.
  • Mutations in NPHS1 → congenital nephrotic syndrome of the Finnish type but also associated with steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome in children.
  • It causes:
    • Massive proteinuria
    • Foot process effacement
    • Steroid non-responsiveness
    • No immune complex deposition
    • Electron microscopy shows diffuse foot process effacement, without immune deposits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. COL4A5 (type IV collagen) gene mutation: Incorrect. Mutations in COL4A5 are associated with Alport syndrome, which involves defects in the basement membrane leading to hematuria, progressive renal failure, and hearing loss, not the nephrotic syndrome with podocyte effacement described in this case.

 

Option C. PKD1 (polycystin) gene mutation: Incorrect. Mutations in PKD1 are associated with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), which typically presents with cyst formation in the kidneys, hypertension, and kidney failure, not nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option D. PAX2 gene mutation: Incorrect. Mutations in PAX2 are linked to renal-coloboma syndrome, which causes renal hypoplasia and eye abnormalities, not nephrotic syndrome or podocyte effacement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome with podocyte effacement is often linked to mutations in genes responsible for the structural integrity of the glomerular filtration barrier, such as the NPHS1 (nephrin) gene, which plays a key role in maintaining the slit diaphragm between podocytes.

choices.text: Greater than 3 times the upper limit of AST or ALT.
Greater than 2 times the upper limit of bilirubin.
Jaundice to liver failure ratio of 3:1.
No other alternative cause of liver injury.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is enrolled in a clinical trial for a new medication to manage hyperlipidemia. After 8 weeks of treatment, he developed jaundice. The patient has no history of liver disease, and his liver function tests were normal prior to starting the medication. Which of the following statements is false regarding Hy's Law?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Jaundice to liver failure ratio of 3:1.

 

  • Hy's Law suggests that significant liver injury is indicated if there is an elevation of liver enzymes (AST or ALT) greater than three times the upper limit of normal and bilirubin greater than two times the upper limit of normal, with no other identified cause for liver injury. 
  • However, the jaundice to liver failure ratio does not typically apply as a specific ratio of 3:1; rather, it indicates the presence of liver injury, which can lead to liver failure without a defined ratio.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Greater than 3 times the upper limit of AST or ALT: This is a correct statement; Hy's Law specifies that AST or ALT must exceed three times the upper limit of normal.

 

Option B. Greater than 2 times the upper limit of bilirubin: This is also a correct statement, as Hy's Law requires that bilirubin levels be more than twice the upper limit of normal.

 

Option D. No other alternative cause of liver injury: This statement is correct, as Hy's Law requires ruling out other potential causes of liver injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hy's Law is important in identifying drug-induced liver injury and involves criteria regarding the elevation of liver enzymes and bilirubin levels, along with the exclusion of other causes of liver injury, but does not specifically define a ratio of jaundice to liver failure.

choices.text: Administer tocolytics and deliver at 37 weeks
Administer antihypertensive, magnesium sulfate, and proceed with delivery
Give steroid cover and delay delivery until steroid cover is complete

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman at 35 weeks and 5 days gestation presents to the labor and delivery unit with severe epigastric pain, headache, and blurred vision. Her blood pressure is 170/110 mmHg. She is having regular contractions, and on examination, her cervix is 3 cm dilated with intact membranes. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer antihypertensive, magnesium sulfate, and proceed with delivery

 

  • This patient presents with severe preeclampsia at 35 weeks of gestation, which is characterized by hypertension (BP ≥160/110 mmHg), signs of end-organ damage (epigastric pain, headache, blurred vision), and labor.
  • The immediate goals of management are to control her blood pressure with antihypertensives to prevent complications such as stroke, prevent seizures with magnesium sulfate, and proceed with delivery due to the severity of preeclampsia and the patient being at term or near-term (≥34 weeks).
  • Given that she is already in labor and near term, the most appropriate action is to proceed with delivery, as this is the definitive treatment for preeclampsia.
  • Delaying delivery or administering tocolytics is contraindicated in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer tocolytics and deliver at 37 weeks: Incorrect. Tocolytics are used to delay labor, but they are contraindicated in cases of severe preeclampsia due to the risk of worsening maternal and fetal outcomes. Delivery should not be delayed in this situation.

 

Option B. Conservative management and continue observation: Incorrect. Conservative management is inappropriate in cases of severe preeclampsia, especially with the patient already in labor. Immediate treatment and delivery are necessary.

 

Option D. Give steroid cover and delay delivery until steroid cover is complete: Incorrect. Corticosteroids are typically given to enhance fetal lung maturity in cases of preterm labor <34 weeks. In this case, the patient is already past 34 weeks, and delaying delivery for steroid cover is not appropriate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with severe preeclampsia at ≥34 weeks gestation, immediate management involves controlling blood pressure, preventing seizures with magnesium sulfate, and proceeding with delivery.
  • This is necessary to prevent maternal and fetal complications.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of bisphosphonates in the treatment of osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Promoting osteoclast apoptosis

 

  • Bisphosphonates work primarily by inducing apoptosis (programmed cell death) in osteoclasts.
  • When bisphosphonates are ingested, they are absorbed into the bone matrix.
  • When osteoclasts attach to the bone surface to resorb it, they take up bisphosphonates, which then disrupt their metabolic activity.
  • This disruption leads to an increase in osteoclast apoptosis, thereby reducing the number of osteoclasts available to resorb bone and ultimately slowing down the bone loss that occurs in osteoporosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stimulating osteoclast activity: Bisphosphonates do not stimulate osteoclast activity; in fact, they inhibit it. Osteoclasts are responsible for bone resorption (the process of breaking down bone tissue), and stimulating their activity would lead to increased bone loss, which is contrary to the goal of treating osteoporosis. In osteoporosis, there is an imbalance where bone resorption outpaces bone formation, and bisphosphonates aim to correct this imbalance.

 

Option B. Inhibiting osteoblast function: While bisphosphonates primarily target osteoclasts to reduce bone resorption, they do not directly inhibit osteoblast function. Osteoblasts are the cells responsible for bone formation, and preserving their function is crucial for maintaining bone density. Bisphosphonates do not have a significant negative impact on osteoblasts; rather, they work to stabilize bone remodeling by preventing excessive resorption.

 

Option D. Enhancing calcium absorption: Bisphosphonates do not enhance calcium absorption from the gastrointestinal tract. Instead, they work by decreasing bone resorption and, consequently, reducing the release of calcium from bones into the bloodstream. They may be used alongside calcium and vitamin D supplements to ensure adequate mineralization of bone, but their primary action is not to enhance calcium absorption.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Bisphosphonates promote osteoclast apoptosis, reducing bone resorption and helping to maintain or improve bone density in osteoporosis.

choices.text: FSH in the follicular phase

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents to your clinic with concerns about her fertility. She is trying to conceive and would like to understand her ovarian reserve, as she is aware that age may impact her chances of becoming pregnant. You are considering various tests to assess her ovarian reserve. Which of the following is the most accurate measure of ovarian reserve?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH)

 

  • Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) is considered the best and most accurate marker for ovarian reserve.
  • AMH is produced by granulosa cells of small growing follicles in the ovaries and reflects the quantity of remaining ovarian follicles.
  • The level of AMH correlates with the number of antral and pre-antral follicles, providing a reliable estimate of ovarian reserve.
  • AMH levels remain relatively stable throughout the menstrual cycle and decrease as a woman ages, making it a highly valuable tool for assessing fertility potential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FSH in the follicular phase: Incorrect. Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels in the early follicular phase (day 3) are commonly used to assess ovarian reserve, but FSH levels can fluctuate and are less reliable than AMH for predicting ovarian reserve.

 

Option B. Luteal phase LH: Incorrect. Luteinizing hormone (LH) levels in the luteal phase are not useful for assessing ovarian reserve. LH is primarily involved in ovulation and does not provide information about the remaining ovarian follicle pool.

 

Option C. Post-luteal phase LH: Incorrect. LH levels after the luteal phase do not reflect ovarian reserve and are not used for this purpose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) is the most accurate and reliable marker for assessing ovarian reserve.
  • It reflects the number of small growing follicles in the ovaries and remains stable throughout the menstrual cycle, providing valuable insight into fertility potential.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with progressive weakness in his legs and arms over the past 6 months. He reports difficulty walking and frequent falls. On examination, he has reduced deep tendon reflexes in all extremities, and sensation to vibration and proprioception is diminished in his feet. Nerve conduction studies show evidence of demyelination. A lumbar puncture reveals elevated cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) protein with normal cell count. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP)

 

  • The patient's progressive weakness, reduced deep tendon reflexes, diminished sensation to vibration and proprioception, along with the nerve conduction studies showing demyelination, suggest a chronic condition affecting the peripheral nerves. 
  • The elevated CSF protein with a normal cell count (albuminocytologic dissociation) is characteristic of CIDP, which is a chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Guillain-Barré syndrome: While this condition also presents with demyelination, it typically presents acutely and often follows a viral infection. It usually features a rapid onset of weakness and areflexia rather than the progressive weakness over 6 months seen in this patient.

 

Option B. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS): ALS primarily affects motor neurons leading to weakness and atrophy but typically does not show sensory loss or elevated CSF protein with a normal cell count.

 

Option D. Multifocal motor neuropathy (MMN): This condition usually presents with asymmetric motor weakness and typically does not involve sensory deficits or elevated CSF protein levels.

 

Educational Objective:
