  • Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) is characterized by progressive weakness, sensory loss, reduced reflexes, and a distinctive CSF profile of elevated protein with normal cell count, distinguishing it from other neuropathies.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with a raised, thick scar on her ear that developed after a piercing 2 years ago. The scar is firm, extends beyond the boundaries of the original wound, and continues to grow. She has a family history of similar scars in her mother and sister. Histologic examination of the lesion shows dense collagen bundles. Which of the following growth factors is most involved in the pathogenesis of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-β)

 

  • This patient has a keloid, characterized by excessive collagen deposition that extends beyond the borders of the original wound.
  • TGF-β plays a central role in promoting fibrosis and collagen production, which contributes to keloid formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidermal growth factor (EGF): Incorrect. EGF primarily stimulates keratinocyte and epithelial cell proliferation and is not primarily involved in excessive collagen deposition seen in keloids.

 

Option B. Platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF): Incorrect. PDGF stimulates fibroblast and smooth muscle cell proliferation but is less involved in the excessive collagen deposition seen in keloids compared to TGF-β.

 

Option C. Fibroblast growth factor (FGF): Incorrect. FGF is important for angiogenesis and wound healing, but its role is less central than TGF-β in the pathogenesis of keloids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-β) plays a major role in the pathogenesis of keloids by promoting fibroblast activity and excessive collagen deposition, leading to abnormal scar formation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presents with difficulty in controlling upward and downward eye movements. A lesion is suspected in a structure associated with the control of vertical gaze. Which of the following is the center for vertical gaze?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rostral Interstitial Nucleus of Cajal

 

  • The Rostral Interstitial Nucleus of Cajal (riMLF) is responsible for controlling vertical gaze, including both upward and downward movements, as well as torsional movements of the eyes.
  • It is located in the pretectal region of the midbrain and works in conjunction with other structures like the interstitial nucleus of Cajal and fibers of the posterior commissure to coordinate vertical eye movements.

 

 

Other Options:


 

Option A. Pontine Paramedian Reticular Formation (PPRF): This area is primarily responsible for horizontal gaze movements, especially conjugate movements toward the ipsilateral side.


 

Option B. Raphe Nucleus: This nucleus plays a role in serotonin production and is involved in regulating mood and sleep rather than gaze control.


 

Option D. Nucleus of Perlia: This nucleus is thought to be involved in convergence, and its exact function is still controversial and less understood compared to well-established structures like the rostral interstitial nucleus of Cajal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Rostral Interstitial Nucleus of Cajal is the primary center for controlling vertical gaze.
  • It works together with other midbrain nuclei to enable coordinated upward and downward eye movements.
  • In contrast, horizontal gaze is primarily controlled by the Pontine Paramedian Reticular Formation (PPRF).
  • Understanding these gaze centers is critical for localizing lesions in patients presenting with gaze palsies.

questions.text: A forensic expert is analyzing plant residues found at a crime scene in a rural area known for illicit drug activity. Among several samples, the expert finds leaf suspected to contain a substance with significant abuse potential, which is frequently trafficked and abused globally. Identify the plant, which is known for being the primary source of this substance?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Erythroxylum coca

 

  • Erythroxylum coca is the correct choice as it is known for being the primary source of cocaine, a substance with significant abuse potential.
  • Cocaine is derived from the leafs of this plant and has major implications in both forensic toxicology and criminal investigations due to its psychoactive effects and high potential for dependency and abuse.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Datura: While it contains toxic compounds such as scopolamine and atropine and is occasionally abused for its hallucinogenic effects, it is less commonly associated with global trafficking compared to cocaine.
 

Option C. Digitalis Purpura: Known as Digitalis purpurea, this plant is used medically for its cardiotonic glycosides like digoxin and digitoxin, and is not abused due to severe toxic effects and lack of psychoactive properties.
 

Option D. Cannabis: Although cannabis (marijuana) is widely abused for its psychoactive effects from THC, the context of global trafficking and powerful psychoactive substance fits better with cocaine derived from Erythroxylum coca.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cocaine is obtained from Erythroxylum coca, which can be identified by following features:
    • Leaf: Characteristic of the leaf is an areolated portion bounded by two longitudinal curved lines, one line on each side of the midrib.
    • Flowers are small, and disposed in little clusters on short stalks.
    • Red Berries: The flowers mature into red berries.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with bone pain and a history of recurrent kidney stones. X-rays of the bones reveal lytic lesions in the long bones. A bone biopsy of the lesion shows fibrous tissue with osteoclast-like giant cells, consistent with a brown tumor. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this bone lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperparathyroidism

 

  • Brown tumors are a hallmark finding in hyperparathyroidism, particularly severe or untreated cases.

  • Hyperparathyroidism leads to increased levels of PTH, which causes osteoclast activation and bone resorption.

  • This results in the formation of cystic bone lesions known as brown tumors.

  • These lesions contain fibrous tissue, osteoclasts, and hemosiderin, which gives them their characteristic brown color on histological examination.

  • Brown tumors are seen in conditions like primary hyperparathyroidism, usually due to a parathyroid adenoma, or in secondary hyperparathyroidism related to chronic renal failure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism: Incorrect. Hypothyroidism does not cause osteoclastic activity or the formation of brown tumors. It is more commonly associated with myopathy, weight gain, and bradycardia, rather than bone lesions.

 

Option B. Hypoparathyroidism: Incorrect. Hypoparathyroidism is characterized by low PTH levels and hypocalcemia, leading to symptoms like muscle cramps, tetany, and seizures. It does not cause the excessive bone resorption required for brown tumor formation.

 

Option D. Hyperthyroidism: Incorrect. Hyperthyroidism may cause increased bone turnover but does not specifically lead to brown tumors. The bone changes seen in hyperthyroidism are related to osteoporosis rather than osteoclastic resorption as seen in hyperparathyroidism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Brown tumors are cystic bone lesions seen in severe hyperparathyroidism, resulting from excessive osteoclastic activity and bone resorption due to elevated PTH levels.

questions.text: A 58-year-old diabetic male presents with progressive worsening of vision. On examination, fundus findings suggest neovascularization. Fluorescein angiography findings is shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Proliferative diabetic retinopathy

 

  • The image demonstrates the features of proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR), characterized by neovascularization arising from the optic nerve head (neovascularization of the disc, NVD), as well as neovascularization along larger retinal vessels and elsewhere (NVE).
  • These new, fragile blood vessels develop in response to retinal ischemia and can lead to severe complications like vitreous hemorrhage or retinal detachment if untreated.
  • The presence of neovascularization is a key distinguishing feature of PDR.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Mild non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR): In mild NPDR, microaneurysms and intraretinal hemorrhages are present, but there is no neovascularization, which is the hallmark of proliferative disease.
 

Option B. Severe non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy: Severe NPDR is characterized by increased microaneurysms, venous beading, and intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) but still lacks the neovascularization seen in PDR.
 

Option C. Birdshot choroidopathy: Birdshot choroidopathy presents with characteristic yellow-white lesions scattered across the fundus and is not typically associated with neovascularization. It is a type of posterior uveitis that affects the choroid and retina bilaterally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy is the advanced stage of diabetic eye disease, marked by neovascularization, which requires aggressive treatment like laser photocoagulation to prevent severe visual loss.
  • It is crucial for diabetics, particularly those with a long history or poorly controlled diabetes, to undergo regular eye examinations for early detection and management of diabetic retinopathy.

choices.text: Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman underwent a total thyroidectomy for a large goiter. Two hours postoperatively, she develops acute onset stridor and difficulty breathing while in the recovery room. Her voice is normal, but she has inspiratory stridor and increased work of breathing. The surgical site shows no signs of swelling or hematoma. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bilateral vocal cord paralysis

 

  • The clinical presentation of acute onset stridor with a normal voice shortly after thyroid surgery is highly suggestive of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury leading to bilateral vocal cord paralysis.
  • When both recurrent laryngeal nerves are injured, the vocal cords remain in a paramedian position, leading to airway narrowing, stridor, and respiratory distress while preserving normal phonation.
  • This condition requires prompt recognition and airway management, often necessitating reintubation and tracheostomy for securing the airway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hematoma compressing the trachea: A hematoma would typically present with swelling at the surgical site and would cause external compression of the trachea, not vocal cord paralysis.

 

Option C. Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury: Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury usually presents with hoarseness rather than stridor and is less likely to cause acute airway compromise.

 

Option D. Laryngospasm: Laryngospasm is a sudden spasm of the vocal cords, often transient and usually related to irritation, anesthesia, or hypocalcemia. It is less likely in a patient with normal calcium levels and no history of laryngeal stimulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients presenting with postoperative stridor after thyroid surgery, bilateral vocal cord paralysis should be considered, especially if the voice remains normal.
  • Immediate airway management is crucial, as the condition can progress rapidly to airway obstruction.

choices.text: Mouth then nose then esophagus
Trachea then nose then mouth

questions.text: A term neonate is delivered via emergency cesarean section due to fetal distress. At birth, the baby is not crying and appears limp with poor muscle tone. The delivery team initiates neonatal resuscitation, including suctioning to clear the airway. What is the correct order of suctioning during neonatal resuscitation to reduce the risk of aspiration?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mouth then nose

 

  • During neonatal resuscitation, the mouth is suctioned first followed by the nose.
  • This order is important to reduce the risk of aspiration.
  • Suctioning the nose first can stimulate the infant to gasp and potentially inhale secretions into the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nose then mouth: Suctioning the nose first increases the risk of aspiration, as it can cause the neonate to gasp before clearing secretions from the mouth.

 

Option C. Mouth then nose then esophagus: Routine suctioning of the esophagus is not recommended in neonatal resuscitation unless there is a specific indication, as it can cause a vagal response and bradycardia.

 

Option D. Trachea then nose then mouth: Routine tracheal suctioning is not indicated unless there is evidence of meconium aspiration and the infant is not vigorous (e.g., poor tone, respiratory effort).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In neonatal resuscitation, suctioning should follow the order of mouth first, then nose, to reduce the risk of aspiration.
  • The suction pressure should be kept between 80-100 mm Hg using a 12 or 14 French suction catheter to prevent injury to the delicate neonatal tissues.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is undergoing emergency laparotomy due to severe blunt abdominal trauma resulting in liver injury and significant bleeding. During the surgery, the surgeon applies a clamp to a structure within the hepatoduodenal ligament to temporarily control the bleeding and allow time to assess the liver damage. Which of the following structures is primarily compressed during this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Portal vein & hepatic artery

 

  • Pringle’s maneuver is a surgical technique used to control bleeding from the liver, particularly in cases of trauma or during liver surgeries.
  • It involves clamping or compressing the hepatoduodenal ligament, which contains the portal vein, hepatic artery, and common bile duct.
  • By compressing the hepatoduodenal ligament, the surgeon temporarily occludes blood flow through the portal vein and hepatic artery, which are the main blood vessels supplying the liver.
  • This maneuver helps to control bleeding until more definitive surgical measures can be taken.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hepatic vein & hepatic artery: Incorrect. The hepatic veins drain blood from the liver into the inferior vena cava and are not located within the hepatoduodenal ligament. Pringle’s maneuver targets vessels that supply blood to the liver, not those that drain it.

 

Option C. Common bile duct & hepatic vein: Incorrect. While the common bile duct is located within the hepatoduodenal ligament, the hepatic veins are not. The hepatic veins are located posteriorly in the liver and drain into the inferior vena cava, so they are not involved in Pringle’s maneuver.

 

Option D. Common bile duct & portal vein: Incorrect. The portal vein is one of the structures compressed during Pringle’s maneuver, but the focus is on controlling blood flow through the portal vein and hepatic artery, not the common bile duct. The bile duct is not a major target for controlling hemorrhage in this procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pringle’s maneuver is used to temporarily control liver bleeding by compressing the hepatoduodenal ligament, which occludes the portal vein and hepatic artery.
  • This maneuver helps to reduce blood flow to the liver during traumatic injuries or liver surgeries, providing time for further surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman has been on a prolonged fast for two days, consuming only water. During this period, her body has shifted its metabolism to maintain blood glucose levels and provide energy. Which of the following enzymes would have decreased activity during this fasting state?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phosphofructokinase 1

 

  • Phosphofructokinase 1 (PFK-1) is a key enzyme in glycolysis, responsible for the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate.
  • During fasting, the body aims to conserve glucose and instead increases gluconeogenesis and fatty acid oxidation.
  • PFK-1 activity decreases as glycolysis is downregulated in favor of gluconeogenesis.
  • The reduction in insulin and the increase in glucagon during fasting inhibit PFK-1, leading to decreased glycolytic flux.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyruvate carboxylase: Incorrect. Pyruvate carboxylase is an enzyme involved in gluconeogenesis, converting pyruvate to oxaloacetate. During fasting, gluconeogenesis is upregulated to maintain blood glucose levels, so pyruvate carboxylase activity increases, not decreases.

 

Option B. Glycogen phosphorylase: Incorrect. Glycogen phosphorylase is responsible for glycogenolysis, breaking down glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate. During fasting, glycogen stores are mobilized to maintain blood glucose levels, so glycogen phosphorylase activity increases during this time.

 

Option C. Hormone-sensitive lipase: Incorrect. Hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) is involved in the breakdown of stored triglycerides into free fatty acids in adipose tissue. During fasting, HSL is activated by glucagon and epinephrine, leading to increased lipolysis for energy production. Thus, its activity increases, not decreases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During fasting, the body prioritizes gluconeogenesis and fatty acid oxidation over glycolysis to maintain blood glucose levels.
  • Phosphofructokinase 1 (PFK-1) activity decreases as glycolysis is downregulated, while enzymes involved in gluconeogenesis and lipolysis are upregulated.

choices.text: Proximal tibia, anteromedial from the tibial tuberosity
Distal radius, near the wrist joint

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents to the emergency department in hypovolemic shock following a motor vehicle accident. Despite multiple attempts, intravenous access could not be obtained within 90 seconds. The decision is made to establish intraosseous (IO) access. Which of the following is the most appropriate site for intraosseous cannulation in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Proximal tibia, anteromedial from the tibial tuberosity

 

  • The proximal tibia is the most common and preferred site for intraosseous cannulation in children due to its accessibility and the presence of a rich vascular network.
  • Insertion is typically 1-2 cm anteromedial from the tibial tuberosity, which allows for rapid infusion of fluids and medications in emergency situations when IV access is not feasible.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midshaft of the humerus: The midshaft of the humerus is not a recommended site for initial IO access, especially in pediatric patients.

 

Option C. Distal femur, lateral condyle: The distal femur can be used as an alternative site in infants and young children but is not as commonly used as the proximal tibia.

 

Option D. Distal radius, near the wrist joint: The distal radius is not a typical site for intraosseous access in emergency situations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intraosseous (IO) access is an effective alternative for rapid fluid and medication administration in emergency situations when intravenous access cannot be established.
  • Common sites for IO cannulation include the proximal tibia (1-2 cm anteromedial from the tibial tuberosity), distal femur, and distal tibia near the medial malleolus.

choices.text: Recurrence can occur due to neovascularisation
Saphenous nerve injury causes loss of sensation in the medial aspect of the leg
The sural nerve is in danger during stripping of the great saphenous vein
Deep vein thrombosis can occur postoperatively

questions.text: A 45-year-old male undergoes surgery for varicose veins. During the procedure, the surgeon strips the great saphenous vein. Which of the following statements regarding complications of varicose vein surgery is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The sural nerve is in danger during stripping of the great saphenous vein

 

  • The sural nerve runs laterally alongside the short saphenous vein, not the great saphenous vein.
  • Therefore, the sural nerve is more likely to be injured during stripping of the short saphenous vein, not the great saphenous vein.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recurrence can occur due to neovascularisation: Some surgeons have argued that surgical trauma and subsequent inflammation in the groin are associated with neovascularisation, which in turn may lead to recurrence

 

Option B. Saphenous nerve injury causes loss of sensation in the medial aspect of the leg: The saphenous nerve accompanies the great saphenous vein medially, and injury to it during surgery can result in sensory loss in the medial aspect of the leg.

 

Option D. Deep vein thrombosis can occur postoperatively: Surgery involving the veins can lead to venous stasis and predispose patients to deep vein thrombosis, especially in the postoperative period.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • In varicose vein surgery, injury to the saphenous nerve is a common complication due to its close proximity to the great saphenous vein.
  • However, the sural nerve is at risk during stripping of the short saphenous vein, not the great saphenous vein.
  • Postoperative complications include lymphedema and deep vein thrombosis.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents with asymptomatic patchy hair loss that she noticed over the past several months. She reports that the areas of hair loss are smooth and shiny with adherent scaling noted in few areas. Physical examination reveals atrophic patches with evidence of scarring on the scalp. Carpet tack sign was positive on removal of scales. There are no associated lesions elsewhere on her skin or nails. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Discoid lupus erythematosus

 

  • This patient presents with cicatricial (scarring) alopecia, characterized by patchy hair loss in areas that are smooth, shiny, and atrophic, with evidence of scarring and few areas of adherent scaling.
  • One of the most common causes of scarring alopecia is discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE), a chronic autoimmune condition that affects the skin.
  • In DLE, inflammatory processes lead to permanent destruction of hair follicles and result in scarring.
  • The hallmark of DLE is scarring and atrophic plaques, which can occur on the scalp, causing irreversible hair loss.
  • Carpet tack sign positivity also points to the diagnosis of DLE.
  • The presence of these smooth, shiny areas of scarring strongly points toward DLE in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lichen planopilaris: Lichen planopilaris is a variant of lichen planus that affects hair follicles and can cause scarring alopecia. However, the presentation is usually accompanied by pruritus and associated skin lesions and nail involvement, which were not noted in this case. Also Carpet tack sign is not associated with LPP.

 

Option B. Tinea capitis: Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp, commonly seen in children. It often presents with itchy lesions over scalp, and inflammatory variants, kerion & favus present with boggy swelling or scutula respectively, both of which are not mentioned in the question.

 

Option C. Alopecia areata: Alopecia areata is an autoimmune condition that causes non-scarring hair loss with smooth, round patches of hair loss. However, there is no scarring or atrophy in alopecia areata, and hair can often regrow in the affected areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE) is a chronic autoimmune condition that can cause cicatricial (scarring) alopecia.
  • Patients with DLE often present with smooth, shiny, atrophic patches of hair loss with adherent scaling showing Carpet tack sign positivity, which is a key feature that distinguishes DLE from other causes of hair loss.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs corresponds to Drug A?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Doxycycline

 

  • Doxycycline is a tetracycline antibiotic that binds to the 30S ribosomal subunit of bacterial ribosomes.
  • It prevents the attachment of aminoacyl-tRNA to the A site on the ribosome, thereby inhibiting the addition of new amino acids to the growing polypeptide chain.
  • This action effectively halts bacterial protein synthesis, making it bacteriostatic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chloramphenicol: This drug binds to the 50S ribosomal subunit and inhibits peptidyl transferase, preventing the formation of peptide bonds between amino acids during protein elongation. It does not act at the A site or involve the 30S subunit.

 

Option C. Azithromycin: Azithromycin is a macrolide that binds to the 50S ribosomal subunit, blocking translocation during protein synthesis. It does not inhibit the binding of aminoacyl-tRNA at the 30S subunit.

 

Option D. Penicillin G: Penicillin G is a beta-lactam antibiotic that inhibits cell wall synthesis by blocking transpeptidase enzymes involved in peptidoglycan cross-linking. It does not act on the ribosome or protein synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Doxycycline inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by targeting the 30S ribosomal subunit and preventing the binding of aminoacyl-tRNA to the A site.
  • Chloramphenicol and azithromycin act on the 50S subunit, but with different mechanisms.
  • Penicillin G acts on bacterial cell wall synthesis, not on the ribosomal machinery.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman is bitten by a stray dog and presents to the clinic for post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) for rabies. Which of the following statements is correct regarding rabies PEP?

 

  1. Category I exposure requires both vaccine and immunoglobulin.
  2. Immunoglobulin is not needed if the patient has received prior full rabies vaccination.
  3. Local wound cleaning is essential in all cases of dog bites.
  4. Vaccination is stopped if the dog dies within 3 days of the bite.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3

 

  • Statement 2: Correct. If a patient has previously received a full rabies vaccination series, rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) is not required. In such cases, booster doses of the rabies vaccine are administered after exposure.
  • Statement 3: Correct. Local wound cleaning is a critical step in rabies PEP and should be performed in all cases of animal bites. It helps reduce the viral load at the wound site, decreasing the chance of infection.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Statement 1: Incorrect. Category I exposure involves minor contact with animals, such as touching or feeding, with no skin breach. This does not require PEP unless there is a high suspicion of rabies. Category II and III exposures are the ones that require vaccine and possibly immunoglobulin.
  • Statement 4: Incorrect. Vaccination should not be stopped even if the dog dies within 3 days of the bite, as rabies can remain asymptomatic in the animal for some time. PEP should be continued based on the exposure risk and clinical judgment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post Exposure Prophylaxis of Rabies Guidelines

 

  • Category-wise PEP measures:
    • Category I wound: None
    • Category II wound: Local treatment of wound +Immediate vaccination
    • Category III wound: Local treatment of wound +Immediate vaccination + Immediate immunoglobulin
  • PEP is discontinued if:
    • Suspected animal proved free of rabies by an appropriate laboratory
    • In case of domestic animal, latter remains healthy throughout 10-day observation period from day of bite
  • Rabies Immunoglobulin is NOT indicated in previously vaccinated individuals

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a history of progressive abdominal discomfort and early satiety. Physical examination reveals hepatomegaly, with the liver palpable 10 cm below the costal margin. A CT scan of the abdomen is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydatid cyst

 

  • The CT scan findings of multilocular cysts with calcifications, septations, and daughter cysts, along with the characteristic cartwheel or spoke-wheel appearance, are highly suggestive of hydatid cyst.
  • This condition is caused by infection with the parasite Echinococcus, and it commonly involves the liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amoebic liver abscess: This would present with a solitary lesion, often without the characteristic daughter cysts or calcifications.

 

Option C. Hepatic adenoma: It is usually a solitary, well-defined, non-cystic lesion that does not have the septations or calcifications seen in hydatid disease.

 

Option D. Pyogenic liver abscess: This typically presents as a solitary or multiple abscess with fluid levels and may show air-fluid levels, but without the classic cartwheel or daughter cyst appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hydatid cysts, caused by Echinococcus species, present with multiloculated cystic lesions on imaging, often with calcifications, septations, and daughter cysts.
  • They are a parasitic infection commonly transmitted via contact with dogs or sheep.
  • Treatment involves anti-parasitic drugs and possibly surgical intervention.

questions.text: A forensic expert is investigating a case of suspected suffocation. The cause of death involves various types of mechanical asphyxia, but one listed method is not classified under suffocation. Which of the following is not typically considered a type of suffocation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Throttling

 

  • Throttling refers to manual strangulation, which involves external compression of the neck using the hands or another object to obstruct blood vessels and the airway, ultimately causing asphyxia.
  • It does not fall under the category of suffocation, which involves blockage of airflow rather than compression of the neck.

 

Other Options:


 

Option A. Smothering: Involves obstructing the external air passages (e.g., nose and mouth) with an external object, thereby preventing breathing and leading to suffocation.


 

Option B. Choking: Involves blockage of the internal airway (e.g., by a foreign body in the throat or trachea) that prevents the individual from breathing properly.


 

Option D. Gagging: Gagging is a type of suffocation where an obstruction is placed in or around the mouth to prevent the individual from breathing adequately, resulting in asphyxia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Suffocation refers to a condition where the airway is obstructed, either internally or externally, leading to hypoxia.
  • Throttling is a form of manual strangulation involving direct pressure on the neck, which makes it distinct from other types of suffocation, such as smothering, choking, and gagging.
  • Recognizing these differences is essential in forensic medicine for accurately determining the mechanism of death in asphyxia cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fever, facial swelling, and nasal congestion. He is immunocompromised due to poorly controlled diabetes mellitus and is diagnosed with mucormycosis. Which of the following cell wall components is notably absent or minimally present in the fungal pathogen causing mucormycosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beta 1, 3, glucan

 

  • Mucormycosis is caused by fungi of the order Mucorales such as Mucor and Rhizopus.
  • The cell walls of these fungi lack significant amounts of Beta 1, 3 glucan, which is otherwise a common polysaccharide present in the cell walls of most other fungi.
  • Beta 1, 3 glucan serves as a major structural component in most fungi and is important in diagnostic tests like the Beta-D-Glucan (BDG) test, which is positive for infections like candidiasis and aspergillosis but is typically negative in mucormycosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mannoproteins: These are present in most fungal cell walls, including those of mucor species. They play roles in adherence and immune evasion.

 

Option C. Chitin: Chitin provides structural strength to the fungal cell wall and is a common component found across various fungal species, including mucor.

 

Option D. Ergosterol: Ergosterol is a component of the fungal cell membrane, not the cell wall, and is found in nearly all fungal species, including those causing mucormycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Beta 1, 3 glucan is notably absent or present at very low levels in fungi causing mucormycosis, unlike in other fungi like Candida or Aspergillus.
  • This absence is clinically significant since diagnostic tests for Beta-D-Glucan are negative in mucormycosis.

choices.text: Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure
Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to left ventricular pressure

questions.text: Which of the following best explains the rise in blood pressure during the early phase of the Valsalva maneuver?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure

 

  • The Valsalva maneuver consists of forced expiration against a closed glottis, which increases intrathoracic pressure.
  • During Phase I of the maneuver, the rise in intrathoracic pressure is transmitted to the aorta, resulting in a transient increase in blood pressure.
  • This occurs because the elevated pressure in the thoracic cavity temporarily compresses the aorta, leading to an increase in aortic pressure before the blood flow begins to decrease due to reduced venous return.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase in left atrial pressure: Incorrect. While intrathoracic pressure increases left atrial pressure during the Valsalva maneuver, this does not directly cause the rise in blood pressure observed during Phase I. The pressure rise is primarily due to increased aortic pressure.

 

Option B. Increase in left ventricular volume: Incorrect. Left ventricular volume does not increase during the initial phase of the Valsalva maneuver. In fact, as intrathoracic pressure increases, venous return to the heart decreases, leading to a subsequent decrease in left ventricular filling during later phases.

 

Option D. Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to left ventricular pressure: Incorrect. Although intrathoracic pressure increases during the Valsalva maneuver, the immediate rise in blood pressure is due to the increase in aortic pressure rather than left ventricular pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During Phase I of the Valsalva maneuver, the increase in intrathoracic pressure is transmitted to the aorta, resulting in a transient rise in aortic pressure and blood pressure.
  • This precedes the drop in venous return that characterizes later phases of the maneuver.

questions.text: Match the following types of teeth with their typical ages of eruption in children and adolescents.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4

 

  • The chronology of eruption of secondary dentition or permanent teeth is as follows:
    • Canine: Erupts at 11-12 years (A-3)
    • Lateral incisor: Erupts at 8-9 years (B-2)
    • First molar: The first molars are among the earliest permanent teeth to erupt, usually appearing at 6-7 years of age. (C-1)
    • Third molar: Third molars, or "wisdom teeth," are the last to erupt and typically appear between 17-25 years of age. (D-4)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronology of eruption of secondary dentition or permanent teeth:
 

 

Mnemonic: Mother Is In Pain Papa Can Make Medicine

questions.text: A 28-year-old man visits the clinic for a routine checkup. During the neurological examination, you assess his sensory perception. The patient is able to sense skin stretching and responds appropriately to joint position changes. These sensory modalities are primarily mediated by mechanoreceptors located in the skin and joints. Which of the following mechanoreceptors is most likely responsible for detecting skin stretch and contributing to joint position sense in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ruffini corpuscles

 

  • Ruffini corpuscles are slowly adapting mechanoreceptors found in the skin and joints.
  • They are specialized for detecting skin stretch and are involved in providing information related to joint position and movement.
  • Ruffini corpuscles play a critical role in proprioception, helping the body understand limb positioning and the movement of joints, as well as the stretching of skin during movement.
  • This allows the patient to accurately perceive changes in skin tension and the position of their joints, as described in this clinical case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pacinian corpuscles: Incorrect. Pacinian corpuscles are mechanoreceptors that detect deep pressure and vibration, not skin stretch or joint position sense. They are rapidly adapting and respond to transient mechanical changes rather than continuous skin stretch or proprioceptive input.

 

Option B. Meissner corpuscles: Incorrect. Meissner corpuscles are rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors responsible for detecting light touch and fine tactile discrimination, especially in areas like the fingertips. They do not detect skin stretch or provide information about joint position.

 

Option D. Merkel cells: Incorrect. Merkel cells are mechanoreceptors that detect sustained pressure and texture, helping in fine tactile sensing such as detecting textures and shapes. However, they are not involved in sensing skin stretch or joint position.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ruffini corpuscles are mechanoreceptors responsible for detecting skin stretch and providing information about joint position and movement, playing an essential role in proprioception.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with symptoms of chronic diarrhea. A stool sample is collected and processed using the formal-ether concentration technique to examine for the presence of parasites. The specimen is labelled with four different layers (A, B, C, D) after centrifugation. At which layer are parasitic ova most likely to be found under the microscope?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Layer D

 

 

  • The formal-ether concentration technique is a sedimentation method used to isolate parasitic ova, cysts, and larvae from stool samples.
  • It relies on the differential densities of fecal debris and parasitic organisms.
  • The heavier parasitic elements, including ova and cysts, settle at the bottom of the tube and are concentrated in the sediment, which is referred to as Layer D in this scenario.
  • Thus, parasitic ova are most likely found at the bottom sediment layer (Layer D).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Layer A: This level contains ether, which is used to extract fecal debris.

 

Option B. Layer B: This level is where the plug of debris is found after centrifugation.

 

Option C. Layer C: This level contains formalin, which fixes and preserves the morphology of the parasitic elements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The formal-ether concentration technique for stool samples is a sedimentation method where parasitic ova, cysts, and larvae settle at the bottom of the tube after centrifugation.
  • The bottom layer (Layer D) contains the concentrated parasitic elements.

questions.text: A 34-year-old pregnant woman at 36 weeks gestation presents to the emergency department with continuous vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain. She has a history of chronic hypertension. On examination, her vitals are stable, and the uterus is tense and tender. Ultrasound confirms placental abruption. The fetal heart rate is normal. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Induction of labor

 

  • In cases of placental abruption where maternal vitals are stable, the fetal heart rate is normal, and the gestational age is 36 weeks, the preferred management is induction of labor.
  • Placental abruption refers to the premature detachment of the placenta from the uterine wall, which can lead to serious complications for both the mother and fetus.
  • Since the fetus is near term and both the mother and fetus are stable, inducing labor is the safest option to expedite delivery and prevent further complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer magnesium sulfate: Incorrect. Magnesium sulfate is typically used for seizure prophylaxis in patients with preeclampsia or eclampsia, which is not relevant in this case of stable placental abruption.

 

Option C. Perform fetal scalp pH monitoring: Incorrect. Fetal scalp pH monitoring is used to assess fetal well-being during labor, particularly if there is concern for fetal distress. In this case, there is no evidence of fetal distress, and it is not indicated.

 

Option D. Administer antibiotics: Incorrect. Antibiotics would be necessary if there was a concern for infection, such as chorioamnionitis, which is not present in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of placental abruption at or near term (≥36 weeks), with stable maternal and fetal conditions, induction of labor is the preferred management.
  • Immediate cesarean section is reserved for cases with signs of fetal distress or maternal instability.

choices.text: Dorsal lingual branches of the lingual artery
Tonsillar branch of the facial artery
Descending palatine branch of the maxillary artery

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents to the emergency department with a sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and a fever of 39.2°C (102.5°F). Physical examination reveals swollen and erythematous tonsils with exudates bilaterally. The child is diagnosed with acute tonsillitis. During a routine tonsillectomy, there is significant bleeding from the tonsillar bed. Which of the following arteries is most likely the primary source of the hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tonsillar branch of the facial artery

 

  • The tonsillar branch of the facial artery is the primary source of blood supply to the palatine tonsils.
  • During a tonsillectomy, this vessel is the most likely source of significant bleeding.
  • Other arteries that contribute to the blood supply of the tonsil include the ascending palatine branch of the facial artery, the ascending pharyngeal artery (branch of the external carotid), dorsal lingual branches of the lingual artery, and descending palatine branches of the maxillary artery.
  • However, the tonsillar branch of the facial artery is typically the dominant vessel and thus most often implicated in hemorrhage during tonsillectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The tonsillar branch of the facial artery is the main arterial supply to the palatine tonsils, and it is the most common source of hemorrhage during tonsillectomy.

choices.text: Abnormal synthesis of collagen leading to lung and liver fibrosis
Deposition of misfolded α1-antitrypsin proteins in the lungs
Destruction of alveolar walls due to neutrophil elastase activity
Autoimmune attack on hepatocytes and alveoli

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic cough and progressive shortness of breath presents with worsening dyspnea. He has a 10 pack-year smoking history but quit 10 years ago. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds bilaterally and hyperresonance to percussion. Spirometry shows a FEV1/FVC ratio of 55% and a reduced diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO). A liver biopsy performed for abnormal liver enzymes reveals periodic Acid-Schiff (PAS)-positive, diastase-resistant inclusions within hepatocytes. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for this patient’s lung and liver findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Destruction of alveolar walls due to neutrophil elastase activity

 

  • This patient has alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency, a condition that leads to unregulated neutrophil elastase activity due to lack of functional AAT, resulting in destruction of alveolar walls and panacinar emphysema.
  • The PAS-positive, diastase-resistant inclusions in hepatocytes represent accumulated misfolded AAT proteins, leading to liver disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abnormal synthesis of collagen leading to lung and liver fibrosis: Incorrect. This describes conditions like pulmonary fibrosis and cirrhosis, but this patient’s lung findings (emphysema) are due to elastase activity, not fibrosis.

 

Option B. Deposition of misfolded α1-antitrypsin proteins in the lungs: Incorrect. The misfolded AAT accumulates in the liver, not the lungs. The lung damage is due to elastase activity.

 

Option D. Autoimmune attack on hepatocytes and alveoli: Incorrect. This describes conditions like autoimmune hepatitis or Goodpasture syndrome, but the lung and liver findings here are due to AAT deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • α1-antitrypsin deficiency leads to uncontrolled neutrophil elastase activity, causing alveolar wall destruction (emphysema) and misfolded protein accumulation in the liver, manifesting as PAS-positive, diastase-resistant inclusions.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with fever, sore throat, and generalized fatigue. Laboratory studies reveal an absolute neutrophil count (ANC) of 400/mm³, consistent with agranulocytosis. Which of the following drugs is most likely to cause agranulocytosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methimazole

 

  • Methimazole is an antithyroid medication that can cause agranulocytosis as a rare but serious side effect.
  • It is used to treat hyperthyroidism, such as Graves' disease.
  • Agranulocytosis can present with symptoms like fever, sore throat, and signs of infection.
  • Patients on methimazole should be advised to seek immediate medical attention if they develop such symptoms, as agranulocytosis can be life-threatening.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ibuprofen: While ibuprofen (a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, or NSAID) can cause gastrointestinal and renal side effects, it is not typically associated with causing agranulocytosis.

 

Option C. Prednisone: Prednisone, a corticosteroid, can cause leukocytosis (an increase in white blood cell count) rather than agranulocytosis. It can suppress the immune system but is not directly associated with severe reductions in neutrophil counts.

 

Option D. Hydroxychloroquine: Hydroxychloroquine is an immunomodulatory drug used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and lupus. It can cause rare hematological side effects, such as aplastic anemia, but agranulocytosis is far more commonly linked to methimazole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Methimazole can cause agranulocytosis, a serious side effect that requires patients to be vigilant about symptoms like fever and sore throat.
  • NSAIDs like ibuprofen and corticosteroids like prednisone are not typically associated with agranulocytosis.
  • Hydroxychloroquine has rare hematologic side effects but is less commonly linked to agranulocytosis compared to methimazole.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with progressive hearing loss that started during her second pregnancy. She has a family history of hearing loss in her mother. On examination, Rinne test is negative bilaterally, and Weber test localizes to the left ear. Tympanic membranes appear normal. What is the most likely underlying pathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Otosclerosis

 

  • This patient's presentation is consistent with otosclerosis, which is characterized by progressive conductive hearing loss, often noted during or after pregnancy due to hormonal influences that can exacerbate the condition.
  • The family history of hearing loss supports a hereditary predisposition, and the negative Rinne test (indicative of conductive hearing loss) further suggests otosclerosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endolymphatic hydrops: Endolymphatic hydrops (Meniere's disease) is characterized by episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness, which are not described in this case.

 

Option C. Acoustic neuroma: Acoustic neuroma typically presents with asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss and may involve tinnitus or imbalance but not conductive hearing loss.

 

Option D. Eustachian tube dysfunction: Eustachian tube dysfunction can cause conductive hearing loss, but it usually presents with symptoms like ear fullness or a history of recurrent upper respiratory infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Otosclerosis is a common cause of progressive conductive hearing loss, often presenting in young adults, particularly women, and may be exacerbated by hormonal changes such as pregnancy.
  • Diagnosis is supported by family history, clinical testing (e.g., negative Rinne test), and can be confirmed with impedance audiometry.

questions.text: A 48-year-old female with a history of renal transplantation 4 months prior is being evaluated for renal function. Which imaging modality should be utilized for functional assessment of her transplanted kidney?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tc 99m MAG3

 

  • Tc 99m MAG3 is ideal for renal function evaluation in transplant recipients because it provides information on both glomerular filtration and tubular excretion

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tc 99m DMSA: Incorrect. Tc 99m DMSA primarily assesses the renal cortex and is used for evaluating renal scarring and pyelonephritis, not routinely for post-transplant function.

 

Option B. Tc 99m DTPA: Incorrect. Tc 99m DTPA measures the glomerular filtration rate but does not provide information on tubular function, which is significant in the evaluation of a transplanted kidney.

 

Option C. Captopril DTPA: Incorrect. Captopril DTPA is used for the detection of renovascular hypertension, not routine post-transplant renal function assessment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most appropriate nuclear medicine imaging test to assess renal function in a patient who has undergone renal transplantation is Tc 99m MAG3 scan because it measures renal perfusion, function, and urinary excretion effectively in the post-transplant setting.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with schizophrenia is being treated with an antipsychotic drug. The patient has a history of developing extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) with previous medications and prefers a drug that will not cause these side effects. Which of the following drugs is known to cause sedation but not extrapyramidal side effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Clozapine

 

  • Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic that has a lower affinity for D2 receptors compared to 5HT2A receptors.
  • This receptor profile significantly reduces the risk of extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS), such as tremors, rigidity, and dystonia, which are common with many other antipsychotics that strongly block D2 receptors.
  • However, clozapine is associated with sedation due to its antagonism of histamine H1 receptors.
  • While it is effective for treatment-resistant schizophrenia, it requires close monitoring for potential side effects like agranulocytosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pimozide: Pimozide is a typical antipsychotic that has a higher risk of causing extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) due to its strong blockade of D2 receptors in the nigrostriatal pathway.

 

Option C. Fluphenazine: Fluphenazine is a high-potency typical antipsychotic that is well-known for its ability to cause EPS because of strong D2 receptor antagonism. It is less likely to cause sedation but more likely to cause motor side effects.

 

Option D. Haloperidol: Haloperidol is another high-potency typical antipsychotic with a high risk of EPS due to potent D2 receptor blockade. It is less sedating compared to low-potency antipsychotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic that causes sedation but has a low risk of extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) due to its lower affinity for D2 receptors.
  • Typical antipsychotics like pimozide, fluphenazine, and haloperidol have a higher risk of EPS because they strongly block D2 receptors.
  • Clozapine requires close monitoring for agranulocytosis but is particularly useful for patients who cannot tolerate EPS.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is least likely to cause hyperkalemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amphotericin B

 

  • Amphotericin B is an antifungal agent that can cause hypokalemia rather than hyperkalemia.
  • It disrupts fungal cell membranes by binding to ergosterol, and a common side effect is renal tubular dysfunction, leading to the loss of potassium through the kidneys.
  • Therefore, it is least likely to cause hyperkalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Potassium-sparing diuretic: Potassium-sparing diuretics like spironolactone or amiloride can cause hyperkalemia by inhibiting potassium excretion in the kidneys. They are commonly associated with elevated potassium levels, especially when combined with other drugs that affect potassium balance.

 

Option C. Renin-angiotensin system blockers: ACE inhibitors (e.g., lisinopril) and ARBs inhibit the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), reducing aldosterone secretion and potassium excretion, which can lead to hyperkalemia.

 

Option D. Cyclosporine: Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressant that can cause hyperkalemia by reducing aldosterone secretion and impairing potassium excretion in the kidneys. This makes it a common culprit in transplant patients experiencing elevated potassium levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Amphotericin B is associated with hypokalemia, not hyperkalemia, due to its effects on the kidneys.
  • Potassium-sparing diuretics, renin-angiotensin system blockers, and cyclosporine can all cause hyperkalemia by impairing renal potassium excretion.
  • When using medications that affect potassium levels, monitoring serum potassium is crucial, particularly when combining drugs that can increase potassium levels.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department due to progressive weakness in her limbs and an enlarging abdomen. Her parents report that she has become more tired and less active over the past few months. Physical examination reveals hepatomegaly and decreased muscle tone. A skeletal muscle biopsy shows abnormal glycogen accumulation with very long outer branches. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anderson disease

 

  • Anderson disease, also known as glycogen storage disease type IV (GSD IV), is caused by a deficiency in the branching enzyme (amylo-1,4 to 1,6-glucosyltransferase).
  • This enzyme is critical for forming the branched structure of glycogen.
  • In its absence, glycogen accumulates with very long outer branches, leading to a structure that is less soluble and more resistant to breakdown.
  • The accumulation of abnormal glycogen primarily affects the liver and muscle, causing symptoms such as hepatomegaly, progressive muscle weakness, and myopathy.
  • Over time, the buildup of abnormal glycogen can result in liver fibrosis and cirrhosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hers disease: Incorrect. Hers disease (GSD VI) results from a deficiency in liver glycogen phosphorylase, which affects the liver’s ability to break down glycogen. It is associated with mild hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and growth retardation, but it does not involve abnormal glycogen branching with very long outer chains as seen in Anderson disease.

 

Option B. McArdle disease: Incorrect. McArdle disease (GSD V) is due to a deficiency in muscle glycogen phosphorylase, leading to exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, and myoglobinuria after exertion. It does not result in abnormal glycogen with long outer branches and does not typically cause hepatomegaly.

 

Option C. Von Gierke's disease: Incorrect. Von Gierke's disease (GSD I) is caused by a deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase, leading to severe hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hyperlipidemia. The glycogen structure in this condition is normal, but the liver cannot release glucose into the blood, leading to hepatomegaly. It does not present with abnormal branching of glycogen as seen in Anderson disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anderson disease (GSD IV) is caused by a deficiency in the branching enzyme, leading to the accumulation of abnormal glycogen with very long outer branches.
  • This glycogen accumulates in the liver and muscle, causing hepatomegaly, muscle weakness, and myopathy.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents for a routine check-up. The parents mention that they are beginning to encourage their child to use the toilet, but they are unsure if it is the right time. The child has recently shown some interest in using the toilet but has not yet consistently communicated the need to go. At what age is toilet training typically started in a developmentally normal child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 years

 

  • Toilet training is usually started around 2 years of age in a developmentally normal child.
  • At this age, the child may begin to show interest in using the toilet and may have enough physical and cognitive maturity to participate in the process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 12 months: At 12 months, most children are not yet developmentally ready for toilet training. They lack the necessary motor skills and bladder control.

 

Option B. 18 months: While some children may start showing interest in the toilet around 18 months, most are not yet ready for consistent training.

 

Option D. 4 years: By 4 years of age, most children are expected to have mastered toilet training. Starting at this age would be considered delayed for most children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Toilet training generally begins around the age of 2 years, when the child has developed the physical readiness and cognitive skills needed to participate in the process.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the clinic with fever, fatigue, and a recent history of a tick bite. Laboratory results reveal a peripheral blood smear stained with Giemsa, as shown below. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for the patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ehrlichia chaffeensis

 

  • Ehrlichia chaffeensis causes human monocytic ehrlichiosis, a tick-borne disease.
  • On a Giemsa-stained peripheral blood smear, it is characterized by the presence of “morulae,” which are clusters of bacteria observed within monocytes.
  • The presence of these characteristic clusters helps in the diagnosis of ehrlichiosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anaplasma phagocytophilum: Anaplasma phagocytophilum causes human granulocytic anaplasmosis, which involves neutrophils rather than monocytes. Morulae are seen in neutrophils, not monocytes, distinguishing it from Ehrlichia chaffeensis.

 

Option C. Bartonella henselae: Bartonella henselae is the causative agent of cat scratch disease. Although it can be visualized with specialized stains like Warthin-Starry, it does not typically present with morulae in peripheral blood smears.

 

Option D. Coxiella burnetii: Coxiella burnetii, responsible for Q fever, cannot be diagnosed via Giemsa stain of peripheral blood smears, as it is an intracellular pathogen that requires serologic testing or PCR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ehrlichia chaffeensis can be identified by the presence of morulae within monocytes on a Giemsa-stained peripheral smear.
  • Distinguishing between intracellular infections often involves noting which type of white blood cells are affected and recognizing specific intracellular patterns.

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Allis tissue forceps

 

  • Allis tissue forceps have distal blades that are not opposing each other.
  • The tip has teeth in each blade that are opposing.
  • There is a lock in the proximal part.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Babcock's forceps: In Babcock’s forceps, the distal part of the blade is curved with a triangular fenestra, which allows soft tissues to bulge out. The tip is non-traumatic with transverse serrations. It has a lock in the proximal part. It is used to hold tubular structures, such as parts of the bowel, fallopian tube, appendix, ureter, etc.

 

 

Option B. Lane’s tissue holding forceps: They are stout with thick distal blades and oval fenestrae. It has an opposing tooth on the tip and a lock in the proximal part. It is used to hold bulky and tough structures and lymph nodes.

 

Option C. Kocher’s hemostatic forceps: They are identified by the opposing tooth on the tip and serrations in the distal blades. It is used to hold pedicles, tough structures, and cut ends of muscles. It can also hold ribs during rib dissection and be used for blunt dissection or resected bowel.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Babcock’s forceps are non-traumatic and primarily used for holding tubular structures like the bowel or fallopian tubes, making them ideal for atraumatic manipulation in surgeries involving delicate tissues.
  • Allis forceps have toothed jaws and are better suited for holding tougher structures like fascia, while Kocher’s forceps are designed for holding firm structures like pedicles and muscles.

choices.text: Evacuation under ultrasound guidance is preferable
Baseline hemogram, TSH, and chest X-ray are essential
Anti-D immunoglobulin is not required for Rh-negative women
Treatment is typically by suction evacuation

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the management of molar pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-D immunoglobulin is not required for Rh-negative women

 

  • In the management of molar pregnancy, Anti-D immunoglobulin is required for Rh-negative women.
  • Even though a molar pregnancy is abnormal, the presence of trophoblastic tissue still carries the Rh antigen, which can lead to maternal sensitization in Rh-negative women.
  • To prevent this, Anti-D immunoglobulin should be administered after the evacuation of a molar pregnancy if the woman is Rh-negative.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Evacuation under ultrasound guidance is preferable: Correct. Suction evacuation under ultrasound guidance ensures complete removal of the molar tissue and reduces the risk of complications like perforation.

 

Option B. Baseline hemogram, TSH, and chest X-ray are essential: Correct. Baseline investigations, including a hemogram, TSH, and chest X-ray, are important to assess for complications like anemia, hyperthyroidism, and metastatic spread to the lungs, which can occur in cases of molar pregnancy.

 

Option D. Treatment is typically by suction evacuation: Correct. Suction evacuation is the standard treatment for molar pregnancy. It effectively removes the abnormal trophoblastic tissue and allows for histopathological examination to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the management of molar pregnancy, Anti-D immunoglobulin is required for Rh-negative women to prevent Rh sensitization, even in abnormal pregnancies like a molar pregnancy.

choices.text: Packet 1 for 12 months
Packet 2 for 12 months
Packet 1 for 6 months
Packet 2 for 6 months

questions.text: A patient visits the outpatient department with a satellite skin lesion. During examination, one hypopigmented lesion and one thickened nerve are observed. Images of two blister packs are provided below. Which treatment would be most appropriate for this patient according to NLEP Guidelines?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Packet 1 for 6 months.

 

  • The treatment best suited for this patient, would be packet 1 for 6 months.
  • One thickened nerve and one hypopigmented satellite skin lesion in a clinical setting point to paucibacillary (PB leprosy) according to NLEP Guidelines.
  • NLEP guidelines mention a 2 drug MDT for PB leprosy.
  • According to NLEP Guidelines, Paucibacillary leprosy is treated with rifampicin and dapsone, over the course of six months.

 

 

 

 

 

 

FUTURE OF NLEP Guidelines in India

 

 

 

 

MoHFW, GoI wants to implement the above-mentioned changes in Hansen’s disease classification and treatment from 1st April 2025.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • According to NLEP Guidelines, for a patient with Paucibacillary leprosy, characterized by 1-5 skin lesions and / or No nerve thickening or One thickened nerve, the appropriate treatment is with a regimen containing Rifampicin and Dapsone (Packet 1) for a duration of 6 months.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old marathon runner is looking to optimize his nutrition for endurance performance. He regularly consumes bananas as part of his diet and is curious about their nutritional profile. His primary concerns are calories, calcium, and micronutrient intake. Which of the following statements accurately describes the nutritional content of bananas per 100 grams?

 

  1. Iron: 10 mg
  2. Calcium: 10 mg
  3. Beta-carotene: 124 micrograms
  4. Calories: 104 kcal
  5. Vitamin C: 27 mg
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 3 and 4

 

Ripe banana -

 

  1. Calories: Bananas contain 104 kcal, making them an excellent source of quick energy, particularly beneficial for athletes like marathon runners.
  2. Calcium: Each 100 grams of banana provides 10 mg of calcium, contributing to daily calcium intake, though not as a significant source.
  3. Beta-carotene: Bananas provide 124 micrograms of beta-carotene, a precursor to vitamin A, important for vision and immune function.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Iron: Bananas typically contain only a small amount of iron, 0.5 mg per 100 gm.

 

5. Vitamin C: The vitamin C content of bananas is 7 mg per 100 grams.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Banana is a good source of:

  • Vitamins A, B6, C
  • Carbohydrates, Energy
  • Fibre
  • Potassium, Phosphorus

 

  •  Banana is NOT a good source of:
    • Calcium, Iron (Due to presence of phytates)
    • Zinc

 

Additional Information

 

Nutritive value of some fruits & dry fruits (per 100 gm)

questions.text: You are in the operating room and notice the tracing in gray color waveform on this device. What does it indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CO2 pressure in exhaled air

 

  • Function: Capnography measures the concentration of CO2 in exhaled air over time, producing a waveform called a capnogram.
  • Components: Capnography equipment typically comprises a CO2 sensor, which can be placed in the circuit of a mechanically ventilated patient or near the patient's airway for non-intubated individuals (e.g., during procedural sedation). The CO2 concentration is then plotted over time to produce a waveform.
  • Waveform Analysis: The capnogram is typically divided into four phases:
    • Phase I: Baseline, representing inspired gas, which is ideally CO2-free.
    • Phase II: The expiratory upstroke, representing the beginning of expiration with a mix of dead space and alveolar gas.
    • Phase III: Alveolar plateau, where the CO2 concentration stabilizes, reflecting primarily alveolar gas.
    • Phase 0: Inspiratory downstroke, as the patient begins to inhale again.

 

 

  • End-Tidal CO2 (EtCO2): This is the maximum value of CO2 at the end of expiration, and it provides an estimation of the arterial CO2 concentration, although they may not always be identical due to various physiological and pathological factors.

 

Clinical Applications:

 

  • Confirming correct endotracheal tube placement.
  • Monitoring the quality of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR). A sudden rise in EtCO2 can indicate return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC).
  • Evaluating a patient's ventilatory status.
  • Monitoring patients during procedural sedation.
  • Detecting conditions like pulmonary embolism, bronchospasm, and hypoventilation, among others.

 

Limitations:

 

  • Factors like changes in cardiac output, changes in alveolar ventilation, and equipment issues can influence the accuracy of capnography.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CO2 pressure in inhaled air: Airway pressure monitoring involves measuring the pressure within the airways, typically during mechanical ventilation, but it does not produce a CO2 waveform.

 

Option C. O2 pressure in inhaled air: Measuring the pressure of oxygen in inhaled air is not typically displayed as a capnography waveform.

 

Option D. O2 pressure in exhaled air: Measuring the pressure of oxygen in exhaled air is not typically displayed as a capnography waveform.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Capnography is a crucial monitoring tool in the operating room and other clinical settings, used to measure and display the concentration of CO2 in exhaled air over time, helping to assess ventilation, confirm endotracheal tube placement, and monitor the effectiveness of resuscitation

choices.text: Prevention of bacterial dissemination
Stimulation of fibroblast proliferation
Activation of complement and autoantibody production
Inhibition of T cell-mediated immunity

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with fever, fatigue, and joint pain. She is diagnosed with a systemic autoimmune disease, and laboratory tests show positive anti-double-stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA) and anti-Smith (anti-Sm) antibodies. She is started on immunosuppressive therapy, and her symptoms improve. Studies suggest that neutrophils in this condition form extracellular networks of chromatin and antimicrobial proteins that contribute to the propagation of autoimmune responses. Which of the following is the most likely role of these extracellular networks in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Activation of complement and autoantibody production

 

  • Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are webs of chromatin released by neutrophils to trap and kill pathogens, but in autoimmune diseases like SLE, they can abnormally expose nuclear antigens, leading to autoantibody production and activation of the complement system.
  • This process contributes to the pathogenesis of SLE.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prevention of bacterial dissemination: Incorrect. While NETs help trap and kill pathogens in normal immune responses, their role in this context is related to autoimmune activation, not bacterial containment.

 

Option B. Stimulation of fibroblast proliferation: Incorrect. Fibroblast proliferation is more related to tissue repair and fibrosis, not a direct effect of NETs in autoimmune conditions like SLE.

 

Option D. Inhibition of T cell-mediated immunity: Incorrect. NETs do not inhibit T cell responses; rather, they promote the activation of the immune system, including complement and autoantibody production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) contribute to the propagation of autoimmune responses by promoting complement activation and autoantibody production.

questions.text: A 11-year-old boy presents with symptoms of chronic anemia, weakness, and poor growth, with a low weight-to-height ratio. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of orotic acid in the urine. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Uridine

 

  • The presentation is consistent with orotic aciduria, a disorder caused by a deficiency in uridine monophosphate (UMP) synthase, which is an enzyme involved in the de novo pyrimidine synthesis pathway.
  • This deficiency results in the accumulation of orotic acid due to an inability to convert it into UMP.
  • The elevated orotic acid can lead to megaloblastic anemia, growth retardation, and weakness.
  • Uridine supplementation is the treatment of choice because it bypasses the enzymatic defect in UMP synthase.
  • Supplementing with uridine provides a source of pyrimidine that can be converted into UMP, which then supports normal pyrimidine synthesis and metabolism.
  • This helps to reduce the accumulation of orotic acid and corrects the associated symptoms like anemia and growth retardation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoxanthine: Incorrect. Hypoxanthine is a precursor in the purine synthesis pathway, not the pyrimidine synthesis pathway. It has no role in correcting UMP synthase deficiency or reducing orotic aciduria. It would not address the patient's symptoms.

 

Option C. Cytidine: Incorrect. While cytidine is a pyrimidine nucleoside, it is not the treatment of choice for orotic aciduria. Uridine directly bypasses the UMP synthase deficiency and helps reduce orotic acid accumulation more effectively.

 

Option D. Guanine: Incorrect. Guanine is a purine base and is not involved in the pyrimidine synthesis pathway. It does not address the underlying UMP synthase deficiency or the symptoms associated with orotic aciduria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Orotic aciduria results from a deficiency in UMP synthase, leading to elevated orotic acid levels, megaloblastic anemia, and growth retardation.
  • The most effective treatment is uridine supplementation, which bypasses the enzyme defect, allowing the body to produce UMP and normalize pyrimidine levels.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with progressive vision loss in the left eye. Examination findings shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Staphyloma

 

  • Staphyloma is characterized by the outward bulging of the uveal tissue through a weakened area of the cornea or sclera, resulting in a bluish, opaque appearance of the affected area.
  • It often arises due to trauma, infection, or inflammatory disease that leads to the loss of structural integrity in the eye's wall, leading to the prolapse of underlying tissue.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Keratoconus: Involves progressive thinning and conical protrusion of the cornea without uveal prolapse. The typical presentation is a cone-shaped corneal deformation, and it usually does not involve a bluish discoloration as seen in staphyloma.
 

Option B. Keratomalacia: Associated with severe vitamin A deficiency, leading to corneal ulceration and softening. While it can cause significant corneal damage, it does not present with uveal tissue prolapse or the marked protrusion seen in staphyloma.
 

Option D. Granular dystrophy: This condition is characterized by small, discrete, white opacities in the corneal stroma. It does not cause corneal thinning, bulging, or exposure of the uveal tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Staphyloma involves the thinning of the corneal or scleral layers of the eye, with a characteristic protrusion involving the uveal tissue, which gives it a bluish hue.
  • This condition is usually secondary to injury, infection, or inflammatory processes that compromise the eye's structural integrity, leading to potential vision loss if untreated.

 

Types of Staphylomas -

 

 

 

Note:

 

The most common cause for anterior staphyloma is sloughing corneal ulcer.

 

The most common cause for posterior staphyloma is degenerative high axial myopia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of painful genital ulcers that have been present for several days. Which of the following pathogens is most likely causing these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Haemophilus ducreyi

 

  • Haemophilus ducreyi is the causative organism of chancroid, which typically presents with painful genital ulcers and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy.
  • The ulcers caused by chancroid are characteristically soft, have an irregular margin, and are often associated with pain—making it distinct from other sexually transmitted infections that present with genital ulcers.
  • This condition is also accompanied by painful unilateral lymphadenopathy that may progress to suppurative inguinal buboes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treponema pallidum: This is the causative organism of syphilis. Primary syphilis presents with a painless, firm, and well-demarcated chancre. Unlike chancroid, syphilis does not cause painful ulcers.

 

Option B. Chlamydia trachomatis: Specifically, the L1-L3 serovars of Chlamydia trachomatis cause lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), which can present with a painless genital ulcer followed by painful lymphadenopathy (buboes). The ulcer itself is not painful.

 

Option D. Herpes simplex: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection can also cause painful genital ulcers. However, HSV ulcers typically present as multiple vesicles that rupture to form shallow ulcers, usually accompanied by systemic symptoms such as fever and malaise. The ulcers in HSV are not usually as irregular and deep as those seen in chancroid.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman presents to the clinic with fever, rash, and conjunctivitis. She recently travelled to a tropical region known for mosquito-borne illnesses. The life cycle of infective agent is shown in the diagram. Which of the following congenital abnormalities is a major concern if the infection is transmitted transplacentally?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microcephaly

 

  • Zika Virus is the agent shown in the lifecycle diagram, involving transmission between non-human primates and humans via Aedes spp. mosquitoes.
  • It has an enzootic cycle in primates and an urban cycle in humans.
  • When a pregnant woman contracts the Zika virus, the infection can be transmitted transplacentally, potentially leading to microcephaly in the fetus.
  • Microcephaly is characterized by an abnormally small head, resulting from impaired brain development, and may cause significant neurological deficits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anencephaly: This congenital abnormality involves the absence of major portions of the brain and skull but is not associated with Zika virus infection.

 

Option C. Spina Bifida: This neural tube defect involves incomplete closure of the spine and is related to folic acid deficiency during pregnancy, not Zika virus infection.

 

Option D. Hydrocephalus: This condition is characterized by an accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid in the brain but is not the primary concern in Zika infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Zika Virus, transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes, can cause microcephaly when transmitted to the fetus during pregnancy.
  • Pregnant women should take precautions to avoid mosquito exposure in endemic areas to prevent this serious congenital complication.

questions.text: A 40-year-old farmer presents with gastroenteritis characterized by severe abdominal pain and diarrhea. Stool culture reveals a Gram-negative bacillus that does not ferment lactose, produces a streak of hydrogen sulphide (H₂S), and is oxidase negative. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Salmonella enterica

 

  • Based on the patient's presentation and stool culture findings, the most likely causative agent is Salmonella enterica.
  • This organism is a Gram-negative bacillus that is known to cause gastroenteritis, often associated with poultry or animal exposure.
  • It does not ferment lactose, produces H₂S, and is oxidase negative—characteristics that match Salmonella.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Campylobacter jejuni: This Gram-negative bacillus grows in a microaerophilic environment and prefers 42°C, but it is oxidase positive and comma-shaped, which does not match the characteristics provided.

 

Option C. Vibrio cholerae: Vibrio cholerae is a Gram-negative, comma-shaped, oxidase-positive organism that grows in alkaline media, primarily causing watery diarrhea (cholera), not typically bloody diarrhea.
