Option D. Shigella flexneri: Shigella is a Gram-negative bacillus that causes bloody diarrhea but is a non-lactose fermenter and does not produce H₂S, unlike Salmonella. Therefore, it does not match the complete description given.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the following organisms with their appropriate transport media:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-4, B-3, C-1, D-2

  • Streptococcus: The appropriate transport medium is Pike’s Medium (A-4). This medium is used for Streptococci to keep the sample viable until further testing.
  • Neisseria: Amies Medium or Stuart's Medium is used to transport Neisseria (B-3), especially because these organisms are highly susceptible to changes in temperature and must be kept viable for accurate culture.
  • Vibrio cholerae: VR Medium (Venkatraman-Ramakrishnan) and Cary Blair Medium are used to transport Vibrio cholerae (C-1). These media maintain the viability of Vibrio species, which are sensitive to environmental changes.
  • Shigella: Buffered glycerol saline or Cary Blair Medium are used to transport Shigella and Salmonella (D-2). These bacteria need to be kept in conditions that prevent overgrowth of other bacteria.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of chronic renal insufficiency is admitted to the hospital with severe bacterial pneumonia. He is started on a carbapenem due to suspected multidrug-resistant organisms. Which of the following carbapenems carries the highest risk of seizures, particularly in patients with renal impairment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Imipenem

 

  • Imipenem is a carbapenem that is associated with a higher risk of seizures, especially in patients with renal insufficiency or central nervous system (CNS) disorders.
  • The risk of seizures with imipenem is thought to be due to its ability to cross the blood-brain barrier and interact with GABA receptors in the CNS.
  • This effect can be particularly pronounced in patients with impaired renal function, where drug accumulation can increase CNS exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Meropenem: Meropenem has a lower risk of seizures compared to imipenem, making it a preferred option in patients with a history of seizures or CNS disorders.

 

Option C. Ertapenem: Ertapenem is less likely to cause seizures compared to imipenem and is generally well-tolerated, though it is less broad-spectrum in activity.

 

Option D. Doripenem: Doripenem has a lower seizure risk compared to imipenem, with a safety profile similar to meropenem in terms of CNS effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Imipenem is associated with the highest risk of seizures among the carbapenems, particularly in patients with renal impairment or CNS disorders.
  • Meropenem and doripenem are preferred alternatives when there is concern about seizure risk.
  • Adjusting the dose in renal impairment is crucial when using imipenem to minimize the risk of CNS toxicity.

choices.text: Granulation tissue is still present
Wound strength is 80% of normal tissue

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman undergoes cesarean section to deliver a term infant, and the lower abdominal incision is sutured. The sutures are removed 1 week later. Which of the following statements best describes the wound site at the time of suture removal?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Granulation tissue is still present

 

  • At 1 week, wound healing is incomplete, and granulation tissue is still present.
  • More collagen is synthesized in the following weeks.
  • Wound strength peaks at about 80% by 3 months.
  • Type IV collagen is found in basement membranes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Collagen degradation exceeds synthesis: Incorrect. Collagen synthesis predominates at this stage, not degradation.

 

Option C. Wound strength is 80% of normal tissue: Incorrect. At 1 week, wound strength is only around 10%, not 80%.

 

Option D. Type IV collagen predominates: Incorrect. Type III collagen, not type IV, predominates in the early stages of wound healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Granulation tissue is present in the proliferative phase of wound healing, typically seen around 1 week after injury.

 

Summary Timeline of Wound Healing:

choices.text: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

questions.text: Which of the following components is not part of the Revised Trauma Score (RTS)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pulse rate

 

  • Pulse rate is not part of the Revised Trauma Score.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS): The GCS assesses eye-opening, verbal, and motor responses and is part of the RTS.

 

Option B. Respiratory rate: This is another component of the RTS and contributes to the assessment of respiratory function.

 

Option C. Systolic blood pressure: This is included in the RTS to assess circulatory status.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a clinical tool used to assess trauma severity, incorporating the Glasgow Coma Scale, respiratory rate, and systolic blood pressure.

questions.text: In which of the following organs is the type of epithelium shown in the image found?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urinary bladder

 

  • The image shows transitional epithelium (also known as urothelium), which is characteristic of the urinary bladder.
  • Transitional epithelium is a specialized type of epithelium that can stretch and expand to accommodate fluctuating volumes of fluid, such as urine in the bladder.
  • This epithelium has a distinctive appearance with multiple layers of cells.
  • When the bladder is relaxed, the surface cells (dome-shaped or umbrella cells) appear rounded.
  • When the bladder is distended with urine, these surface cells flatten out, allowing the bladder to stretch without tearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenum: Incorrect. The duodenum is lined with simple columnar epithelium with numerous goblet cells for absorption and secretion. It does not exhibit the multilayered and dome-shaped surface cells seen in transitional epithelium.

 

Option B. Esophagus: Incorrect. The esophagus is lined with stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium to protect against mechanical stress during swallowing. It does not have the distensible properties of transitional epithelium.

 

Option C. Vagina: Incorrect. The vagina is lined with stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium, which is designed to withstand friction and mechanical stress during intercourse and childbirth. It does not have the elastic properties seen in transitional epithelium, which are essential for the urinary bladder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Transitional epithelium (urothelium) is found in the urinary bladder and other parts of the urinary tract, such as the ureters and the proximal urethra.
  • It is uniquely adapted to stretch and expand in response to varying volumes of urine, allowing the bladder to fill and empty without damage.

choices.text: Naloxone should be used for long-term maintenance to prevent opioid relapse.
Naltrexone can decrease opioid cravings during the maintenance phase of recovery.
Naltrexone is effective in reducing alcohol cravings and preventing opioid relapse.
Naloxone is effective without the need for repeated dosing in acute opioid toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the use of naloxone and naltrexone in opioid management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Naltrexone is effective in reducing alcohol cravings and preventing opioid relapse.

 

  • Naltrexone is used as a maintenance therapy after acute opioid detoxification to prevent relapse by blocking the euphoric effects of opioids.
  • It is also effective in reducing cravings in chronic alcohol use disorder, making it useful in the management of alcohol dependence.
  • However, it does not decrease cravings for opioids themselves, which differentiates it from medications like buprenorphine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Naloxone should be used for long-term maintenance to prevent opioid relapse: This is incorrect. Naloxone is used for acute opioid overdose due to its rapid onset of action. It has a short half-life, requiring repeated administration in cases of severe toxicity, making it unsuitable for long-term maintenance.

 

Option B. Naltrexone can decrease opioid cravings during the maintenance phase of recovery: This is incorrect. While naltrexone prevents the euphoric effects of opioids and thus helps to prevent relapse, it does not decrease the cravings for opioids.

 

Option D. Naloxone is effective without the need for repeated dosing in acute opioid toxicity: This is incorrect. Due to its short duration of action, naloxone often requires repeated dosing or a continuous infusion in cases of severe opioid toxicity, as the effects of the opioid may outlast those of naloxone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Naloxone is used for acute opioid overdose but has a short half-life, necessitating frequent dosing.
  • Naltrexone is used for maintenance therapy to prevent opioid relapse and reduce cravings for alcohol, but it does not decrease opioid cravings.
  • Naltrexone blocks the euphoric effects of opioids, helping to prevent relapse in patients undergoing recovery.

questions.text: A 11-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after falling from a height. He complains of severe pain on the right side of his chest. Examination reveals tenderness at the midaxillary line, and imaging shows a rib fracture with accumulation of blood in the pleural space, causing a hemothorax and atelectasis. Which of the following is the most likely source of bleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intercostal vessels

 

  • The intercostal vessels run along the inferior margin of each rib in the intercostal spaces, making them vulnerable to injury when there is a rib fracture.
  • In this case, the rib fracture at the midaxillary line likely caused damage to the intercostal arteries and veins, leading to bleeding into the pleural space and subsequent hemothorax.
  • The intercostal arteries branch off the thoracic aorta, while the intercostal veins drain into the azygos system.
  • Injury to these vessels can cause significant bleeding, particularly in the context of trauma such as a fall, leading to complications like hemothorax and atelectasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left common carotid artery: Incorrect. The left common carotid artery supplies the head and neck, originating from the aortic arch. It is not located near the ribs or pleural space and would not be affected by a rib fracture. Injury to this vessel would lead to neck or upper chest bleeding, not a hemothorax from rib trauma.

 

Option C. Subclavian artery: Incorrect. The subclavian artery is located above the first rib and beneath the clavicle. It supplies blood to the upper limbs and parts of the chest. While it can be injured in severe trauma, it is not directly related to rib fractures at the midaxillary line. Damage to the subclavian artery would cause bleeding in the upper chest or shoulder region rather than a hemothorax from a rib injury.

 

Option D. Thoracic duct: Incorrect. The thoracic duct is the main lymphatic channel in the body, draining lymph into the left subclavian vein. Injury to the thoracic duct can result in a chylothorax (accumulation of lymph in the pleural space), but it would not cause a hemothorax. It is also less likely to be injured from a rib fracture compared to the intercostal vessels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intercostal vessels are a common source of bleeding in cases of rib fractures, as they run along the inferior margin of each rib and can be damaged by fractures.
  • Injury to these vessels can lead to a hemothorax, which is the accumulation of blood in the pleural space, potentially causing atelectasis and difficulty breathing.

questions.text: A laboratory technician is working with a pathogen that poses a high risk of aerosol transmission and has the potential to cause serious or lethal disease. The laboratory must use a containment level with stringent safety measures, including a pass-through autoclave with bioseal in the laboratory room. Which Biosafety Level (BSL) is most appropriate for handling this pathogen?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) BSL-3

 

  • BSL-3 is designated for working with pathogens that are either indigenous or exotic and that pose a potential for aerosol transmission.
  • These agents can cause serious or potentially lethal diseases.
  • Safety measures at BSL-3 include high containment procedures, including a pass-through autoclave with a bioseal required in the laboratory room.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BSL-1: This level is used for working with agents that pose minimal potential hazards to personnel and the environment, typically involving no containment. Pathogens at this level are unlikely to cause disease.

 

Option B. BSL-2: BSL-2 is for agents that pose moderate hazards to personnel and the environment, such as Influenza or HIV. Containment at this level includes moderate-risk procedures but does not include the high containment measures necessary for aerosol-transmitted pathogens.

 

Option D. BSL-4: BSL-4 is the highest biosafety level, used for dangerous and exotic agents that pose a high risk of aerosol-transmitted infections and life-threatening diseases (e.g., Ebola virus). This level also requires stringent safety measures, including a pass-through autoclave, but it is meant for higher-risk pathogens than those handled at BSL-3.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Amniocentesis for evaluation of fetal chromosomal anomalies
Maternal serum for evaluation of fetal chromosomal abnormalities

questions.text: Which of the following best describes Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing (NIPT)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Maternal serum for evaluation of fetal chromosomal abnormalities

 

  • Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing (NIPT) involves analyzing cell-free fetal DNA (cffDNA) that circulates in the maternal bloodstream.
  • This test can detect common chromosomal abnormalities such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21), trisomy 18, trisomy 13, and sex chromosome anomalies.
  • NIPT is performed by collecting a maternal blood sample and is non-invasive, posing no risk to the fetus.
  • It can be offered as early as 10 weeks of pregnancy and is a highly accurate screening tool for detecting fetal chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amniocentesis for evaluation of fetal chromosomal anomalies: Incorrect. Amniocentesis is an invasive procedure that involves extracting amniotic fluid for genetic testing. While it provides definitive information, it carries a risk of complications such as miscarriage and is not part of NIPT.

 

Option B. Pre-conceptional gene testing of an ova: Incorrect. Pre-conceptional gene testing refers to preimplantation genetic testing during in-vitro fertilization (IVF) cycles, not to prenatal testing like NIPT, which evaluates the fetus during pregnancy.

 

Option D. Testing of maternal tissue: Incorrect. NIPT tests the cell-free fetal DNA (cffDNA) in the maternal bloodstream, not maternal tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing (NIPT) is a highly accurate screening test for detecting fetal chromosomal abnormalities.
  • It analyzes cell-free fetal DNA from maternal blood and can screen for conditions like trisomy 21 (Down syndrome), trisomy 18, and trisomy 13.
  • It is a non-invasive method that poses no risk to the fetus and can be done as early as 10 weeks gestation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with a history of angle-closure glaucoma presents with symptoms consistent with major depressive disorder. The clinician is considering starting the patient on antidepressant therapy. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amitriptyline

 

  • Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) that has strong anticholinergic properties.
  • TCAs have a high affinity for muscarinic receptors, leading to their blockade, which can impair the outflow of aqueous humor and increase intraocular pressure.
  • This effect can worsen angle-closure glaucoma, a condition characterized by reduced drainage of aqueous humor due to the angle between the cornea and iris being too narrow or blocked.
  • Therefore, amitriptyline should be avoided in patients with angle-closure glaucoma to prevent exacerbation of the condition.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Sertraline: Sertraline is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that does not have significant anticholinergic activity and is generally safe for patients with glaucoma.

 

Option C. Mirtazapine: Mirtazapine is a tetracyclic antidepressant that has minimal anticholinergic effects, making it a safer choice for patients with angle-closure glaucoma.

 

Option D. Fluvoxamine: Fluvoxamine is another SSRI with negligible anticholinergic activity and can be used safely in patients with glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Amitriptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA), should be avoided in patients with angle-closure glaucoma due to its anticholinergic effects, which can further impede the outflow of aqueous humor and raise intraocular pressure.
  • When treating depression in patients with glaucoma, medications with minimal or no anticholinergic effects, such as SSRIs, are generally preferred to avoid worsening of glaucoma.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman in her second trimester presents with sudden onset of severe left flank pain and visible blood in her urine. She has no prior history of renal disease or urinary tract infections. On examination, she appears uncomfortable but afebrile, and her vital signs are stable. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Renal calculus

 

  • Renal calculi (kidney stones) are more likely during pregnancy due to physiological changes such as increased urinary calcium excretion and urinary stasis.
  • The classic presentation includes sudden-onset flank pain, hematuria, and possibly nausea or vomiting.
  • The absence of fever and normal vital signs rule out conditions like pyelonephritis.
  • The second trimester is a common time for kidney stones to present due to the dilation of the renal pelvis and ureters, which predisposes to stone formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute pyelonephritis: Incorrect. Acute pyelonephritis typically presents with fever, chills, and flank pain along with signs of systemic infection, which are absent in this case. Hematuria is less common in pyelonephritis than in renal calculi.

 

Option B. Glomerulonephritis: Incorrect. Glomerulonephritis typically presents with hematuria but is usually associated with hypertension, proteinuria, and edema, none of which are present in this patient.

 

Option D. Acute cystitis: Incorrect. Acute cystitis usually presents with dysuria, urgency, and frequency, without the severe flank pain described here. Hematuria can be present, but the key distinguishing feature is the flank pain, which suggests involvement of the upper urinary tract (e.g., renal calculi).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a pregnant woman presenting with sudden-onset flank pain and hematuria, renal calculi (kidney stones) should be highly suspected, particularly in the second trimester.
  • Hematuria, along with severe flank pain, is a classic presentation of nephrolithiasis, and pregnancy predisposes to stone formation due to urinary stasis and increased calcium excretion.

questions.text: The procedure shown in the image is done for which of the below mentioned condition.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rectal cancer

 

  • Image shows trans-anal local excision that is typically reserved for early-stage rectal cancers, specifically for tumors that are:
    • Small (<3 cm)
    • Well- to moderately-differentiated
    • Within 8 cm of the anal verge
    • Limited to <30% of the rectal circumference
    • Without lymph node involvement

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Benign enlargement of the prostate: TURP is done for enlargement of the prostate

 

Option C. Meningomyelocele: Meningomyelocele requires open surgical repair

 

Option D. Uterine prolapse: Uterine prolapse repair is done vaginally/transabdominally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Transanal local excision is suitable for small, early-stage rectal tumors (T1, N0) that are well-differentiated and confined without lymph node involvement.
  • More advanced tumors (T2 with lymph node involvement) require more extensive surgical approaches, such as transabdominal resection.

questions.text: The Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion outlines key strategies to improve global health. Which of the following is not the action areas identified in the Ottawa Charter?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ensure equitable healthcare financing

 

  • Ensure equitable healthcare financing is not explicitly listed as one of the five action areas in the Ottawa Charter, although equitable financing is an important aspect of overall health system reforms.
  • The Ottawa Charter focuses more on community action, skills development, supportive environments, and policy reorientation.
  • The Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion was established in 1986 and outlines five key action areas for health promotion:
  1. Strengthen community action: Empowering communities to take control over their health by supporting community-based initiatives.
  2. Develop personal skills: Providing individuals with information and education to make healthy choices and improve their well-being.
  3. Create supportive environments: Promoting physical and social environments that support health.
  4. Build healthy public policy: Integrating health considerations into public policies across sectors.
  5. Reorient health services: Shifting healthcare focus from treatment to prevention and promoting equity in health.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion emphasizes community involvement, individual empowerment, and supportive environments as key strategies to enhance global health.
  • While equitable healthcare financing is important, it is not one of the core action areas specifically defined by the charter.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old child with autoimmune disease is about to begin long-term steroid therapy. The pediatrician reviews the child's vaccination status and makes recommendations regarding which vaccines should be administered or avoided. Which of the following statements is/are accurate in this situation?

 

  1. Continue routine vaccinations as per the immunization schedule.
  2. Administer the pneumococcal vaccine according to the standard schedule.
  3. Only inactivated vaccines should be used during steroid therapy.
  4. Oral polio vaccine (OPV) should not be given to the child’s siblings.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2, 3, 4

 

  • In the case of a child with an autoimmune disease who will receive steroid therapy, certain vaccination guidelines need to be followed:

 

2. Pneumococcal Vaccine: This vaccine is particularly important for immunocompromised children to protect against pneumococcal infections, which they are at a higher risk for.

 

3. Inactivated Vaccines: During steroid therapy, live vaccines (like MMR and OPV) are generally avoided due to the weakened immune response. Only killed or inactivated vaccines should be used.

 

4. Avoiding OPV for Siblings: OPV is a live attenuated vaccine, which poses a risk of vaccine-derived transmission to immunocompromised individuals. Therefore, it is recommended to avoid OPV for siblings when a child in the household is immunocompromised.

 

Other Option:

 

  1. Continue routine vaccinations as per the immunization schedule: Routine vaccination schedules cannot be continued without modification for children on long-term steroids because live vaccines are contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Children on long-term steroid therapy should receive inactivated vaccines only, such as the pneumococcal vaccine.
  • Live vaccines like the oral polio vaccine (OPV) should be avoided in both the patient and close contacts (e.g., siblings) due to the risk of transmission.

choices.text: It is a screening test for cervical cancer.
It is a diagnostic test for cervical cancer.
It is a screening tool for all types of genital tract cancers.
It is a diagnostic test for vaginal infections.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of abnormal vaginal discharge. During the visit, the physician recommends a Pap smear as part of her routine care. The patient is curious and asks about the purpose of this test. Which of the following is the most accurate description of the Pap smear?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a screening test for cervical cancer.

 

  • A Pap smear (Papanicolaou test) is used primarily as a screening tool to detect precancerous changes and early-stage cervical cancer.
  • It involves collecting cells from the cervix to check for abnormal cells that could indicate cervical dysplasia or cervical cancer.
  • While it can sometimes incidentally detect infections like Trichomoniasis, its primary purpose is cervical cancer screening.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is a diagnostic test for cervical cancer: Incorrect. A Pap smear is a screening test, not a diagnostic one. If abnormalities are found, further diagnostic procedures like colposcopy and biopsy are needed to confirm cervical cancer.

 

Option C. It is a screening tool for all types of genital tract cancers: Incorrect. The Pap smear specifically screens for cervical cancer and precancerous changes in the cervix, not other types of genital tract cancers like ovarian or endometrial cancer.

 

Option D. It is a diagnostic test for vaginal infections: Incorrect. While the Pap smear may incidentally detect vaginal infections like Trichomoniasis, it is not designed as a diagnostic test for infections. It is primarily used for cervical cancer screening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A Pap smear is primarily a screening test for cervical cancer.
  • It helps detect precancerous changes and early-stage cervical cancer. It is not a diagnostic test for infections or for other gynecological cancers.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of alcohol use disorder wants to stop drinking. She has had multiple failed attempts in the past. What is the most appropriate pharmacological treatment to prevent relapse?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Naltrexone

 

  • Naltrexone is an opioid receptor antagonist that helps reduce cravings and the rewarding effects of alcohol, making it a suitable choice for preventing relapse in individuals with alcohol use disorder.
  • It is particularly helpful for patients who continue to experience cravings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Disulfiram: Disulfiram works by inhibiting aldehyde dehydrogenase, leading to unpleasant symptoms (e.g., nausea, flushing) when alcohol is consumed. It is best suited for patients who are highly motivated to abstain because it relies on the patient’s willingness to adhere to the treatment and avoid alcohol. It is less effective in preventing relapse in those with a history of multiple failed attempts.

 

Option C. Acamprosate: Acamprosate helps with maintaining abstinence by modulating glutamatergic neurotransmission, reducing post-acute withdrawal symptoms like anxiety and insomnia. It is most effective when started after achieving abstinence but is less effective than naltrexone in reducing cravings during the initial period of recovery.

 

Option D. Topiramate: Topiramate is sometimes used off-label for alcohol use disorder to reduce cravings, but it is not as well established as naltrexone or acamprosate. It is not considered a first-line pharmacological option for preventing relapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Naltrexone is the preferred pharmacological treatment for preventing relapse in alcohol use disorder due to its ability to reduce cravings and the rewarding effects of alcohol.

choices.text: Continue lithium at the current dose
Switch to valproic acid before surgery

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with bipolar disorder is stable on lithium. He is scheduled for surgery next week. What is the most appropriate recommendation regarding his lithium?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Discontinue lithium 48-72 hours before surgery

 

  • Lithium should typically be stopped 48-72 hours before major surgery due to the risk of lithium toxicity.
  • During surgery, there is a potential for fluctuations in fluid and electrolyte levels, which can affect lithium clearance and increase the risk of toxicity.
  • Additionally, anesthesia can impair renal function, further complicating lithium management.
  • Discontinuing lithium temporarily and restarting it after surgery is usually the safest approach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue lithium at the current dose: Continuing lithium during surgery is not advisable due to the risk of renal impairment, dehydration, and potential lithium toxicity caused by altered kidney function and fluid shifts during and after the procedure.

 

Option B. Increase lithium dose preoperatively: Increasing the lithium dose would increase the risk of toxicity, especially given the renal and fluid challenges during surgery. This approach is not recommended.

 

Option D. Switch to valproic acid before surgery: Switching to another mood stabilizer like valproic acid is not typically necessary just for the surgical period. Temporary discontinuation of lithium is a simpler and safer option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lithium should be temporarily discontinued 48-72 hours before major surgery to reduce the risk of toxicity due to changes in renal function and fluid balance.

questions.text: A 10-day-old newborn is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to persistent jaundice, lethargy, and poor feeding & hypoglycemia. The parents report that the infant's stool has become pale, and they have noticed dark yellow urine stains on his diaper. Opthalmology reference was done which revealed the formation of cataract. The infant was started on antibiotics for presumed sepsis 2 days ago but has not improved. Laboratory tests reveal conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, elevated liver enzymes, and a positive reducing substances test in the urine. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency

 

  • The presentation of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with a history of sepsis in a newborn, along with pale stools, jaundice, and dark urine, suggests a diagnosis of galactosemia.
  • The most common type is due to a deficiency in the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase.
  • This enzyme deficiency prevents the proper metabolism of galactose, leading to toxic accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in various organs.
    • Galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by an inability to convert galactose into glucose. Symptoms often present early in life when infants are exposed to milk, which contains lactose (comprising glucose and galactose).
    • Without this enzyme, the infant accumulates galactose-1-phosphate, leading to liver damage, kidney dysfunction, and brain involvement.
    • These infants are also at high risk for E. coli sepsis.
    • Treatment involves the immediate elimination of lactose from the diet and the use of soy-based or lactose-free formulas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Galactosidase deficiency: It is not a specific term. The enzyme deficiency in classical galactosemia is galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase, not a general galactosidase.

 

Option B. Urea cycle defect: This would more likely present with hyperammonemia, vomiting, and neurologic symptoms (such as seizures), but not conjugated hyperbilirubinemia or jaundice.

 

Option D. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency: This (von Gierke disease) presents with hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hepatomegaly, but it is not associated with jaundice or sepsis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Galactosemia, caused by a deficiency in galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase, presents in neonates with jaundice, hepatomegaly, and sepsis, particularly with E. coli.
  • Early recognition and dietary management with lactose-free formula are essential to prevent long-term complications and improve outcomes.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of hypertension presents to the clinic with complaints of erectile dysfunction. His physician prescribes a medication that works by enhancing the effect of nitric oxide through the inhibition of a specific enzyme, leading to increased levels of cyclic GMP and smooth muscle relaxation in the corpus cavernosum. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitor

 

  • Sildenafil is a phosphodiesterase 5 (PDE5) inhibitor.
  • It works by inhibiting the enzyme PDE5, which normally breaks down cyclic GMP (cGMP) in the corpus cavernosum.
  • By inhibiting PDE5, sildenafil allows for increased levels of cGMP, leading to smooth muscle relaxation and enhanced blood flow to the penis, thereby facilitating erection during sexual stimulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aromatase inhibitor: This class of drugs inhibits the enzyme aromatase, which converts androgens into estrogens. Aromatase inhibitors are typically used in the treatment of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer in postmenopausal women.

 

Option B. 5 alpha reductase inhibitor: These drugs, such as finasteride and dutasteride, inhibit 5 alpha reductase, an enzyme that converts testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT). They are used in the management of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and androgenic alopecia.

 

Option D. Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator (SERM): SERMs (e.g., tamoxifen) are compounds that act as estrogen receptor agonists or antagonists depending on the tissue. They are primarily used in breast cancer treatment and osteoporosis prevention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sildenafil is a PDE5 inhibitor that enhances cGMP levels, leading to smooth muscle relaxation and improved blood flow in the treatment of erectile dysfunction.
  • Aromatase inhibitors and 5 alpha reductase inhibitors are used in hormone-related conditions, but they do not directly affect cGMP levels.
  • SERMs act on estrogen receptors and are unrelated to the mechanism of action of sildenafil.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman at 8 weeks gestation presents to the clinic seeking medical termination of pregnancy. You review the options for first-trimester abortion with her. Which of the following methods is not used for medical termination in the first trimester?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate

 

  • Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate is used for second-trimester abortions, typically beyond 12-14 weeks gestation.
  • It is not used for first-trimester medical terminations.
  • Ethacridine lactate works by inducing labor, but because the amniotic cavity is too small to allow for this method in the first trimester, it is not appropriate for early pregnancy termination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dilatation and curettage: Incorrect. Dilatation and curettage (D&C) is a surgical method that can be used for pregnancy termination in the first trimester, particularly before 13 weeks.

 

Option C. Mifepristone + misoprostol: Incorrect. This combination is the standard regimen for medical termination of pregnancy in the first trimester. Mifepristone blocks progesterone receptors, and misoprostol induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy.

 

Option D. Manual vacuum aspiration: Incorrect. Manual vacuum aspiration (MVA) is a safe and effective method for first-trimester abortion, commonly performed up to 12-14 weeks gestation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate is not used for first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy.
  • It is primarily used for second-trimester abortions, while first-trimester options include mifepristone + misoprostol, manual vacuum aspiration, and dilatation and curettage.

questions.text: In cases of ethylene glycol poisoning and its characteristic metabolic acidosis, treatment involves correction of the acidosis, removal of any remaining ethylene glycol, and administration of an inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH), the enzyme that oxidizes ethylene glycol to the organic acids that cause the acidosis. Ethanol frequently is the inhibitor given to treat ethylene glycol poisoning. Results of experiments using ADH with and without ethanol are shown to the right. Based on these data, what type of inhibition is caused by the ethanol?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Competitive

 

  • A competitive inhibitor increases the apparent Km for a given substrate.
  • This means that, in the presence of a competitive inhibitor, more substrate is needed to achieve one half Vmax.
  • The effect of a competitive inhibitor is reversed by increasing substrate concentration ([S]).
  • At a sufficiently high [S], the reaction velocity reaches the Vmax observed in the absence of inhibitor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Feedback: Feedback inhibition occurs when the product of a reaction inhibits the enzyme that helped produce it, usually as part of a regulatory pathway. Ethanol is not a product of the reaction catalyzed by alcohol dehydrogenase; instead, it acts as a competitive inhibitor. Therefore, feedback inhibition does not apply in this context.

 

Option C. Irreversible: Irreversible inhibition occurs when an inhibitor forms a permanent bond with the enzyme, completely inactivating it. In this case, the data shows that increasing the substrate concentration increases the reaction rate, indicating that the inhibition by ethanol can be overcome. This suggests that the inhibition is reversible, not irreversible.

 

Option D. Noncompetitive: Noncompetitive inhibition occurs when an inhibitor binds to an enzyme at a site other than the active site, reducing the enzyme's activity regardless of substrate concentration. If ethanol were acting as a noncompetitive inhibitor, the reaction rate would not increase significantly with increasing substrate concentration, as the inhibition would not depend on substrate competition. However, in the data provided, increasing the substrate concentration increases the reaction rate, which is inconsistent with noncompetitive inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ethanol acts as a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase, competing with the substrate (such as ethylene glycol) for the enzyme's active site.
  • Competitive inhibition can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration, which increases the rate of the enzymatic reaction.

choices.text: Defective bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubule
Impaired hydrogen ion secretion in the distal tubule
Increased chloride reabsorption in the collecting duct
Increased ammonium excretion in the proximal tubule

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with a known history of Sjogren’s syndrome presents with fatigue, muscle weakness and recurrent loin pain; lab finding shows: S. Na – 136 mEq/L, S. K  - 3.2 mEq/L, S. HCO3 16 mEq/L, S. Cl – 112 mEq/L. Her X-ray of the abdomen is shown below. Which of the following is the likely mechanism responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Impaired hydrogen ion secretion in the distal tubule

 

  • This patient presents with Renal Tubular Acidosis (RTA) Type 1, which is also known as distal RTA. Type 1 RTA is characterized by an inability of the distal tubules to secrete hydrogen ions effectively, resulting in a persistently high urine pH (>5.5) and a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis. 
  • Sjogren’s syndrome is an autoimmune condition frequently associated with distal RTA due to autoimmune destruction of the intercalated cells in the distal tubules, leading to impaired hydrogen ion excretion. 
  • This causes systemic acidosis, hypokalemia, and an increased risk of calcium phosphate kidney stones due to the alkaline urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Defective bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubule: This describes RTA Type 2 (proximal RTA), which results from impaired bicarbonate reabsorption. However, in RTA Type 2, urine pH can become low (<5.5) after significant bicarbonate loss, unlike the persistently alkaline urine seen in distal RTA.

 

Option C. Increased chloride reabsorption in the collecting duct: This mechanism is not involved in RTA. Increased chloride reabsorption may be relevant to conditions like hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis but does not explain the underlying issue in this case.

 

Option D. Increased ammonium excretion in the proximal tubule: Ammonium excretion is not impaired in distal RTA, and increased ammonium excretion would actually help compensate for acidosis, which is not the mechanism at play here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • RTA Type 1 (distal RTA) is commonly associated with Sjogren’s syndrome and involves impaired hydrogen ion secretion in the distal tubules, leading to metabolic acidosis with a persistently high urine pH, hypokalemia, and an increased risk of kidney stones.

questions.text: A research team is investigating whether obesity is a significant risk factor for breast cancer. They want to determine if there is an association between categorical variables: obesity (present or absent) and breast cancer occurrence (present or absent). Which of the following statistical tests would be the most appropriate for this analysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chi-square test

 

  • The Chi-square test is the most appropriate test in this scenario.
  • This test is used to examine the association between two categorical variables—in this case, obesity (present/absent) and breast cancer occurrence (present/absent).
  • It helps determine whether there is a statistically significant relationship between obesity and breast cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Student’s paired 't' test: This test compares the means of two related groups (e.g., pre-treatment and post-treatment in the same group of patients). It is not applicable when comparing categorical variables like obesity and breast cancer.

 

Option B. Student’s unpaired 't' test: This test compares the means of two independent groups (e.g., mean weight in obese vs. non-obese individuals). It is used for continuous data and not for categorical variables.

 

Option D. Wilcoxon’s signed rank test: This is a non-parametric test used to compare two related groups when the data is not normally distributed. It is more suited for ordinal or continuous data, not categorical comparisons like obesity and breast cancer occurrence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Chi-square test is used to assess associations between two categorical variables, making it ideal for determining whether obesity is a significant risk factor for breast cancer.

questions.text: Based on the mechanism shown in the below image, which of the following drugs most likely corresponds to Drug C?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clopidogrel

 

  • Clopidogrel is an ADP receptor inhibitor that specifically targets the P2Y12 receptor on platelets.
  • By blocking this receptor, clopidogrel prevents ADP-mediated platelet activation, thereby reducing platelet aggregation.
  • This mechanism is especially useful in the prevention of arterial thrombosis in conditions like acute coronary syndrome and after stent placement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin: Aspirin inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX), reducing the synthesis of thromboxane A2 (TxA2), which is involved in platelet aggregation. It does not act directly on the ADP receptors like P2Y12.

 

Option C. Abciximab: Abciximab is a GPIIb/IIIa receptor antagonist, which blocks the final common pathway of platelet aggregation by preventing fibrinogen binding to the GPIIb/IIIa receptors on the platelet surface.

 

Option D. All of these: This option is incorrect because only Clopidogrel specifically acts on the P2Y12 ADP receptor. Aspirin and Abciximab act on different pathways involved in platelet aggregation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mechanism of action of anti-platelet drugs

questions.text: Match the following countries with their achievements:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-c, 2-b, 3-a

 

  • Russia (1-c): It was the first country to socialize medicine completely, creating a state-run health system that provided healthcare services to all citizens.
  • Germany (2-b): It was the first country to introduce compulsory sickness insurance under Otto von Bismarck's leadership, laying the foundation for modern social health insurance systems.
  • India (3-a): It was the first country to establish a fingerprinting bureau, which helped in advancing the field of forensic science.

 

Educational Objective:

 

First Country Honours

 

  • First country to socialize medicine completely: Russia
  • First country to introduce compulsory sickness insurance: Germany
  • First country to start family planning programme: India
  • First country to start blindness control programme: India
  • First country to establish finger printing bureau: India (Calcutta, 1897)

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with a BMI 34 kg/m² presents for evaluation of her liver function tests, which reveal elevated levels of AST and ALT. She has no history of alcohol use, viral hepatitis, or significant liver disease. After lifestyle modifications and weight loss attempts, her healthcare provider discusses pharmacotherapy options for her condition. Which of the following medications is FDA-approved for the management of her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Resmetirom

 

  • Resmetirom is an FDA-approved medication specifically indicated for the treatment of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) in adults with liver fibrosis.
  •  It works as a selective thyroid hormone receptor beta agonist, which helps improve liver fat content and liver function tests.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metformin: Metformin is primarily used for managing type 2 diabetes and is not specifically FDA-approved for the treatment of NAFLD or NASH, though it may be used off-label.

 

Option B. Pioglitazone: While pioglitazone has shown benefits in improving liver histology in patients with NASH, it is not specifically FDA-approved for this indication and is primarily used for diabetes management.

 

Option C. Semaglutide: Semaglutide is used for the management of type 2 diabetes and obesity, but it does not have FDA approval specifically for the treatment of NAFLD or NASH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Resmetirom is the only FDA-approved medication specifically targeting the treatment of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease and non-alcoholic steatohepatitis, making it an essential option for managing liver function abnormalities associated with obesity and metabolic syndrome.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with a history of heartburn, regurgitation, and a sensation of fullness in her chest, especially after eating large meals. She reports that the symptoms worsen when lying down. A barium swallow study is performed, revealing part of the stomach protruding through the esophageal hiatus into the chest cavity. Which of the following structures is most likely herniated through the diaphragm in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gastric fundus

 

  • In a hiatal hernia, the gastric fundus or other parts of the stomach protrude through the esophageal hiatus of the diaphragm into the thoracic cavity.
  • The esophageal hiatus is an opening in the diaphragm that normally allows the esophagus to pass through to connect with the stomach.
  • Hiatal hernias are classified into sliding hiatal hernias and paraesophageal hiatal hernias:
    • Sliding hiatal hernia is the most common type and occurs when the gastroesophageal junction and part of the stomach move above the diaphragm.
    • Paraesophageal hiatal hernia occurs when a portion of the gastric fundus herniates through the hiatus alongside the esophagus, while the gastroesophageal junction remains below the diaphragm.
  • Patients with hiatal hernias often experience gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) symptoms, such as heartburn and regurgitation, due to the displacement of the stomach into the thoracic cavity, altering the pressure gradient.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duodenum: Incorrect. The duodenum is fixed retro-peritoneally and is not typically involved in hiatal hernias. Its location and attachments make it unlikely to herniate through the esophageal hiatus.

 

Option C. Transverse colon: Incorrect. The transverse colon is more likely to be involved in hernias through the diaphragmatic crura or foramen of Morgagni, but not through the esophageal hiatus. Hiatal hernias involve structures adjacent to the gastroesophageal junction.

 

Option D. Pancreatic tail: Incorrect. The pancreatic tail is positioned deep within the abdomen and would not be involved in a hiatal hernia through the esophageal hiatus. It is fixed near the splenic hilum and is not near the diaphragm’s esophageal opening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A hiatal hernia involves the herniation of the gastric fundus or other parts of the stomach through the esophageal hiatus of the diaphragm into the thoracic cavity.
  • It is commonly associated with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) due to altered pressure dynamics at the gastroesophageal junction.

questions.text: A child is unable to carry out movements of pronation-supination since childhood due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radio-ulnar synostosis

 

  • Radio-ulnar synostosis is a congenital condition where the radius and ulna are fused together at the elbow.

  • This fusion prevents the normal rotation of the radius around the ulna, leading to a complete inability to perform pronation and supination.

  • Children with this condition typically have a characteristic limitation in forearm movements from an early age.

  • They may have a functional limitation but may adapt to certain activities.

  • This condition is lifelong and profoundly affects the ability to perform these rotational movements, making it the most fitting option for the scenario described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial Dislocation: Radial dislocation, particularly of the radial head, occurs when the head of the radius is displaced from its normal position. This condition can be due to trauma, such as a fall, or can occur in specific scenarios like "nursemaid's elbow," where the radius slips out of its normal position due to sudden pulling. A child with a radial dislocation may have pain, limited movement, and visible deformity. However, this is usually an acute condition and, if treated, can allow for full recovery of movement. While it can limit these movements temporarily, it is generally not a lifelong issue unless there are recurrent dislocations or complications.

 

Option B. Congenital Radial Head Dysplasia: Congenital radial head dysplasia refers to a developmental abnormality of the radial head that can lead to dysfunction in the forearm. This condition often results in a poorly formed radial head, which can cause instability or misalignment at the elbow joint. Children may experience restricted motion or discomfort, particularly in pronation and supination. However, this is less common than some other causes. It can affect function but may not completely prevent pronation and supination; the degree of limitation can vary widely.

 

Option D. Elbow Dislocation: Elbow dislocation occurs when the bones of the elbow joint are displaced. Commonly results from trauma, such as falls or sports injuries, leading to the displacement of the ulna and/or radius from the humerus. Acute pain, swelling, and visible deformity are typical. Movement is usually severely restricted immediately after dislocation. After reduction, most children can regain normal function, including pronation and supination, with appropriate rehabilitation. Chronic issues arise only if there are complications or recurrent dislocations, but it generally does not cause lifelong inability to perform these movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Radio-ulnar synostosis directly leads to an inability to perform pronation and supination due to the fusion of the radius and ulna.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a painless thyroid nodule and diarrhea. A thyroid biopsy reveals the presence of amyloid deposits within the tumor. He is also found to have a strong family history of thyroid cancer and so his genetic testing was done which reveals a RET proto-oncogene mutation. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Paraneoplastic production of serotonin

 

  • This patient has medullary thyroid cancer (MTC), which is derived from parafollicular C cells that produce calcitonin. Other hormones like Serotonin, VIP and ACTH can also be secreted by tumor cells.
  • These hormones can cause secretory diarrhea by increasing intestinal secretion.
  • The RET proto-oncogene mutation further supports the diagnosis of familial medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperthyroidism: Incorrect. The patient’s presentation lacks the classic symptoms of hyperthyroidism (such as weight loss, tremors, and palpitations). MTC does not typically result in hyperthyroidism.

 

Option B. Histamine secretion by the tumor: Incorrect. Histamine does not cause diarrhea

 

Option D. Increased parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) secretion: Incorrect. PTHrP causes hypercalcemia of malignancy, often associated with squamous cell carcinomas or renal cell carcinoma, not medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In medullary thyroid carcinoma, excessive calcitonin production by tumor cells can cause diarrhea as a paraneoplastic symptom. This cancer is associated with RET proto-oncogene mutations and amyloid deposits in the thyroid.
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma → Calcitonin producing tumor
  • Calcitonin and other hormones like serotonin, VIP and ACTH increases intestinal fluid secretion → Secretory diarrhea
  • Amyloid deposits = calcitonin aggregates
  • RET mutation → Diagnostic hallmark of familial MTC (MEN 2 syndromes)
  • MEN 2A: Medullary thyroid carcinoma + pheochromocytoma + parathyroid hyperplasia
  • MEN 2B: Medullary thyroid carcinoma + pheochromocytoma + mucosal neuromas + marfanoid habitus

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with sudden onset of right-sided facial paralysis, inability to close her right eye, and loss of taste sensation on the anterior two-thirds of her tongue. Physical examination reveals drooping of the right side of her face and absence of the corneal reflex on the right. Imaging reveals a lesion at the base of the skull affecting the cranial nerve as it exits through its respective foramen. Which foramen is most likely involved in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Internal acoustic meatus

 

  • This patient's presentation of sudden right-sided facial paralysis, inability to close the eye, and loss of taste sensation on the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is consistent with a lesion of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII).
  • The facial nerve is responsible for motor control of the muscles of facial expression, taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and innervation to the lacrimal and salivary glands.
  • It also contributes to the afferent limb of the corneal reflex.
  • The facial nerve (CN VII) exits the skull through the internal acoustic meatus, along with the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII).
  • A lesion at this location, such as from a tumor or other compressive pathology, can result in facial paralysis and loss of taste sensation as seen in this patient.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foramen ovale: The foramen ovale transmits the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V3). This nerve is responsible for sensory innervation to the lower face and motor innervation to the muscles of mastication. A lesion affecting the foramen ovale would present with loss of sensation in the mandibular distribution and difficulty with mastication, not facial paralysis or loss of taste sensation.

 

Option C. Jugular foramen: The jugular foramen transmits cranial nerves IX (glossopharyngeal), X (vagus), and XI (accessory). A lesion here would cause deficits such as dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), hoarseness (vocal cord paralysis), and shoulder weakness (due to accessory nerve involvement), but not facial paralysis or loss of taste on the anterior tongue.

 

Option D. Hypoglossal canal: The hypoglossal canal transmits the hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII), which controls the muscles of the tongue. Lesions here cause weakness or atrophy of the tongue muscles, typically with deviation of the tongue to the side of the lesion when protruded, but this would not cause facial paralysis or taste disturbances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) exits the skull via the internal acoustic meatus and is responsible for motor innervation to the muscles of facial expression, taste sensation on the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and innervation to the lacrimal and salivary glands.
  • A lesion affecting the internal acoustic meatus can result in facial paralysis and loss of taste sensation on the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with a painless nodule in her neck that she noticed two months ago. She has no history of radiation exposure and her family history is unremarkable. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the thyroid nodule reveals cells as are given in the image. There are also psammoma bodies present. Ultrasound shows a solitary, well-defined nodule in the right thyroid lobe. Which of the following genetic mutations is most commonly associated with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) BRAF mutation

 

  • This patient has features consistent with papillary thyroid cancer, the most common type of thyroid malignancy.
  • Orphan Annie-eye nuclei and psammoma bodies are characteristic histologic findings.
  • BRAF mutations are commonly associated with papillary thyroid cancer and are often predictive of a more aggressive course.
  • BRAF mutations can be seen with Malignant melanoma, Hairy cell leukemia, LCH, Papillary thyroid cancer 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RET proto-oncogene mutation: Incorrect. RET mutations are associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma, not papillary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Option C. TP53 mutation: Incorrect. TP53 mutations are typically associated with anaplastic thyroid carcinoma, a much more aggressive and rare type of thyroid cancer.

 

Option D. RAS mutation: Incorrect. RAS mutations can be associated with follicular thyroid carcinoma and follicular variant of papillary thyroid carcinoma, but they are less common in classic papillary thyroid carcinoma than BRAF mutations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is often associated with BRAF mutations and is characterized by papillary structures, orphan Annie eye nuclei, and psammoma bodies.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the clinic with her husband, both expressing concern after having unprotected intercourse 4 days ago. They do not want to conceive at this time, and she is very anxious. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prescribe ulipristal acetate

 

  • Ulipristal acetate is an effective form of emergency contraception that can be used up to 5 days (120 hours) after unprotected intercourse.
  • It is a selective progesterone receptor modulator that works by inhibiting or delaying ovulation.
  • Given that this patient had unprotected intercourse 4 days ago, ulipristal acetate is the best option for preventing pregnancy.
  • Ulipristal is more effective than levonorgestrel when used in the later part of the 5-day window, and it does not lose efficacy as rapidly over time.
  • It is appropriate for patients who seek emergency contraception more than 72 hours after intercourse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Order an ultrasound: Incorrect. An ultrasound is not necessary for emergency contraception. Ultrasound is used to confirm an established pregnancy or evaluate other gynecologic concerns, but it is not relevant at this early stage.

 

Option C. Give the Yuzpe regimen: Incorrect. The Yuzpe regimen involves high-dose combined oral contraceptives (estrogen and progestin) as emergency contraception. While effective, it is less effective and associated with more side effects (nausea and vomiting) compared to ulipristal acetate.

 

Option D. Prescribe levonorgestrel : Incorrect. Levonorgestrel is another form of emergency contraception but is most effective when used within 72 hours of intercourse. Given that the patient is 4 days (96 hours) post-intercourse, ulipristal acetate is the preferred option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ulipristal acetate is the most effective form of emergency contraception when used within 5 days (120 hours) after unprotected intercourse.
  • It is particularly useful when more than 72 hours have passed, as its efficacy remains higher than that of levonorgestrel.
  • Emergency contraception works by inhibiting or delaying ovulation and should be given as soon as possible after unprotected intercourse.

choices.text: Both succenturiate lobe and velamentous insertion

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is undergoing a routine ultrasound at 28 weeks gestation. The ultrasound reveals the placental structure as shown in the image . What is the most likely diagnosis based on these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both succenturiate lobe and velamentous insertion

 

  • The image and clinical description suggest the presence of both a succenturiate lobe and velamentous cord insertion.
  • A succenturiate lobe is an accessory placental lobe that is separate from the main placental body and connected by blood vessels.
  • Velamentous insertion occurs when the umbilical cord inserts into the fetal membranes rather than the placental mass.
  • This configuration makes the vessels vulnerable to injury, especially during labor.
  • This combination can lead to complications like vasa previa or hemorrhage if the vessels are damaged during labor or delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Succenturiate lobe: Incorrect. While the succenturiate lobe is present in this case, this option does not explain the velamentous cord insertion, which is a significant finding in the ultrasound and the image.

 

Option B. Normal placenta: Incorrect. A normal placenta has a single placental mass with the umbilical cord inserting directly into it. The findings described are abnormal, specifically involving an accessory lobe and velamentous insertion.

 

Option D. Marginal insertion of the cord: Incorrect. In marginal insertion, the umbilical cord inserts at the edge of the placental mass, but still directly into the placenta, not into the membranes as seen with velamentous insertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Both succenturiate lobe and velamentous insertion are placental abnormalities.
  • The succenturiate lobe is an accessory placental lobe, and velamentous cord insertion is when the umbilical cord inserts into the membranes, making the vessels vulnerable to injury.
  • These conditions increase the risk of complications such as vasa previa and fetal hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man recently returned from a rural area in northeastern India, where he experienced several episodes of fever, chills, and fatigue over the past week. He presents to a district hospital, and laboratory testing confirms a diagnosis of Plasmodium falciparum malaria. What is the most appropriate first-line treatment for his condition in this region?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Artemether plus lumefantrine

 

The Drug of choice treatment for Plasmodium falciparum infection in North Eastern states is artemether + lumefantrine

 

ARTEMISINS - ARTESUNATE AND ARTEMETHER

 

  • Fastest acting anti-malarial
  • Effective against MDR parasites
  • Short acting
  • C/I in 1st trimester

 

 Artemisinin Combination Therapy [ACT]

 

  • Artemisin + Long acting drug
  • DOC for chloroquine resistant malaria Combinations
  • Artemether + Lumefantrine: DOC in North Eastern States
  • Artesunate + Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine: DOC for rest of India
  • The dose of artesunate is 200 mg OD for 3 days whereas sulfadoxine (1500 mg) and pyrimethamine (75 mg) should be taken on day 1 only)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For P. falciparum malaria in regions with known drug resistance, artemether plus lumefantrine is the most effective first-line treatment, ensuring rapid and sustained clearance of the malaria parasite.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the emergency department with pain and swelling in his left ear, which developed over the past 2 days. He mentions a history of repeated trauma to the ear from his job as a boxing coach. On physical examination, the left ear shows erythema, tenderness, and a swollen, indurated pinna with no visible discharge. The tympanic membrane appears normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Perichondritis

 

  • The clinical presentation of painful, erythematous swelling over the auricle in a patient with a history of trauma suggests perichondritis.
  • Perichondritis is an infection of the perichondrium, typically occurring after trauma, lacerations, or surgical incisions to the ear.
  • The most common causative organism is Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
  • If left untreated, it can lead to cartilage necrosis, resulting in a "cauliflower ear" deformity, which is often seen in individuals exposed to repeated ear trauma, such as boxers and wrestlers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otitis externa: Otitis externa typically presents with pain, itching, and discharge from the ear canal, but it does not involve the pinna itself.

 

Option C. Chondrodermatitis helicis: Chondrodermatitis helicis presents as a painful nodule on the helix or antihelix, caused by chronic pressure and not by infection.

 

Option D. Auricular cellulitis: Auricular cellulitis can present with erythema and swelling, but it involves the soft tissue of the auricle and not specifically the cartilage, and it is not associated with a history of trauma as prominently.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Perichondritis of the ear commonly results from trauma or surgery and can progress to cartilage necrosis if untreated.
  • It typically requires antibiotic therapy targeting Pseudomonas aeruginosa and may present as a painful, erythematous swelling of the auricle without tympanic membrane involvement.

choices.text: Administer a booster dose of Hepatitis B vaccine
Administer Hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) with a full vaccination course
Repeat the full course of Hepatitis B vaccine

questions.text: A 28-year-old healthcare worker accidentally sustains a needle stick injury while handling a patient who is known to be Hepatitis B positive. The healthcare worker’s serology report shows HBsAg negative and Anti-HBs level of 105 mIU/ml. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) No treatment required

 

  • The healthcare worker’s serology indicates that he is HBsAg negative, which confirms the absence of active infection, and the Anti-HBs level of 105 mIU/ml demonstrates sufficient immunity to Hepatitis B from prior vaccination.
  • An Anti-HBs titre greater than 10 mIU/ml is considered protective.
  • Therefore, no further treatment is necessary as the healthcare worker already has adequate antibody titres.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer a booster dose of Hepatitis B vaccine: A booster is not needed when an individual has a protective antibody titre (>10 mIU/ml). In this case, a level of 105 mIU/ml is well above the protective threshold.

 

Option B. Administer Hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) with a full vaccination course: HBIG is recommended for post-exposure prophylaxis in individuals who are not vaccinated or do not have sufficient antibody titres. Given that the healthcare worker has adequate immunity, this option is not necessary.

 

Option C. Repeat the full course of Hepatitis B vaccine: Repeating the full vaccination course is indicated for individuals who are non-responders to the initial vaccination series or who have very low or absent antibody titres. Since the healthcare worker has a sufficient level of antibodies, repeating the course is not warranted.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In individuals with prior Hepatitis B vaccination, an Anti-HBs titre greater than 10 mIU/ml indicates sufficient immunity.
  • If this threshold is met after a needle stick exposure, no additional prophylactic treatment is required.

questions.text:
Which of the following organisms also share the characteristic known as “viable but not cultivable”?

 

1. M. leprae

2. M. tuberculosis

3. Treponema pallidum

4. Salmonella

5. Staphylococcus
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 and 3

 

1. Mycobacterium leprae is the causative agent of leprosy and is termed "viable but not cultivable" because it cannot be grown in artificial media in laboratory conditions. Instead, it is grown in armadillo models or mouse footpads. This limitation makes diagnosis largely dependent on clinical findings and histopathology.

 

3. Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis, is another example of a microorganism that cannot be cultured in artificial laboratory media. Its unique requirements for growth in human tissues make it extremely difficult to cultivate outside a living host, thereby classifying it as viable but non-cultivable in traditional lab settings.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: Unlike M. leprae, M. tuberculosis can be cultured in standard laboratory media, such as Lowenstein-Jensen medium, and therefore does not fit the description of viable but not cultivable.

 

4. Salmonella: Salmonella species can be easily cultivated in standard nutrient media and are commonly grown for laboratory identification purposes.

 

5. Staphylococcus: Staphylococcus species, including Staphylococcus aureus, can be readily grown in nutrient-rich media like blood agar, making them cultivable in standard laboratory conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Certain pathogens such as Mycobacterium leprae and Treponema pallidum are described as "viable but not cultivable" because they cannot be grown in artificial laboratory media.
  • Diagnostic approaches for such pathogens rely heavily on alternative techniques like animal models, clinical symptoms, or serology.

choices.text: These symptoms are associated with hyperdopaminergic activity in the mesocortical pathway
Second-generation antipsychotics are significantly more effective than first-generation antipsychotics in treating these symptoms
These symptoms are typically more resistant to treatment than positive symptoms and are associated with poorer functional outcomes
Cognitive remediation therapy has shown consistent, large effect sizes in improving these symptoms across multiple studies

questions.text: A 28-year-old man suffering from schizophrenia presents with social withdrawal, lack of motivation, and reduced emotional expression. His family reports that these symptoms have been present for the past year. Which of the following statements about his condition is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) These symptoms are typically more resistant to treatment than positive symptoms and are associated with poorer functional outcomes

 

  • The symptoms described (social withdrawal, lack of motivation, reduced emotional expression) are negative symptoms of schizophrenia.
  • Negative symptoms are generally more difficult to treat with antipsychotic medication compared to positive symptoms like hallucinations and delusions.
  • They are associated with greater functional impairment and poorer overall prognosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. These symptoms are associated with hyperdopaminergic activity in the mesocortical pathway (False): Negative symptoms are associated with hypodopaminergic activity (reduced dopamine activity) in the mesocortical pathway, not hyperdopaminergic activity. Hyperdopaminergic activity (in the mesolimbic pathway) is more associated with positive symptoms.

 

Option B. Second-generation antipsychotics are significantly more effective than first-generation antipsychotics in treating these symptoms (False): While second-generation antipsychotics may have some benefits over first-generation antipsychotics in terms of side effects and possibly better tolerability, their effectiveness in treating negative symptoms is only modestly better, and overall, the impact on negative symptoms remains limited.

 

Option D. Cognitive remediation therapy has shown consistent, large effect sizes in improving these symptoms across multiple studies (False): Cognitive remediation therapy is more effective for improving cognitive deficits rather than negative symptoms. The impact on negative symptoms tends to be smaller and less consistent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Negative Symptoms of Schizophrenia:

 

  • Negative symptoms are defined by the absence of normal behaviors.
  • They are sometimes also called deficit symptoms.
  • They are:
    • Avolition - Loss of drive for goal-directed activities
    • Apathy - Lack of concern
    • Anhedonia -Lack of pleasure in previously pleasurable activities
    • Asociality -Lack of social interaction
    • Affective flattening (Or emotional blunting) - Lack of emotional response
    • Alogia - Decreased verbal communication
  • They are more resistant to treatment than positive symptoms and are linked to greater functional impairment.

choices.text: Hypersensitivity of the peripheral chemoreceptors to hypoxia
Increased respiratory drive due to metabolic acidosis
Delayed detection of changes in blood CO2 by central chemoreceptors
Increased lung stiffness leading to decreased tidal volume

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of chronic heart failure is brought to the emergency department due to increasing shortness of breath, fatigue, and periods of rapid breathing followed by pauses in breathing during sleep. His wife reports that she has noticed these episodes of irregular breathing during the night, where his breathing pattern alternates between deep, rapid breaths and periods of no breathing. Physical examination reveals an elevated jugular venous pressure and bilateral crackles on lung auscultation. Which of the following best explains the underlying mechanism of this patient's breathing pattern?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Delayed detection of changes in blood CO2 by central chemoreceptors

 

  • Cheyne-Stokes breathing is a cyclic pattern of breathing characterized by periods of hyperventilation followed by apnea.
  • This abnormal respiratory pattern occurs due to a delayed response of the central chemoreceptors in detecting changes in arterial carbon dioxide (CO2) levels.
  • In patients with chronic heart failure, as seen in this case, reduced cardiac output leads to poor blood circulation, which in turn delays the transport of CO2 to the brain’s respiratory centers.
  • The central chemoreceptors, responsible for detecting CO2 levels, respond with a delay, causing alternating phases of hyperventilation (when CO2 is elevated) and apnea (when CO2 levels drop too low due to overcompensation).
  • The respiratory centers overshoot in response to these delayed signals, resulting in the waxing and waning pattern of breathing characteristic of Cheyne-Stokes respiration.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypersensitivity of the peripheral chemoreceptors to hypoxia: Incorrect. While peripheral chemoreceptors respond to hypoxia, they are not primarily responsible for the cyclic breathing pattern seen in Cheyne-Stokes breathing. The main issue in Cheyne-Stokes is the delayed feedback in response to changes in blood CO2 levels, which does not involve hypoxia sensitivity as the primary cause.

 

Option B. Increased respiratory drive due to metabolic acidosis: Incorrect. Metabolic acidosis increases the respiratory drive and can lead to rapid, deep breathing (Kussmaul breathing), not the cyclical waxing and waning pattern characteristic of Cheyne-Stokes breathing.

 

Option D. Increased lung stiffness leading to decreased tidal volume: Incorrect. Increased lung stiffness (as seen in conditions like pulmonary fibrosis) may result in shallow, rapid breathing, but it does not lead to the cyclical breathing pattern of hyperventilation followed by apnea that defines Cheyne-Stokes breathing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cheyne-Stokes breathing is characterized by alternating periods of hyperventilation and apnea.
  • It occurs due to delayed detection of blood CO2 changes by central chemoreceptors, often seen in patients with heart failure or neurological damage.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with advanced HIV (CD4 count of 50 cells/µL) presents with a 3-week history of cough, night sweats, weight loss, and fatigue. Sputum testing is positive for acid-fast bacilli, leading to a diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis (TB). After starting anti-TB therapy, he begins antiretroviral therapy (ART) 2 weeks later. Six weeks after initiating ART, he returns with worsening cough, fever, and new lymphadenopathy. His repeat chest X-ray shows worsening infiltrates. What is the most likely cause of his clinical deterioration?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome

 

  • Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS) occurs when there is a paradoxical worsening of an underlying infection after the initiation of antiretroviral therapy in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with advanced HIV. 
  • As the immune system starts to recover due to ART, it may mount an exaggerated inflammatory response to existing infections, leading to clinical deterioration, such as worsening pulmonary symptoms and new lymphadenopathy in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drug-resistant tuberculosis: While drug-resistant TB is a possibility, the timing of the deterioration shortly after starting ART is more characteristic of IRIS than of resistance, especially since he was started on appropriate anti-TB therapy.

 

Option B. HIV-associated pneumonia: While patients with low CD4 counts are at risk for various opportunistic infections, the specific symptoms and timeline in this case are more suggestive of IRIS.

 

Option D. Antiretroviral drug toxicity: Although ART can have side effects, the clinical picture and timing of the deterioration are not typical of direct toxicity, especially since the worsening symptoms correlate with the initiation of ART rather than with adverse effects.

 

Educational Objective:
