  • Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS) is a common phenomenon in patients with advanced HIV starting antiretroviral therapy, leading to a paradoxical worsening of previously existing infections due to an inflammatory response as the immune system begins to recover.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with recurrent skin rashes, primarily affecting his face and hands. He notes that the rashes often worsen after spending time outdoors, particularly when he visits rural areas. Physical examination reveals erythematous patches with scaling. The dermatologist suspects a contact dermatitis triggered by an airborne allergen. Which of the following is the most common cause of airborne dermatitis in this region?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Parthenium

 

  • Parthenium hysterophorus, a common weed, is the most frequent cause of airborne contact dermatitis in India.
  • The plant releases airborne allergens, particularly in rural areas, leading to dermatitis, especially on exposed areas like the face and hands .
  • Parthenium is a known allergen that can trigger allergic contact dermatitis, often affecting individuals who spend significant time outdoors in regions where the weed is prevalent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chrysophyllum: Chrysophyllum is not a common cause of airborne contact dermatitis and is not widely associated with allergic skin reactions in this context.

 

Option B. Calotropis: Calotropis is known for its latex, which can cause contact dermatitis through direct contact, but it is not a major cause of airborne dermatitis.

 

Option D. Rothrangal: This is not a recognized cause of airborne dermatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Parthenium hysterophorus is the most common cause of airborne contact dermatitis in India, particularly in rural areas.
  • It causes skin reactions through airborne allergens, affecting individuals who are exposed to it outdoors.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with acute kidney injury (AKI) 7 days after undergoing coronary angiography (CAG). Laboratory tests reveal elevated creatinine levels and hypocomplementemia. A renal biopsy is done and shown below. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atheroembolic disease 

 

  • The most likely underlying cause of this patient's AKI is atheroembolic disease (cholesterol embolization). 
  • This condition commonly occurs after procedures such as coronary angiography that involve the manipulation of atherosclerotic plaques. Cholesterol crystals can dislodge from atherosclerotic plaques in the aorta and renal arteries, causing small vessel occlusions and ischemic damage. The classic triad includes:
  • AKI
  • Hypocomplementemia (due to complement activation by emboli)
  • Signs of cholesterol embolization, which may include livedo reticularis and blue toe syndrome.
  • Renal biopsy typically shows cholesterol clefts within small renal arteries.
  • The delayed onset of AKI (days after the procedure) and the presence of hypocomplementemia further support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contrast-induced AKI: Contrast nephropathy typically occurs within 48 hours of contrast administration and resolves over several days. It is usually characterized by a rise in creatinine without hypocomplementemia or embolic phenomena.

 

Option C. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP): TTP is a thrombotic microangiopathy that presents with thrombocytopenia, hemolytic anemia, AKI, fever, and neurologic symptoms. There is no mention of thrombocytopenia or other features of TTP in this patient.

 

Option D. Antiphospholipid syndrome: This syndrome is characterized by thrombosis and recurrent pregnancy loss, along with the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies. While it can cause AKI due to renal vascular thrombosis, the clinical presentation and hypocomplementemia are more consistent with atheroembolic disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Atheroembolic disease is a potential complication after vascular procedures, presenting with delayed AKI, hypocomplementemia, and cholesterol crystal embolization.

choices.text: Accumulation of iron within macrophages
Products of free radical-induced lipid peroxidation
Deposition of misfolded proteins
Glycogen storage in excess

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for a routine physical examination. He reports no significant health issues but mentions mild fatigue. Physical examination is unremarkable. He has a history of well-controlled hypertension. A liver biopsy, performed as part of a research study, shows granular, brownish-yellow intracytoplasmic deposits within hepatocytes. No signs of inflammation or fibrosis are noted. The patient's liver enzymes are within normal limits. Which of the following best describes the nature of the observed deposits in this patient’s liver cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Products of free radical-induced lipid peroxidation

 

  • Lipofuscin (a wear-and-tear pigment) affects tissues such as the liver, heart, and brain.
  • Lipofuscin represents products of lipid peroxidation resulting from oxidative damage over time and is considered a marker of cellular aging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Accumulation of iron within macrophages: Incorrect. Iron (hemosiderin) stains with Prussian blue, unlike lipofuscin.

 

Option C. Deposition of misfolded proteins: Incorrect. Misfolded proteins (e.g., amyloid) stain with Congo red, not typical of these deposits.

 

Option D. Glycogen storage in excess: Incorrect. Glycogen appears clear in special stains (PAS), not brownish-yellow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lipofuscin is an age-related pigment resulting from lipid peroxidation and is harmless.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with a headache and altered sensorium. MRI was performed which revealed multiple rings enhancing lesions. MR spectroscopy showed a prominent lipid-lactate peak. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberculoma

 

  • Foci of infection which conglomerating ring enhancing lesions, common around brainstem.
  • Tuberculoma is central nervous system tuberculosis characterized by intracranial granulomas.
  • On MRI, these can appear as ring-enhancing lesions, particularly around the brainstem.
  • MR spectroscopy reveals a lipid-lactate peak due to necrosis within the lesion, which is a distinguishing feature in comparison to other infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurocysticercosis: Neurocysticercosis is a parasitic infection caused by the larval stage of Taenia solium, presenting with seizures, headaches, or other neurological symptoms. MRI findings often include cystic lesions with or without a scolex (the head of the larva), and ring-enhancing lesions when the cyst is dying. MR spectroscopy may show elevated choline and reduced N-acetyl aspartate (NAA), but a prominent lipid-lactate peak is not typical.

 

Option C. PML (Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy): PML is a demyelinating disease caused by the JC virus, most commonly in immunocompromised patients. MRI shows non-enhancing white matter lesions without mass effect, typically in the parieto-occipital regions. MR spectroscopy in PML typically shows a reduction in NAA, reflecting neuronal loss or damage, without a prominent lipid-lactate peak.

 

Option D. Cryptococcomas: Cryptococcomas are localized granulomatous lesions caused by Cryptococcus, seen in both immunocompetent and immunocompromised individuals. MRI may show multiple ring-enhancing lesions, similar to tuberculoma, but spectroscopy differs, usually without a significant lipid-lactate peak.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient presenting with headaches and altered sensorium, multiple ring-enhancing lesions on MRI, accompanied by a prominent lipid-lactate peak on MR spectroscopy, are indicative of tuberculoma, where the lipid-lactate peak suggests necrosis within the lesions.

choices.text: Reentrant atrial circuits; start anticoagulation therapy
Multiple ectopic foci in the atria; correct underlying hypoxia
Gradual shift of the pacemaker focus within the atria; observe without intervention
Sinoatrial node dysfunction; initiate permanent pacemaker placement

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with a history of COPD presents with palpitations. She denies chest pain, shortness of breath, or palpitations. ECG was taken and shown below. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, and her blood pressure is stable at 100/60 mmHg and her SpO2 is 91% with 4L of nasal O2. Serum electrolytes and thyroid function tests are normal. Considering the patient's ECG findings, which of the following mechanisms most likely explains the condition, and what would be the appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multiple ectopic foci in the atria; correct underlying hypoxia

 

  • The patient’s history of COPD and the ECG findings (likely showing multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT)) suggest a condition often caused by multiple ectopic foci in the atria. 
  • MAT is associated with underlying pulmonary conditions, such as COPD, where hypoxia contributes to the arrhythmia. 
  • The first step in management is to correct the underlying hypoxia to address the arrhythmia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reentrant atrial circuits; start anticoagulation therapy: This describes atrial fibrillation, which usually requires anticoagulation. However, the ECG and history are more consistent with multifocal atrial tachycardia rather than atrial fibrillation.

 

Option C. Gradual shift of the pacemaker focus within the atria; observe without intervention: This describes wandering atrial pacemaker, which is typically benign and does not require intervention. However, the patient's COPD history and the likely multifocal atrial tachycardia require correcting the hypoxia.

 

Option D. Sinoatrial node dysfunction; initiate permanent pacemaker placement: This would apply in cases of sick sinus syndrome, which is not supported by the patient's presentation or ECG findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with a history of COPD presenting with palpitations and ECG findings of multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT), the underlying cause is often hypoxia due to lung disease, and the primary management is to address the hypoxia, typically improving the arrhythmia.

choices.text: Entry wound is bevelled in the outer table of the skull
Abrasion collar is seen in entry wound
Harrison-Gilroy test can detect gunshot residue
Stellate shaped wound is seen in contact shot

questions.text: A forensic expert is describing the distinguishing features of gunshot wounds during an autopsy of a gunshot victim. Each type of gunshot wound has characteristic appearances, depending on the range and the point of entry. Which of the following is not a correct feature of a gunshot wound?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Entry wound is bevelled in the outer table of the skull

 

  • The entry wound of a gunshot in the skull is characterized by beveling in the inner table of the skull, not the outer table.
  • When a bullet penetrates the skull, it creates a clean round hole on the outer table, but as it passes through and exits, it causes beveling on the inner aspect, creating a characteristic internal cone-shaped defect.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Abrasion collar is seen in entry wound: The entry wound of a gunshot typically has an abrasion collar due to the friction between the bullet and the skin upon entry.
 

Option C. Harrison-Gilroy test can detect gunshot residue: The Harrison-Gilroy test is indeed used to detect gunshot residue, indicating a person fired or was close to a firearm when it was discharged.
 

Option D. Stellate shaped wound is seen in contact shot: A stellate (star-shaped) wound is often seen in contact gunshot wounds, particularly over bony areas, due to gases expanding beneath the skin, causing it to tear in a star-like pattern.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • When assessing gunshot wounds, understanding the anatomical features of entry and exit wounds is crucial.
  • Bevelling occurs in the inner table of the skull at the entry wound and in the outer table at the exit point.
  • Recognizing these features helps forensic experts determine the direction of the bullet and understand the circumstances of the shooting.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with lower abdominal pain and spotting. She is confirmed to have an unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy based on ultrasound findings. Which of the following is the most common site of implantation in this ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ampulla

 

  • The ampulla of the fallopian tube is the most common site for ectopic pregnancy, accounting for approximately 70-80% of cases.
  • This region is where fertilization typically occurs, and if there is a delay in the movement of the fertilized egg, it may implant in the ampulla rather than traveling to the uterus.
  • The fallopian tube is not designed to support a growing pregnancy, making ectopic pregnancies life-threatening if not managed promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isthmus: Incorrect. The isthmus is a common site for ectopic pregnancy, but it is less common than the ampulla. Ectopic pregnancies in the isthmus account for about 12% of cases.

 

Option B. Infundibulum: Incorrect. The infundibulum, which is closer to the ovary, is a rarer site for ectopic implantation compared to the ampulla and isthmus.

 

Option C. Interstitial portion: Incorrect. The interstitial portion (the part of the tube that traverses the uterine wall) is the least common site for ectopic pregnancy, accounting for 2-4% of cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ampulla of the fallopian tube is the most common site of implantation in ectopic pregnancies, occurring in about 70-80% of cases.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus is being evaluated for adjustments to her antidiabetic medication regimen. She has been experiencing issues with postprandial blood glucose control. Which of the following antidiabetic drugs does not enhance insulin secretion?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rosiglitazone

 

  • Rosiglitazone is a thiazolidinedione (TZD) that works by increasing insulin sensitivity in peripheral tissues such as muscle and adipose tissue.
  • It acts as an agonist of the PPAR-γ (peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-gamma), which improves the body's response to insulin, thereby reducing blood glucose levels.
  • Unlike other options, rosiglitazone does not directly stimulate insulin secretion from the pancreas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exenatide: Exenatide is a GLP-1 receptor agonist that enhances insulin secretion in response to food intake by mimicking the incretin hormone GLP-1. It stimulates glucose-dependent insulin release from the pancreas.

 

Option B. Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor that works by increasing the levels of endogenous incretin hormones like GLP-1 and GIP, which in turn enhance insulin secretion in a glucose-dependent manner.

 

Option D. Repaglinide: Repaglinide is a meglitinide that directly stimulates insulin release from the pancreatic beta cells by closing ATP-sensitive potassium channels, similar to sulfonylureas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rosiglitazone increases insulin sensitivity without directly stimulating insulin secretion.
  • Exenatide, sitagliptin, and repaglinide enhance insulin release from the pancreas through different mechanisms.
  • Thiazolidinediones (TZDs) like rosiglitazone target insulin resistance, making them unique among many antidiabetic therapies.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with recent episodes of syncope, shortness of breath, and palpitations presents with jugular venous distention, pitting edema, and a narrowly split S2. ECG shows atrial fibrillation with right axis deviation, and echocardiography reveals right ventricular hypertrophy. Which genetic mutation is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) BMPR2 mutation.

 

  • This patient's symptoms of syncope, shortness of breath, palpitations, and physical findings such as jugular venous distention, pitting edema, narrowly split S2, along with right ventricular hypertrophy seen on echocardiography, are suggestive of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). 
  • The ECG findings of atrial fibrillation with right axis deviation further support this diagnosis.
  • BMPR2 (Bone Morphogenetic Protein Receptor Type 2) mutations are associated with heritable pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).
  • Mutations in this gene lead to abnormal vascular remodeling in the pulmonary arteries, causing elevated pulmonary pressures and right ventricular hypertrophy, which can eventually lead to right heart failure, as seen in this patient. BMPR2 mutations are the most common genetic cause of familial PAH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MYH7 mutation: This mutation is associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, a condition characterized by left ventricular hypertrophy and typically does not cause right ventricular hypertrophy or pulmonary hypertension.

 

Option B. LMNA mutation: Mutations in the LMNA gene are associated with various forms of cardiomyopathy and conduction system diseases but are not linked to pulmonary arterial hypertension or right ventricular hypertrophy.

 

Option D. KCNQ1 mutation: This mutation is responsible for long QT syndrome, which leads to arrhythmias but does not cause pulmonary hypertension or right ventricular hypertrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The BMPR2 mutation is most commonly associated with heritable pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), which presents with signs of right heart strain, including right ventricular hypertrophy, jugular venous distention, and narrowly split S2.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents to the emergency department with a history of vomiting and diarrhea for 2 days. The child is irritable, has sunken eyes, and decreased skin turgor with a capillary refill time of about 2 seconds. The pediatrician diagnoses the child with moderate dehydration. What is the recommended amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given to this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 75 mL/kg

 

  • For a child with moderate dehydration, the recommended amount of ORS is 75 mL/kg of body weight. This helps to replace the fluid loss effectively and rehydrate the child.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 50 mL/kg: This amount is insufficient for moderate dehydration. It may be more appropriate for minimal dehydration.

 

Option C. 100 mL/kg: This amount is typically used in cases of severe dehydration when initial rehydration with IV fluids may also be considered.

 

Option D. 150 mL/kg: This exceeds the recommended amount and could lead to fluid overload in a child with moderate dehydration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For children with moderate dehydration, administer oral rehydration solution (ORS) at a dose of 75 mL/kg of body weight.
  • This amount helps to replenish lost fluids and electrolytes while ensuring gradual rehydration.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of schizophrenia presents with tremors, bradykinesia, and rigidity that started after he was started on antipsychotic medication. His symptoms are consistent with drug-induced Parkinsonism. Which of the following is the most appropriate drug to manage this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Biperiden

 

  • Biperiden is an anticholinergic agent that is effective in treating drug-induced Parkinsonism, particularly when caused by antipsychotic medications.
  • It works by blocking muscarinic receptors in the brain, which helps to restore the balance between dopaminergic and cholinergic activity that is often disrupted by medications like antipsychotics.
  • Anticholinergic agents are the first-line treatment for extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS), including drug-induced Parkinsonism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tolcapone: Tolcapone is a COMT (Catechol-O-methyltransferase) inhibitor used in Parkinson's disease to enhance the effects of levodopa. It is not used for drug-induced Parkinsonism as it is more specific for treating the motor fluctuations in idiopathic Parkinson's disease.

 

Option B. Selegiline: Selegiline is a MAO-B (monoamine Oxidase-B) inhibitor used in the management of idiopathic Parkinson's disease by reducing the breakdown of dopamine. It is not effective in managing drug-induced Parkinsonism caused by antipsychotics.

 

Option C. Amantadine: Amantadine is an NMDA receptor antagonist with some dopaminergic activity and can be used in Parkinson's disease for managing mild symptoms. However, anticholinergics like biperiden are preferred for drug-induced Parkinsonism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Biperiden and other anticholinergics are the drug of choice for drug-induced Parkinsonism, particularly due to antipsychotic medications.
  • Tolcapone and selegiline are used in idiopathic Parkinson’s disease but are not effective for drug-induced Parkinsonism.
  • Amantadine has some role in Parkinson’s disease but is not the first-line treatment for drug-induced extrapyramidal symptoms.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old male presents to the emergency department with palpitations and dizziness. His ECG shows ventricular arrhythmia. The pathophysiology of ventricular action potentials is reviewed to understand the mechanism behind the abnormal electrical activity. Which of the following options correctly arranges the sequence of events in the ventricular action potential?

 

A) Transient outward flow of potassium

B) Repolarizing K⁺ currents

C) Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels

D) Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C, D, A, B

 

Explanation:

 

The ventricular action potential consists of distinct phases that occur in the following sequence:

 

C. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels: This occurs during Phase 0, where rapid sodium influx leads to depolarization of the ventricular membrane.

 

D. Transient outward flow of potassium: During Phase 1, a brief outward potassium current causes a small drop in membrane potential, initiating partial repolarization.

 

A. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels: In Phase 2, calcium channels open, allowing calcium influx, which sustains the plateau phase, balancing the outward potassium flow.

 

B. Repolarizing K⁺ currents: During Phase 3, calcium channels close, and potassium efflux dominates, causing repolarization of the membrane and the return to the resting membrane potential.

 

This correct sequence is essential for coordinated contraction of the ventricular myocardium and proper cardiac function.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ventricular action potential occurs in a specific order: sodium channel opening (depolarization), followed by transient potassium outflow, then calcium channel activation (plateau phase), and finally, potassium-driven repolarization.
  • This sequence is critical for maintaining proper electrical and mechanical function of the heart.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious on the street. The history reveals chronic alcohol use. Upon arrival, he is confused and disoriented. His vitals are stable, and the physical exam shows no signs of trauma. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B1

 

  • The most appropriate initial treatment in this scenario is Vitamin B1 (thiamine).
  • Chronic alcohol use is strongly associated with thiamine deficiency, which can lead to Wernicke encephalopathy, a condition characterized by confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia.
  • Thiamine is a critical cofactor for enzymes involved in glucose metabolism, including pyruvate dehydrogenase and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase.
  • Administering thiamine before giving glucose is essential, as giving glucose alone can deplete the remaining thiamine stores, potentially worsening Wernicke encephalopathy.
  • Early treatment with thiamine can prevent progression to irreversible neurological damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B6: Incorrect. Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) is important in the management of certain conditions, such as isoniazid toxicity and some types of anemia, but it is not the first-line treatment for Wernicke encephalopathy caused by thiamine deficiency in chronic alcohol use.

 

Option C. Vitamin B12: Incorrect. Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiency is associated with megaloblastic anemia and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, but it is not the treatment for Wernicke encephalopathy. This patient's symptoms, combined with his history of chronic alcohol use, point to a thiamine deficiency rather than a B12 deficiency.

 

Option D. Folic acid: Incorrect. Folic acid is often used to treat megaloblastic anemia in chronic alcohol users, as alcohol can impair folate absorption. However, it does not address the risk of Wernicke encephalopathy. Thiamine is the priority in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with chronic alcohol use at risk for Wernicke encephalopathy, Vitamin B1 (thiamine) should be administered before any glucose to prevent worsening of neurological symptoms.
  • Thiamine deficiency can cause serious complications if not addressed promptly, making early intervention crucial in preventing irreversible damage.

choices.text: There is a strong positive correlation between drug dosage and blood pressure reduction.
There is a negative correlation between drug dosage and blood pressure reduction.
The data shows no significant correlation between drug dosage and blood pressure reduction.
The relationship between drug dosage and blood pressure reduction is non-linear.

questions.text: A researcher is analyzing the relationship between the dosage of a new drug (variable X) and the reduction in blood pressure (variable Y) in a group of hypertensive patients. The scatter plot below displays the data collected from this study. Based on the plot, what conclusion can be drawn about the relationship between the drug dosage and blood pressure reduction?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) There is a strong positive correlation between drug dosage and blood pressure reduction.

 

  • The scatter plot shows that as X (drug dosage) increases, Y (blood pressure reduction) also increases, which is characteristic of a positive correlation.
  • The data points tend to form an upward trend, indicating that higher doses of the drug are associated with greater reductions in blood pressure.
  • This type of relationship is often seen when increasing a medication dose results in a stronger therapeutic effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. There is a negative correlation between drug dosage and blood pressure reduction: Incorrect. A negative correlation would indicate that as the drug dosage increases, the reduction in blood pressure decreases. The plot shows the opposite trend, with both increasing together.

 

Option C. The data shows no significant correlation between drug dosage and blood pressure reduction: Incorrect. The scatter plot clearly shows a pattern where higher X values (dosage) are associated with higher Y values (reduction), indicating a significant positive correlation.

 

Option D. The relationship between drug dosage and blood pressure reduction is non-linear: Incorrect. The scatter plot suggests a linear trend, where changes in X correspond consistently with changes in Y, forming an approximately straight-line pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scatter plots are valuable for visualizing relationships between two continuous variables.

choices.text: Thiamine administration should be given before glucose
The classic triad includes confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia
Korsakoff's syndrome always follows if left untreated
Prompt treatment can reverse symptoms in many cases

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of heavy alcohol use presents with confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia. Which of the following statements about his condition is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Korsakoff's syndrome always follows if left untreated

 

While untreated Wernicke’s encephalopathy can progress to Korsakoff’s syndrome, it does not always do so. Korsakoff’s syndrome, characterized by severe memory impairment and confabulation, occurs in some cases but not all. Early recognition and treatment of Wernicke’s encephalopathy can prevent progression to Korsakoff's syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine administration should be given before glucose (True): Thiamine should be administered before glucose in patients with suspected Wernicke’s encephalopathy because giving glucose without thiamine can worsen the condition. Thiamine is a cofactor in carbohydrate metabolism, and administering glucose first can deplete the already low thiamine levels, exacerbating symptoms.

 

Option B. The classic triad includes confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia (True): The classic triad of Wernicke’s encephalopathy includes confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia (paralysis or weakness of the eye muscles). However, not all patients present with the full triad, making early diagnosis sometimes challenging.

 

Option D. Prompt treatment can reverse symptoms in many cases (True): Early administration of thiamine can reverse the symptoms of Wernicke’s encephalopathy, especially if treatment is initiated quickly. However, if the condition progresses to Korsakoff’s syndrome, cognitive impairments may become permanent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wernicke’s encephalopathy is an acute complication due to thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency. It is characterized by a triad of global confusion, ophthalmoplegia (6th cranial nerve palsy > 3rd nerve palsy), and ataxia in the context of chronic alcohol abuse. Wernicke encephalopathy may clear spontaneously in a few days or weeks or may progress to Korsakoff syndrome. Immediate treatment with thiamine is essential to prevent further progression to Korsakoff syndrome.

choices.text: Use paladai for routine feeding as the primary method
Switch to nasogastric tube feeding due to gestational age
Initiate breastfeeding directly with mother’s milk
Avoid using paladai until 36 weeks gestational age

questions.text: A 2-day-old newborn is in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) because his mother is severely ill and unable to breastfeed. The child was born at 33 weeks of gestation and is stable. Which of the following is the most appropriate method for feeding for this newborn?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Use paladai for routine feeding as the primary method

 

  • A paladai, can be used for feeding neonates born at a gestational age of 32-34 weeks when coordination between swallowing and breathing starts to develop.
  • It is suitable for stable preterm infants who can safely take feeds without the need for tube feeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Switch to nasogastric tube feeding due to gestational age: Nasogastric tube feeding is more appropriate for neonates born before 32 weeks of gestation or for those who cannot coordinate suck, swallow, and breathing. Since the newborn in the scenario is at 33 weeks and stable, paladai can be safely used.

 

Option C. Initiate breastfeeding directly with mother’s milk: Direct breastfeeding may not be immediately feasible for mothers who are unable to breastfeed, and the baby might still be developing the suckling reflex. Hence, expressed milk through paladai is appropriate in this case.

Option D. Avoid using paladai until 36 weeks gestational age: Paladai can be used from 32 weeks gestational age; waiting until 36 weeks is unnecessary when the infant is otherwise stable and shows feeding readiness signs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The paladai is suitable for feeding stable preterm infants born between 32-34 weeks of gestation when coordination between sucking, swallowing, and breathing begins to develop.
  • It is a practical alternative when direct breastfeeding is not an option due to maternal health conditions.

choices.text: Falling on an outstretched hand
Direct blow to the shoulder
Seizure or electric shock
Rotational force applied to the arm

questions.text: What is the mechanism of injury most commonly associated with a posterior shoulder dislocation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Seizure or electric shock

 

  • This option accurately describes the most common mechanism associated with posterior shoulder dislocations.
  • During a seizure or electric shock, the muscles can contract violently and uncontrollably.
  • This muscle spasm can pull the arm into an adducted and internally rotated position, leading to the humeral head dislocating posteriorly out of the glenoid cavity.
  • Posterior dislocations are relatively rare compared to anterior dislocations, but this mechanism is a classic cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Falling on an outstretched hand: This mechanism is typically associated with anterior shoulder dislocations, not posterior. When a person falls and attempts to catch themselves with an outstretched hand, the force is transmitted through the arm to the shoulder. This can cause the humeral head to dislocate forward (anteriorly) out of the glenoid cavity. Anterior dislocations are the most common type, accounting for the majority of shoulder dislocations.

 

Option B. Direct blow to the shoulder: A direct blow to the shoulder can cause a variety of shoulder injuries, including fractures or dislocations. However, it is more commonly associated with anterior dislocations. A significant impact can push the humeral head forward or downward but does not typically result in posterior dislocation unless the force is combined with other factors, such as rotation or specific positioning.

 

Option D. Rotational force applied to the arm: While rotational forces can lead to various shoulder injuries, including some types of dislocations, they are more commonly linked to specific types of traumatic injuries or certain sports-related incidents. This mechanism alone is not typically sufficient to cause a posterior dislocation unless it occurs in conjunction with other factors, such as the arm being in an abnormal position. It is more often involved in injuries like rotator cuff tears or other joint instability rather than a distinct posterior dislocation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Seizure or electric shock is the primary mechanism for posterior shoulder dislocations due to the violent contraction of muscles and subsequent positioning of the arm.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct match of antiarrhythmic drugs with their respective class?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) β-blockers - Class II

 

  • β-blockers are classified as Class II antiarrhythmics. They work by blocking beta-adrenergic receptors, reducing sympathetic activity in the heart, which results in a decrease in heart rate and myocardial contractility.
  • This class of drugs is particularly useful in treating tachyarrhythmias that are driven by excessive sympathetic stimulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Quinidine - Class Ib: This is incorrect. Quinidine is a Class Ia antiarrhythmic, not Class Ib. Class Ia drugs block sodium channels and also have some potassium channel blocking effects, which help prolong the action potential duration.

 

Option B. Lignocaine - Class Ia: This is incorrect. Lignocaine (lidocaine) is actually a Class Ib antiarrhythmic. Class Ib drugs primarily shorten the action potential duration and are effective in treating ventricular arrhythmias.

 

Option C. Amiodarone - Class IV: This is incorrect. Amiodarone is classified as a Class III antiarrhythmic, which blocks potassium channels, leading to prolongation of the action potential and refractory period. It also has actions across other classes but is primarily used as a Class III agent. Class IV drugs include calcium channel blockers like verapamil and diltiazem.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Class II antiarrhythmics are β-blockers, which reduce sympathetic stimulation of the heart.
  • Quinidine is a Class Ia drug, while lidocaine is Class Ib.
  • Amiodarone is a Class III antiarrhythmic that affects potassium channels.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman visits the emergency department with sudden onset dizziness, nausea, and difficulty maintaining balance. She reports that the symptoms began while she was having her hair washed in a salon with her head extended backward over a sink. Physical examination reveals nystagmus, ataxia, and dysarthria. A neurological assessment suggests possible artery damage. Which of the following arteries is most likely damaged in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vertebral artery

 

  • The vertebral artery is susceptible to damage or dissection in situations involving sudden or prolonged neck extension, such as during a hair wash with the head extended backward over a sink.
  • The vertebral artery supplies blood to the posterior circulation of the brain, including the cerebellum and brainstem.
  • Damage to this artery can result in vertebrobasilar insufficiency, leading to symptoms such as dizziness, nystagmus, ataxia, and dysarthria.
  • These symptoms occur because of reduced blood flow to the brainstem and cerebellum, which are critical for balance and coordination.

 

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior cerebral artery: Incorrect. The anterior cerebral artery supplies the medial portions of the frontal and parietal lobes, and damage to this artery typically presents with symptoms like contralateral leg weakness and personality changes, not with dizziness and ataxia.

 

Option C. Middle cerebral artery: Incorrect. The middle cerebral artery supplies the lateral aspects of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes, and damage here is typically associated with contralateral hemiparesis, aphasia, or sensory deficits, rather than balance and coordination issues.

 

Option D. Posterior cerebral artery: Incorrect. While the posterior cerebral artery supplies parts of the occipital lobe and thalamus, its damage typically causes visual disturbances or sensory loss rather than the cerebellar symptoms (e.g., ataxia and nystagmus) seen with vertebral artery damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vertebral artery damage can occur due to sudden neck hyperextension, leading to vertebrobasilar insufficiency and symptoms such as dizziness, nystagmus, ataxia, and dysarthria.
  • Recognizing the relationship between neck positioning and vertebral artery vulnerability is crucial for diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the clinic for her annual check-up. She has been using oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) for contraception for the past couple of years, without any significant side effects. She asks about long term risks associated with OCPs. Which of the following is considered the most serious complication of oral contraceptive usage?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leg vein thrombosis

 

  • Leg vein thrombosis (deep vein thrombosis, or DVT) is a serious complication associated with oral contraceptive pills (OCPs).
  • The estrogen component of OCPs increases the risk of thromboembolic events, including DVT and pulmonary embolism.
  • A patient presenting with unilateral leg pain, swelling, and tenderness should be evaluated for DVT as this can lead to life-threatening complications such as pulmonary embolism if not treated promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Headache: Incorrect. Headaches can be a common side effect of oral contraceptives, especially in women prone to migraines. However, they are generally not considered a serious complication unless associated with neurological symptoms suggestive of stroke.

 

Option C. Breakthrough bleeding: Incorrect. Breakthrough bleeding is a common and mild side effect of OCPs, particularly during the first few months of use. It does not pose a significant risk to the patient’s health.

 

Option D. Breast tenderness: Incorrect. Breast tenderness is a frequent side effect of hormonal contraceptives due to the estrogen and progesterone components. However, it is not dangerous and typically resolves with continued use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oral contraceptives increase the risk of thromboembolic events, including deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism, which are among the most serious complications.
  • Unilateral leg swelling and pain in a woman on OCPs should raise suspicion for DVT, and prompt diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent life-threatening consequences.
  • Milder side effects like headache, breakthrough bleeding, and breast tenderness are common but do not carry the same level of risk as thrombosis.

questions.text:
Match the following postmortem changes with the correct image provided.

 

Column A (Postmortem Changes):

  1. Suggillation
  2. Putrefaction
  3. Adipocere

 

Column B
questions.solution:
Ans. A) a-3, b-1, c-2

 

Explanation:

 

  • a. Suggillation (a3): Suggillation is the settling of blood in dependent areas after death, creating a purple discoloration, which matches Image 3, where this characteristic feature is evident.
  • b. Putrefaction (b1): Putrefaction refers to the breakdown of tissues by bacterial activity, leading to liquefaction and characteristic green or black discoloration, as seen in Image 1.
  • c. Adipocere (c2): Adipocere, or "grave wax," is formed by the transformation of body fat into a waxy substance, typically seen in bodies exposed to a moist environment. This is well-depicted in Image 2.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Suggillation involves discoloration due to blood pooling, putrefaction is the decomposition of tissues due to bacterial activity, and adipocere results from chemical changes in fatty tissues, often under moist conditions.

questions.text:
A public health researcher is compiling data on causes of death in India for a study on mortality trends. To ensure comprehensive data collection, the researcher utilizes various sources of mortality data available in the country. Which of the following sources are commonly used to gather causes of death data in India?

 

  1. Sample Registration System (SRS)
  2. Census
  3. Medical Certification of Cause of Death (MCCD)
  4. Verbal autopsy through Lay information
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4

 

Explanation:

 

  • The sources are commonly used for collecting causes of death data in India:

 

1. Sample Registration System (SRS): This system provides continuous and reliable data on births, deaths, and causes of death through a dual recording system that includes a field investigator and local enumerators.

 

3. Medical Certification of Cause of Death (MCCD): This method involves the certification of death causes by medical professionals for deaths that occur in hospitals or healthcare facilities.

 

4. Lay information and verbal autopsy: This method involves collecting information from family members or close contacts about the circumstances leading up to a person's death. It is particularly useful in rural and hard-to-reach areas where medical certification might not be available.

 

Other Option:

 

2. Census: Incorrect. Census does not collect specific causes of death data. The Census focuses on population counts and demographics rather than mortality causes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vital Statistics Data Sources: Census, Sample Registration System (SRS), Demographic Surveys (NSSO), Civil Registration System, Health Surveys (NFHS, DLHS)
  • Sources for Causes of Death: SRS (IMR, NNMR, MMR, U5MR), Death declaration and Medical certification, Lay information (Through First line health workers)

choices.text: More than 10% of TB patients tested for HIV are HIV-positive.
More than 12% of TB patients tested for HIV are HIV-positive.
More than 15% of TB patients tested for HIV are HIV-positive.
More than 20% of TB patients tested for HIV are HIV-positive.

questions.text: A public health officer is evaluating tuberculosis (TB) and HIV co-infection rates in a district to determine if it should be classified as a high-priority TB-HIV district under the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) in India. According to NTEP guidelines, which of the following criteria defines a high-priority TB-HIV district?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) More than 10% of TB patients tested for HIV are HIV-positive.

 

  • According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), a district is classified as a high-priority TB-HIV district if more than 10% of TB patients tested for HIV in the district are found to be HIV-positive.
  • This classification helps in prioritizing integrated care and resource allocation for TB-HIV co-infection management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Categorisation of Districts under NTEP (for HIV-TB Co-infection)

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer from a rural region presents with a progressively enlarging, swollen hand with multiple nodules and discharging sinuses, as shown below. He reports that the condition has been present for several months and initially started with a small painless swelling after a minor trauma while working in the fields. The patient denies any systemic symptoms like fever or malaise. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Eumycetoma

 

  • Eumycetoma is a chronic granulomatous fungal infection affecting the skin and subcutaneous tissues, often leading to the formation of tumefaction, multiple nodules, and sinuses discharging granules.
  • It typically occurs after trauma involving contaminated soil or organic matter, which explains the history of trauma while farming.
  • The grains seen in the discharging sinuses are characteristic of mycetoma, which differentiates it from other infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sporotrichosis: This is a fungal infection caused by Sporothrix schenckii. It typically presents as nodular lesions along lymphatic vessels but does not usually present with multiple draining sinuses or characteristic granules.

 

Option C. Actinomycosis: Actinomycosis is a bacterial infection that can produce multiple draining sinuses, but it commonly affects the cervicofacial region, and the discharges typically contain sulfur granules.

 

Option D. Cutaneous Tuberculosis: Cutaneous TB presents with skin lesions but is rarely associated with discharging sinuses containing granules. It also involves systemic symptoms more frequently.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Eumycetoma is a chronic infection involving the skin and subcutaneous tissue that presents with swelling, nodules, and multiple discharging sinuses containing grains.
  • It is often caused by fungi and primarily affects individuals working in rural environments.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man undergoes a right-sided neck dissection for invasive neck cancer. Two days postoperatively, he developed partial ptosis, miosis, and decreased sweating on the right side of his face. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Horner’s syndrome

 

  • Horner’s syndrome is characterized by a triad of ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis (loss of sweating) on the affected side of the face.
  • It occurs due to disruption of the cervical sympathetic pathway.
  • In this patient, the cervical sympathetic trunk may have been damaged during neck dissection for thyroid cancer, which is a known risk factor for Horner’s syndrome.
  • Ptosis is caused by paralysis of Müller’s muscle.
  • Miosis is due to loss of the dilator pupillae muscle function.
  • Anhidrosis occurs because of loss of sympathetic innervation to the sweat glands.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transient hypocalcemia: It is a common complication of thyroid or parathyroid surgery, but it presents with symptoms like perioral tingling, numbness, and muscle cramps rather than ptosis, miosis, or anhidrosis.

 

Option C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury: It often occurs in thyroid surgeries, leading to hoarseness or voice changes. It does not cause the ptosis, miosis, or anhidrosis seen in Horner's syndrome.

 

Option D. Postoperative hematoma: Following neck surgery can lead to airway obstruction, pain, and swelling. However, it is unlikely to cause the localized sympathetic nervous symptoms of Horner’s syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Horner’s syndrome is a result of disruption of the cervical sympathetic pathway, commonly due to surgical trauma in the neck region, particularly during thyroid or retro-esophageal surgeries.
  • Its classic triad includes ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis.
  • Recognizing these symptoms is crucial in postoperative evaluations, especially following surgeries involving the neck.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with no significant past medical history presents with new-onset bruising and joint pain. Laboratory workup shows a prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT), but her prothrombin time (PT) and bleeding time are normal. A mixing study is performed, where the patient's plasma is mixed with normal plasma. The PTT remains prolonged after mixing. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Factor VIII inhibitor

 

  • This patient presents with a prolonged PTT and a mixing study that fails to correct the PTT.

  • This suggests the presence of an inhibitor, rather than a deficiency in clotting factors.

  • The decreased factor VIII activity and failure of the mixing study to normalize the PTT point toward a factor VIII inhibitor as the cause of the coagulopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemophilia A: Incorrect. In hemophilia A, which involves a deficiency of Factor VIII, a mixing study would typically correct the prolonged PTT, as the normal plasma would provide the missing factor. Here, the mixing study did not correct the PTT, suggesting an inhibitor rather than a deficiency.

 

Option B. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC): Incorrect. In DIC, both the PT and PTT would be prolonged, and the bleeding time might also be affected due to widespread consumption of clotting factors and platelets. This patient's PT and bleeding time are normal, making DIC unlikely.

 

Option D. Vitamin K deficiency: Incorrect. Vitamin K deficiency typically affects factors II, VII, IX, and X, leading to prolongation of both the PT and PTT. In this case, the PT is normal, ruling out vitamin K deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A prolonged PTT that does not correct in a mixing study suggests the presence of an inhibitor, most commonly against Factor VIII, which can lead to bleeding symptoms similar to hemophilia.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of painful, erythematous pustules covering her trunk and extremities. She feels febrile and has been experiencing chills for the past few days. Physical examination reveals widespread pustules on erythematous skin. Her vital signs show a fever of 38.5°C (101.3°F). A skin biopsy is performed, and she is diagnosed with pustular psoriasis. You are determining the best treatment to control her condition. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acitretin

 

  • Pustular psoriasis is a severe, rare form of psoriasis characterized by widespread erythematous plaques with sterile pustules.
  • Patients may experience systemic symptoms such as fever, chills, and malaise.
  • The treatment of choice for generalized pustular psoriasis is acitretin, an oral retinoid, due to its effectiveness in reducing inflammation and promoting skin turnover.
  • Acitretin is especially useful in controlling severe, systemic forms of psoriasis like pustular psoriasis and is typically used in acute flares.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Psoralen + UV therapy (PUVA): PUVA therapy is used for plaque psoriasis and some chronic forms of the disease, but it is not recommended in acute generalized pustular psoriasis due to the patient's systemic symptoms and the need for rapid intervention.

 

Option B. Systemic steroid: Although systemic corticosteroids can rapidly suppress inflammation, they are not recommended in pustular psoriasis because their withdrawal can lead to severe rebound flares of the disease, worsening the patient's condition.

 

Option D. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is another systemic option used for severe psoriasis, but in the case of acute generalized pustular psoriasis, acitretin is preferred as the first-line treatment. Methotrexate may be considered if acitretin is not suitable, but it is not the primary choice in this situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acitretin, an oral retinoid, is the treatment of choice for generalized pustular psoriasis due to its effectiveness in controlling severe inflammatory flares and promoting skin healing.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is being considered for targeted therapy due to resistance to first-line treatment. The oncologist wants to use a medication that specifically targets the BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for this mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nilotinib

 

  • Nilotinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) that specifically targets the BCR-ABL fusion protein, which is a hallmark of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).
  • It is designed to inhibit the activity of the abnormal tyrosine kinase created by the Philadelphia chromosome translocation (t(9;22)).
  • Nilotinib is used in cases where patients are resistant to or intolerant of first-generation TKIs like imatinib.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lorlatinib: Lorlatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor that targets ALK (Anaplastic Lymphoma Kinase) and ROS1 rearrangements, making it effective in certain types of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), not CML.

 

Option C. Osimertinib: Osimertinib is a third-generation EGFR inhibitor used in patients with EGFR-mutated non-small cell lung cancer. It is effective against tumors with EGFR T790M mutations but does not target BCR-ABL.

 

Option D. Ruxolitinib: Ruxolitinib is a JAK 1 and 2 inhibitor used in the management of myeloproliferative disorders such as myelofibrosis and polycythemia vera. It is not effective against the BCR-ABL fusion protein.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nilotinib is a BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitor specifically used in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).
  • Lorlatinib targets ALK mutations, while Osimertinib targets EGFR mutations, both in non-small cell lung cancer.
  • Ruxolitinib is a JAK 1, 2 inhibitor used for conditions like myelofibrosis and polycythemia vera.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the typical surgical approach for a patient with a giant cell tumour of the bone?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intralesional curettage

 

  • Intralesional curettage is the preferred surgical approach for treating giant cell tumours of the bone, particularly when the tumour is not highly aggressive and is located in a place where complete resection is difficult.
  • This procedure involves scraping out the tumour from the bone while preserving as much surrounding healthy tissue as possible.
  • To minimize the chance of recurrence, the cavity left after curettage is often filled with bone graft material or cement, and additional treatments such as cryotherapy or phenol may be used to destroy residual tumour cells.
  • Intralesional curettage is effective in treating GCTs and has a relatively low complication rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wide resection: Wide resection involves removing the tumour along with a margin of healthy surrounding tissue. This approach is generally reserved for aggressive or recurrent giant cell tumours or when the tumour is located in a critical area where complete excision is feasible without compromising function. While wide resection can reduce the risk of local recurrence, it may also result in significant loss of bone and necessitate reconstruction or rehabilitation. This option is not the first line of treatment for typical GCTs.

 

Option C. Amputation: Amputation is rarely required for giant cell tumours of the bone, as most cases can be managed with less invasive procedures. It is considered only in extreme cases where the tumour is extensively aggressive, recurrent, or if it involves the joint in a way that prevents functional preservation. The decision to amputate is very case-specific and is generally avoided if possible.

 

Option D. Radiation therapy: Radiation therapy is not a primary treatment modality for giant cell tumours. While it can be used in cases where surgical options are limited or to treat recurrent tumours, it is generally considered less effective as a standalone treatment. GCTs are generally responsive to surgical interventions, and the use of radiation is typically limited to specific situations, such as in patients who are not surgical candidates or in cases of incomplete resection where there is a high risk of recurrence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intralesional curettage is the standard approach for managing giant cell tumours, allowing for effective removal with a lower risk of complications.

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) requires thermoregulation due to low birth weight and inability to maintain body temperature. The healthcare provider decides to use the device shown in the image to regulate the infant’s body temperature. This device operates primarily through which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radiation

 

  • The device in the image is a radiant warmer, which is commonly used in the NICU for thermoregulation in neonates. 
  • It works by using radiant heat to maintain a stable body temperature in infants who are unable to do so themselves, particularly those who are premature or of low birth weight.
  • Radiant warmers emit infrared radiation to warm the surface of the neonate’s body directly without needing the surrounding air to be heated. This method is effective for maintaining skin temperature in a controlled manner.
  • Radiant warmers are set in servo-control mode, maintaining the temperature between 36.5°C to 37°C to ensure the neonate remains within a safe and comfortable temperature range.
     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conduction: Refers to heat transfer through direct contact with a warmer surface. It is not the primary mechanism of radiant warmers.

 

Option B. Convection: Involves heat transfer through air movement. Incubators use convective heating to maintain a warm environment for the infant, but this is different from the radiant warmer.

 

Option D. Induction: Is a process where heat is generated through electromagnetic fields, commonly used in cooking but not applicable in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Radiant warmers provide effective thermoregulation for neonates by using radiant heat to directly warm the skin. 
  • This method is particularly useful in the NICU setting for infants who cannot maintain their own body temperature, such as those born prematurely or with low birth weight.

choices.text: Subcostal nerve (T12) and anterior branches of L1-L4

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with lower back pain that worsens with bending and twisting movements. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the lower lumbar region, particularly around the lateral abdominal wall, suggesting involvement of a muscle that stabilizes the lumbar spine and aids in lateral flexion of the trunk. Which of the following nerves most likely innervates the affected muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subcostal nerve (T12) and anterior branches of L1-L4

 

  • The quadratus lumborum muscle is innervated by the subcostal nerve (T12) and the anterior branches of the lumbar nerves L1-L4.
  • This muscle is located in the posterior abdominal wall and extends from the 12th rib to the iliac crest, attaching to the transverse processes of the lumbar vertebrae.
  • Its functions include stabilizing the lumbar spine, assisting in lateral flexion of the trunk, and fixing the 12th rib during forced expiration.
  • Injury or strain to the quadratus lumborum can result in lower back pain, particularly with movements that involve bending or twisting, as these actions engage this muscle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Femoral nerve: Incorrect. The femoral nerve originates from L2-L4 and innervates muscles of the anterior thigh, such as the quadriceps femoris and iliopsoas. It is not involved in innervating the quadratus lumborum, which is located in the posterior abdominal wall.

 

Option C. Obturator nerve: Incorrect. The obturator nerve arises from L2-L4 and supplies the medial compartment of the thigh, innervating muscles like the adductors. It does not contribute to the innervation of the quadratus lumborum.

 

Option D. Ilioinguinal nerve: Incorrect. The ilioinguinal nerve arises from L1 and provides sensory innervation to the inguinal region and lower abdominal wall. Although it is in proximity to the quadratus lumborum, it does not innervate this muscle directly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The quadratus lumborum muscle is innervated by the subcostal nerve (T12) and the anterior branches of L1-L4 from the lumbar plexus.
  • It plays a key role in stabilizing the lumbar spine, lateral flexion of the trunk, and fixing the 12th rib during respiration.

choices.text: The sense strand of DNA is the strand used by RNA polymerase during transcription.
The antisense DNA strand is identical to the RNA transcript except that the DNA strand contains thymine and the RNA strand contains uracil.
The first RNA form produced contains both intron and exon sequences.
Mature mRNA contains a cap at the 5′-end, a poly(A) tail at the 3′ end, introns, and exons.

questions.text: The production of mRNA in eukaryotic cells requires a large number of steps, and drugs targeted to any of these steps could block mRNA production. Which one of the following accurately describes a part of the process of producing mRNA from a eukaryotic gene?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The first RNA form produced contains both intron and exon sequences.

 

  • The sense (or coding) strand of DNA is identical to the mRNA produced, with the exception of the DNA containing thymine and the RNA containing uracil.
  • The template (or antisense) strand of DNA is the strand that is used by RNA polymerase to produce a complementary RNA sequence to the template strand (thus, the antisense strand is complementary to the mRNA produced and is not identical to it).
  • The first RNA form produced by RNA polymerase is hnRNA, which contains both intron (noncoding) and exon (coding sequences) sequences.
  • hnRNA is modified by the addition of a cap to the 5′-end, a poly(A) tail added to the 3′-end, and all introns removed.
  • During processing, the intron sequences are removed from the hnRNA to produce the mature mRNA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The sense strand of DNA is the strand used by RNA polymerase during transcription: This statement is incorrect. RNA polymerase uses the antisense strand of DNA (the template strand) to synthesize the mRNA. The sense strand, also called the coding strand, has a sequence that matches the RNA transcript (except that thymine in DNA is replaced by uracil in RNA). The antisense strand is the template for RNA polymerase to generate a complementary RNA strand.

 

Option B. The antisense DNA strand is identical to the RNA transcript except that the DNA strand contains thymine and the RNA strand contains uracil: This statement is incorrect. The sense strand (coding strand) of DNA, not the antisense strand, is nearly identical to the RNA transcript, with the exception that thymine (T) is replaced by uracil (U) in RNA. The antisense strand is complementary to both the sense strand and the mRNA transcript, not identical to the RNA.

 

Option D. Mature mRNA contains a cap at the 5′-end, a poly(A) tail at the 3′ end, introns, and exons: This statement is incorrect because mature mRNA does not contain introns. The process of splicing removes introns from the pre-mRNA, leaving only the exons in the mature mRNA. While mature mRNA does indeed have a 5′ cap and a 3′ poly(A) tail, it contains only exons, not introns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary transcript of mRNA in eukaryotic cells contains both introns and exons, and introns are spliced out during processing to form the mature mRNA.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with recurrent kidney stones undergoes a metabolic evaluation, which reveals elevated concentrations of various solutes in his urine. Which of the following solutes does not decrease in concentration as filtrate flows through the proximal convoluted tubule?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chloride

 

  • As filtrate moves through the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), the concentration of most solutes decreases due to their reabsorption.
  • However, chloride behaves differently from other solutes.
  • Initially, water is reabsorbed more rapidly than chloride, causing its concentration to increase transiently.
  • Although chloride is later reabsorbed, its concentration does not decrease as significantly compared to other solutes like glucose, amino acids, or bicarbonate in the early PCT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose: Incorrect. Glucose is almost entirely reabsorbed in the PCT, leading to a rapid decrease in its concentration as the filtrate passes through the tubule.

 

Option B. Amino acids: Incorrect. Amino acids are also almost completely reabsorbed in the PCT, causing a sharp decline in their concentration in the filtrate.

 

Option C. Bicarbonate: Incorrect. Bicarbonate is reabsorbed in the PCT to help regulate acid-base balance, resulting in a decreased concentration of bicarbonate in the filtrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the proximal convoluted tubule, the concentration of solutes such as glucose, amino acids, and bicarbonate decreases due to reabsorption.
  • Chloride concentration initially increases due to faster water reabsorption before being reabsorbed later, resulting in a different concentration profile.

questions.text: A study is conducted to assess the accuracy of rapid antigen testing in diagnosing influenza in a group of patients presenting with flu-like symptoms. A total of 180 patients were tested using the rapid antigen test, and their diagnosis was confirmed by a PCR test (gold standard). Out of 70 patients who tested positive on the rapid antigen test, 50 were confirmed to have influenza by PCR. Among the 110 patients who tested negative on the rapid test, 90 were confirmed to be free of influenza by PCR. Calculate the Positive Likelihood Ratio (LR+) and Negative Likelihood Ratio (LR−) for the rapid antigen test.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3.57 and 0.4

 

To calculate the Positive Likelihood Ratio (LR+) and Negative Likelihood Ratio (LR−), we need to determine sensitivity and specificity based on the given data:

 

Step-by-step calculations:

 

  • True Positives (TP) = 50 (patients who tested positive on the rapid antigen test and were confirmed positive by PCR)
  • False Positives (FP) = 70 - 50 = 20 (patients who tested positive on the rapid test but were negative by PCR)
  • True Negatives (TN) = 90 (patients who tested negative on the rapid test and were confirmed negative by PCR)
  • False Negatives (FN) = 110 - 90 = 20 (patients who tested negative on the rapid test but were confirmed positive by PCR)

 

1. Calculating Sensitivity and Specificity:

 

  • Sensitivity = TP / (TP + FN) = 50 / (50 + 20) = 50 / 70 = 0.714
  • Specificity = TN / (TN + FP) = 90 / (90 + 20) = 90 / 110 = 0.818

 

2. Calculating Positive Likelihood Ratio (LR+):

 

 

3. Calculating Negative Likelihood Ratio (LR−):

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Positive Likelihood Ratio (LR+) quantifies how much more likely a positive test result is in those with the disease compared to those without the disease.
  • Negative Likelihood Ratio (LR−) indicates how much less likely a negative test result is in those with the disease compared to those without the disease.
  • For the rapid antigen test in diagnosing influenza, an LR+ of 3.57 means that a positive test result is about 3.57 times more likely in a patient with the disease, and an LR− of 0.4 means that a negative result decreases the likelihood of the disease to 40% of the baseline probability.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male presents with intermittent cyanosis and exercise intolerance that began 6 months ago and has progressively worsened. He has a history of a congenital heart defect, diagnosed shortly after birth, but no interventions were performed. On physical examination, there is cyanosis of the lips and digital clubbing. Cardiac catheterization reveals the following oxygen saturations:

 

  • Right Atrium: 72%
  • Right Ventricle: 74%
  • Pulmonary Artery: 73%
  • Left Atrium: 92%
  • Left Ventricle: 92%
  • Aorta: 85%

 

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Eisenmenger syndrome

 

  • This patient’s cyanosis, exercise intolerance, and the pattern of oxygen saturations strongly suggest Eisenmenger syndrome, which is a complication of an unrepaired congenital heart defect that initially causes a left-to-right shunt. 
  • Over time, the increased pulmonary blood flow leads to pulmonary hypertension, causing a reversal of the shunt (right-to-left), which results in cyanosis and systemic oxygen desaturation (as seen in the lower oxygen saturation in the aorta compared to the left atrium and left ventricle).

 

The patient's cardiac catheterization findings support this diagnosis:

 

  • The saturation difference between the left heart (92%) and the aorta (85%) indicates right-to-left shunting at some point after the left ventricle.
  • The relatively low saturations in the right heart (72-74%) without a significant increase in oxygen saturation in the pulmonary artery (73%) suggests there is no left-to-right shunt.
  • In Eisenmenger syndrome, long-standing left-to-right shunts, such as from a ventricular septal defect (VSD), atrial septal defect (ASD), or patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), lead to pulmonary vascular disease and eventual reversal of the shunt to right-to-left, causing systemic hypoxia and cyanosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ventricular septal defect (VSD): A simple VSD would cause a left-to-right shunt, leading to increased oxygen saturation in the right heart chambers and pulmonary artery. However, the findings here indicate a right-to-left shunt, consistent with Eisenmenger syndrome.

 

Option C. Atrial septal defect (ASD): Similar to a VSD, an ASD would initially cause a left-to-right shunt, increasing oxygen saturation in the right atrium, which is not seen here. The progression to Eisenmenger syndrome (A) is a more accurate explanation for this case.

 

Option D. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA): A PDA would lead to increased oxygenation in the pulmonary artery due to a left-to-right shunt, which is not observed here. Once the PDA causes pulmonary hypertension and a right-to-left shunt, it would lead to Eisenmenger syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eisenmenger syndrome results from the reversal of an initially left-to-right shunt due to progressive pulmonary hypertension, leading to right-to-left shunting, cyanosis, and systemic hypoxemia.

questions.text: Match the condition with the appropriate diagnostic test:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4

 

 

A-1. Hirschsprung's disease is diagnosed by rectal biopsy, which is the gold standard diagnostic test for this condition.

 

B-2. Posterior urethral valve is diagnosed by micturating cystourethrogram, which is a radiographic imaging test of the bladder and urethra during voiding.

 

C-3. Choledochal cyst is diagnosed by MRCP, which is a non-invasive imaging test that uses magnetic resonance imaging to visualize the biliary tree.

 

D-4. Intussusception is diagnosed by CT scan, which is a diagnostic imaging test that provides detailed images of the abdominal organs and structures.

 

Explanation:

 

A. Hirschsprung's disease: This is a congenital disorder in which nerve cells (ganglion cells) are absent from a segment of the bowel, usually the rectum or sigmoid colon, leading to a functional obstruction. Infants with Hirschsprung's typically have difficulty with bowel movements within the first days of life. The symptoms can include constipation, abdominal distension, and vomiting. It is diagnosed often in the neonatal period with a barium enema and confirmed with suction rectal biopsy showing the absence of ganglion cells.

 

B. Posterior urethral valve (PUV): PUV is a congenital malformation in male child where an abnormality of the posterior urethra prevents urine outflow. This can lead to urinary obstruction, distension of the bladder, and can subsequently cause damage to the kidneys. Common symptoms include weak urine stream, difficulty in urination, recurrent urinary tract infections, and failure to thrive. Diagnosis is usually made with a voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG).

 

C. Choledochal cyst: This is a congenital dilation of the bile ducts, often causing obstruction. Patients may present with the classic triad of abdominal pain, jaundice, and an abdominal mass, although not all these signs may be evident. Over time, choledochal cysts can lead to complications like cholangitis, pancreatitis, or even malignancy. Diagnosis is typically done with imaging like ultrasound or MRCP, and definitive treatment is surgical removal.

 

D. Intussusception: This is a medical condition in which a part of the intestine telescopes into another section, leading to bowel obstruction. It is the most common cause of bowel obstruction in children between the ages of 6 months and 3 years. Symptoms include sudden, severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and "currant jelly" stools (due to mucus and blood). The diagnosis can often be made with an ultrasound or CT abdomen showing the characteristic "target sign" and is typically treated with high pressure enema, although some cases may require surgical intervention.

choices.text: Trapping of iodine into the colloid

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, weight gain, and swelling in his neck. Physical examination reveals a significantly enlarged thyroid gland. His blood tests show decreased levels of T3 and T4. A deficiency in dietary iodine is suspected as the underlying cause of her condition. Which of the following best describes the function of thyroid peroxidase in thyroid hormone synthesis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oxidation of iodide

 

  • Thyroid peroxidase is a key enzyme involved in the production of thyroid hormones.
  • It catalyzes the oxidation of iodide to iodine, which is necessary for the iodination of tyrosine residues on thyroglobulin.
  • This process is essential for the formation of monoiodotyrosine (MIT) and diiodotyrosine (DIT), precursors to the thyroid hormones T3 and T4.
  • Iodine deficiency limits the substrate available for this process, leading to reduced production of thyroid hormones and resulting in hypothyroidism, as seen in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iodine transport into follicular cells: Incorrect. The transport of iodine into thyroid follicular cells is mediated by the sodium-iodide symporter (NIS), not thyroid peroxidase. NIS transports iodide across the cell membrane into the follicular cells, where it is then oxidized by thyroid peroxidase.

 

Option B. Trapping of iodine into the colloid: Iodine is trapped in the colloid within the thyroid follicles after being oxidized and organified into the thyroglobulin molecule. This step follows the oxidation of iodide and is not a function of thyroid peroxidase.

 

Option C. Thyroglobulin synthesis: Thyroglobulin is synthesized by the follicular cells of the thyroid and released into the colloid where it acts as a scaffold for thyroid hormone production. However, its synthesis is not directly related to the function of thyroid peroxidase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thyroid peroxidase is responsible for oxidation of iodide to iodine, a critical step in the synthesis of thyroid hormones.
  • In cases of iodine deficiency, reduced availability of iodide results in decreased production of T3 and T4, leading to hypothyroidism and thyroid enlargement.

choices.text: Life is adjusted for the presence of disease.
Premature death is adjusted for the degree of disability.
Years lost to premature death and years lived with disability, adjusted for the severity of the disability.

questions.text: A public health researcher is studying the global burden of disease and focuses on metrics that combine information about mortality and disability. Which of the following best describes Disability-Adjusted Life Years (DALYs)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Years lost to premature death and years lived with disability, adjusted for the severity of the disability.

 

  • Disability-Adjusted Life Years (DALYs) is a measure that quantifies the burden of disease by combining two components:
    • Years of Life Lost (YLL) due to premature death, which accounts for the years lost if an individual die earlier than the standard life expectancy.
    • Years Lived with Disability (YLD), which considers the time spent living with a disability or condition, adjusted by a disability weight that reflects the severity of the condition.
  • By adding these two components, DALYs measure both the impact of early mortality and the burden of living with disease in a single value. It provides a comprehensive view of overall disease burden in a population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Life is adjusted for the presence of disease: Incorrect. This option does not fully capture the two components of DALYs (YLL and YLD) and the focus is on both premature death and disability.

 

Option B. Premature death is adjusted for the degree of disability: Incorrect. While DALYs do account for premature death and disability, they do not directly adjust premature death for the degree of disability.

 

Option C. Life expectancy free of disability: Incorrect. This definition is more aligned with Healthy Life Expectancy (HALE), which estimates life expectancy in terms of years lived without disability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Disability-Adjusted Life Years (DALYs) are a measure that combines years lost due to premature death and years lived with disability, adjusted for severity.
  • DALYs are a key metric in assessing the burden of disease and help guide public health priorities by highlighting the impact of different conditions on a population's health.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man with a family history of hypertension visits the clinic for a routine health check-up. He is currently asymptomatic, with a blood pressure of 120/75 mm Hg. The physician discusses strategies for preventing hypertension with him. Which of the following measures would be appropriate as primary prevention for hypertension in this patient?

 

 

1. Weight reduction

2. Dietary salt reduction

3. Exercise promotion

4. Early diagnosis
