5. Antihypertensive drugs
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3

 

  • Primary prevention of hypertension encompasses measures that can be implemented before the onset of high blood pressure to maintain normal blood pressure levels and reduce the risk of future hypertension. This includes:

 

1. Weight reduction: Maintaining a healthy weight helps reduce the risk of developing hypertension.

 

2. Dietary salt reduction: Reducing sodium intake can help prevent the increase in blood pressure.

 

3. Exercise promotion: Regular physical activity helps maintain a healthy cardiovascular system and prevents hypertension.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Early diagnosis: Early diagnosis is part of secondary prevention.

 

5. Antihypertensive drugs: Medications are reserved for secondary prevention or treatment once hypertension has been diagnosed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Primary prevention of hypertension focuses on lifestyle modifications such as weight reduction, salt restriction, and exercise.
  • Antihypertensive medications are used for treatment or secondary prevention after hypertension is diagnosed, not for primary prevention in individuals with normal blood pressure.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male with a long-standing history of smoking presents with weight loss, jaundice, and new-onset diabetes. CT scan reveals a pancreatic mass. Which of the following is not considered a risk factor for pancreatic cancer?

 

1. Chronic pancreatitis

2. BRCA2 mutation

3. Female gender

4. Cigarette smoking

5. Obesity
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3

 

  • Female gender is not considered a significant risk factor for pancreatic cancer, whereas cigarette smoking is one of the most well-established risk factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2 and 4: BRCA2 mutations increase the risk of pancreatic cancer, especially in families with a strong history of breast and ovarian cancers. Cigarette smoking is also a strong risk factor for pancreatic cancer.

 

Option B. 1 and 5: Chronic pancreatitis and obesity are associated with an increased risk of pancreatic cancer due to the prolonged inflammation and metabolic factors involved.

 

Option D. All risk factors: Female gender alone is not a risk factor. Risk is higher in males

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Pancreatic cancer has multiple risk factors, including chronic pancreatitis, smoking, diabetes, and genetic mutations (such as BRCA2).
  • Female gender is not considered a significant risk factor, unlike male gender or advanced age.

choices.text: Sociodemographic reasons for migration of a population
Prevalence of disease in a population
Environmental and genetic factors in a disease in population
Diseases with long incubation periods

questions.text: A researcher is studying the incidence of certain types of cancer among Japanese individuals who have migrated to the United States compared to those who remained in Japan. This study aims to assess how the risk of cancer changes based on the different environments. Which of the following is most likely being evaluated in this migration study?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Environmental and genetic factors in a disease in population

 

  • Migration studies are used to assess the role of environmental and genetic factors in the development of diseases.
  • By comparing populations who migrate with those who remain in their original location, researchers can determine how much of the disease burden is influenced by changes in environment (such as diet, lifestyle, or exposure to pollutants) versus genetic predisposition.
  • For example, an increase in cancer rates in a migrant population that matches the rates in the host country suggests a stronger environmental influence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sociodemographic reasons for migration of a population: Incorrect. Migration studies are not typically used to study the reasons behind migration but rather to evaluate the health impact of migration.

 

Option B. Prevalence of disease in a population: Incorrect. Cross-sectional studies are more suitable for determining prevalence.

 

Option D. Diseases with long incubation periods: Incorrect. While some migration studies might involve diseases with long incubation periods, the primary focus is on the interaction of genetic and environmental factors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Migration studies are valuable for understanding how environmental changes affect the incidence of diseases in populations with similar genetic backgrounds.
  • They help distinguish between genetic predisposition and environmental influences on disease development.

questions.text: A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with abnormal uterine bleeding. A biopsy reveals simple hyperplasia of the endometrium with atypia. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Simple hysterectomy

 

  • Endometrial hyperplasia with atypia carries a significant risk of progression to endometrial carcinoma.
  • The presence of atypia is concerning, especially in postmenopausal women like this patient.
  • In this case, hysterectomy is considered the best definitive treatment option, as it eliminates the risk of progression to malignancy.
  • For women who are postmenopausal and have atypical hyperplasia, hysterectomy is the ideal treatment to prevent the development of endometrial cancer.
  • This patient is 55 years old, postmenopausal, and desires definitive treatment, making simple hysterectomy the appropriate choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medroxyprogesterone acetate: Incorrect. Progestins like medroxyprogesterone acetate can be used in the treatment of endometrial hyperplasia, particularly in women who wish to preserve fertility or are poor surgical candidates. However, in a postmenopausal woman with atypical hyperplasia, this is not the first-line treatment.

 

Option B. Levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine device (IUD): Incorrect. The levonorgestrel IUD can be used to treat endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, particularly in premenopausal women. However, in this postmenopausal woman with atypia, a hysterectomy is preferred to eliminate the risk of progression to malignancy.

 

Option C. Radiotherapy: Incorrect. Radiotherapy is typically used for the treatment of advanced or recurrent endometrial cancer but is not indicated for simple hyperplasia with atypia. Hysterectomy is the definitive treatment in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For postmenopausal women with endometrial hyperplasia with atypia, the recommended and most definitive treatment is simple hysterectomy to prevent the risk of progression to endometrial cancer.
  • Progestin therapy is an option for patients who are not surgical candidates or who wish to preserve fertility, but hysterectomy is preferred in this context.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male presents with fatigue and dark urine. He has a history of diarrhea for 3 months. On physical examination, scleral icterus is noted, and there is mild right upper quadrant tenderness. Laboratory tests reveal the following:

 

  • Total bilirubin: 2.2 mg/dL
  • Direct bilirubin: 1.6 mg/dL
  • ALP: 422 U/L
  • ALT: 80 U/L
  • Anti-HBs: positive

 

MRCP was done and it is shown. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Colonoscopy

 

  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is characterized by chronic inflammation and fibrosis of the bile ducts, leading to bile duct strictures, which is typically seen on MRCP (magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography).
  • PSC is strongly associated with ulcerative colitis (UC), and many patients with PSC also have underlying IBD. Given this patient’s history of chronic diarrhea, it is essential to evaluate for UC or other forms of IBD.
  • Colonoscopy with biopsy is the next best step to assess for the presence of IBD, particularly UC, which would guide the management of both conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fecal calprotectin: This can be used as a non-invasive marker for IBD activity, but it is not as definitive or necessary as colonoscopy with biopsy for diagnosis in this case.

 

Option C. Liver biopsy: While liver biopsy can confirm PSC, it is not necessary if characteristic findings are present on MRCP, which is the gold standard imaging for PSC.

 

Option D. Serum AMA (Antimitochondrial antibody): This is used to diagnose primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), not PSC. The clinical picture and MRCP findings are more consistent with PSC rather than PBC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with cholestatic liver function abnormalities (elevated ALP), positive anti-HBs, and MRCP findings suggestive of bile duct strictures, colonoscopy is the next best step to evaluate for the presence of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), particularly ulcerative colitis, which is commonly associated with primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC).

questions.text: A radiology resident is reviewing a thyroid ultrasound for evaluation of a nodule. Which of the following is not included in the American College of Radiology's Thyroid Imaging Reporting and Data System (ACR TI-RADS) criteria?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vascularity

 

  • Vascularity refers to the blood flow within a nodule as seen on Doppler ultrasound.
  • While vascularity is assessed in thyroid nodules, it is not part of the ACR TI-RADS. TI-RADS is based on the nodule's composition, echogenicity, shape, margin, and echogenic foci, not vascularity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Margin: Margins are evaluated in thyroid nodules to determine the risk of malignancy. TI-RADS includes margin assessment with descriptors like smooth, ill-defined, lobulated, or irregular to score the nodules.

 

Option B. Echogenicity: Echogenicity describes the brightness of a thyroid nodule compared to the surrounding thyroid tissue. TI-RADS uses echogenicity as a criterion, including anechoic, hyperechoic, isoechoic, and hypoechoic as descriptors.

 

Option D. Shape: The shape of a nodule, whether it is wider than tall or taller-than-wide, is a significant factor in TI-RADS. A taller-than-wide shape is more concerning for malignancy and is thus included in the TI-RADS scoring system.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Vascularity is not included in the ACR TI-RADS criteria for thyroid nodules. TI-RADS is utilized to stratify the risk of thyroid nodules based on their ultrasound characteristics, excluding vascularity, which aids medical students and residents in identifying nodules that may require further evaluation or intervention.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of progressive hearing loss in her right ear over the past year. She reports no significant ear pain, discharge, or vertigo. Physical examination reveals normal-appearing tympanic membranes. The Weber test lateralizes to the right ear, and the Rinne test shows bone conduction greater than air conduction in the right ear. A diagnosis of otosclerosis is suspected. Which of the following tests would be most useful to confirm this diagnosis in a clinical setting?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gelle’s Test

 

  • Gelle’s test is a tuning fork test historically used to confirm the presence of otosclerosis.
  • It is based on the principle that increasing pressure in the external auditory canal would normally result in the stapes footplate being pushed medially, halting sound transmission.
  • In otosclerosis, where the stapes footplate is fixed due to abnormal bone growth, this maneuver does not stop sound transmission, and the test remains positive.
  • This is because the stapes footplate remains fixed despite the pressure changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Audiometry: While audiometry can confirm the type and degree of hearing loss, it does not specifically diagnose otosclerosis without additional clinical tests.

 

Option C. Schwabach Test: This test compares the patient's bone conduction with that of the examiner, which helps in identifying the type of hearing loss but is less specific for otosclerosis.

 

Option D. Tympanometry: This test assesses the mobility of the tympanic membrane and middle ear pressure but is not specific for detecting stapes fixation seen in otosclerosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gelle’s test is useful for diagnosing otosclerosis by assessing the fixation of the stapes footplate.
  • It remains a positive test when the stapes is immobile, unlike in cases of normal middle ear function or sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents with jaundice. Serological tests reveal the following results:

 

  • HBsAg positive
  • Anti-HBs negative
  • Anti-HBc (Total) - Positive
  • Anti-HBc (IgM) - Positive
  • Anti-HDV positive

 

What do you infer from the above findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HBV and HDV coinfection.

 

  • This serological profile is consistent with acute coinfection of both hepatitis B virus (HBV) and hepatitis D virus (HDV). 
  • HDV can only replicate in the presence of HBV, and when both viruses are acquired simultaneously, it is referred to as an HBV and HDV coinfection.

 

Key findings supporting this:

 

  • HBsAg positive: Indicates active hepatitis B infection.
  • Anti-HBs negative: No immunity to HBV (either from recovery or vaccination).
  • Anti-HBc (IgM) positive: Indicates acute HBV infection.
  • Anti-HDV positive: Confirms the presence of hepatitis D virus.
  • In coinfection, both HBV and HDV are acquired at the same time, leading to acute hepatitis. Anti-HBc IgM and Anti-HDV are both positive, suggesting the patient is in the acute phase of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HDV superinfection: HDV superinfection occurs when a person with chronic HBV later acquires HDV. In this case, the Anti-HBc IgM would not be positive, as the infection would be chronic (Anti-HBc IgG would be positive instead).

 

Option C. Chronic HBV: In chronic HBV infection, Anti-HBc IgM would not be positive, as the acute phase has resolved. Instead, Anti-HBc (IgG) and HBsAg would be present for more than 6 months.

 

Option D. HBV in the window period: In the window period, HBsAg would be negative, and only Anti-HBc (IgM) would be positive. Additionally, Anti-HBs would begin to appear as the patient recovers from acute HBV infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HBV and HDV coinfection occurs when both viruses are acquired simultaneously. 
  • This is confirmed by the presence of HBsAg, Anti-HBc (IgM), and Anti-HDV antibodies.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents with chronic, progressive fatigue, unintentional weight loss, left-sided abdominal discomfort, and left shoulder pain. On physical examination, nontender bilateral axillary and right-sided inguinal lymphadenopathy are noted, along with hepatosplenomegaly. A peripheral smear shows the presence of abnormal lymphocytes. Which of the following is the most common cytogenetic abnormality associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) del(13q)

 

  • Del(13q) is the most common cytogenetic abnormality associated with Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL). 
  • This deletion is often linked to a better prognosis in CLL patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. t(9;22): This translocation is characteristic of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) and some cases of acute lymphoblastic leukemia, not CLL.

 

Option C. t(14;18): This translocation is commonly associated with follicular lymphoma and some cases of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, rather than CLL.

 

Option D. del(17p): While del(17p) is associated with poor prognosis in CLL, it is not the most common cytogenetic abnormality seen in this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Del(13q) is the most frequently observed cytogenetic abnormality in Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) and is associated with a relatively favorable prognosis compared to other cytogenetic abnormalities in this malignancy.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child was brought to his paediatrician for evaluation of gastrointestinal problems. The parents report that the boy has been listless for the last few weeks. Lab tests reveal a microcytic, hypochromic anaemia. Blood lead levels are elevated. Which of the enzymes listed below is most likely to have higher-than-normal activity in the liver of this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) δ-Aminolevulinic acid synthase

 

  • This child has the acquired porphyria of lead poisoning.
  • Lead inhibits both d-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase (Porphobilinogen synthase) and ferrochelatase and, consequently, heme synthesis.
  • The decrease in heme increases δ- aminolevulinic acid synthase activity.
  • The decrease in heme also results in decreased hemoglobin synthesis, and anemia is seen.
  • Ferrochelatase is directly inhibited by lead.
  • Heme oxygenase is enzymes of heme degradation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ferrochelatase: Ferrochelatase is an enzyme involved in the final step of heme synthesis, where it catalyzes the insertion of iron into protoporphyrin IX to form heme. In lead poisoning, ferrochelatase is inhibited by lead. This inhibition leads to an accumulation of protoporphyrin IX and a decrease in heme production. Therefore, ferrochelatase activity is decreased, not increased, in cases of lead poisoning.

 

Option C. Heme oxygenase: Heme oxygenase is the enzyme responsible for breaking down heme into biliverdin, releasing iron and carbon monoxide in the process. This enzyme is part of the heme degradation pathway, not the synthesis pathway. In lead poisoning, the problem lies in the synthesis of heme, not its breakdown, so the activity of heme oxygenase is not directly affected and would not be expected to increase.

 

Option D. Porphobilinogen synthase (ALA dehydratase): Porphobilinogen synthase catalyzes the conversion of δ-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) to porphobilinogen, an essential step in heme synthesis. Lead poisoning directly inhibits this enzyme, causing an accumulation of ALA. Therefore, its activity is decreased in lead poisoning, not increased. This makes it an incorrect option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of lead poisoning, lead inhibits key enzymes in the heme synthesis pathway, particularly ferrochelatase and porphobilinogen synthase.
  • As a result, there is a compensatory increase in the activity of δ-aminolevulinic acid synthase due to reduced feedback inhibition from heme.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male is working as an operating room technician at a hospital. He was trained to use STERRAD, a gas plasma sterilizer used for disinfecting operation theatre articles and sensitive instruments that are unsuitable for traditional autoclaving. Which of the following is the active agent used in the STERRAD system?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂)

 

  • Hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) is the active agent used in the STERRAD gas plasma sterilizer.
  • In this system, hydrogen peroxide is vaporized and then subjected to an electrical field to form reactive plasma.
  • This plasma effectively sterilizes the medical instruments by disrupting the cellular components of microorganisms.
  • The advantage of STERRAD is its ability to sterilize instruments at low temperatures, which is particularly useful for temperature-sensitive surgical equipment and materials.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nitrous oxide (N₂O): Nitrous oxide is used primarily as an anesthetic and analgesic agent. It is not used in sterilizers due to its lack of antimicrobial properties.

 

Option C. Ozone: Ozone is used in some sterilization systems because of its strong oxidizing properties, but it is not the active agent in STERRAD systems.

 

Option D. Ethylene oxide (EtO): Ethylene oxide is used as a sterilizing gas in a different kind of sterilization process, mainly for heat-sensitive materials. However, it is not the active agent in the STERRAD gas plasma sterilizer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • STERRAD is a gas plasma sterilizer that uses vaporized hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) as the active agent.
  • This sterilization method is effective for temperature-sensitive equipment and is commonly used in healthcare settings to ensure safe disinfection of delicate surgical instruments.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to a sexually transmitted disease (STD) clinic with complaints of urethral discharge and dysuria. He reports unprotected sexual intercourse with a new partner approximately 2 weeks ago. A Gram stain of the urethral discharge reveals numerous polymorphonuclear leukocytes, but no microorganisms are seen. A culture of the discharge is also negative on routine laboratory media. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chlamydia trachomatis

 

  • Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of nongonococcal urethritis.
  • It is an obligate intracellular bacterium, meaning it cannot be visualized with a Gram stain, and it also cannot be cultured on routine media.
  • In patients with urethritis, the absence of visible microorganisms on Gram stain and a negative culture makes Chlamydia trachomatis the most likely culprit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Haemophilus ducreyi: This bacterium causes chancroid, characterized by painful genital ulcers rather than urethral discharge. It is usually diagnosed by culture or PCR and is not the most common cause of urethritis.

 

Option C. Treponema pallidum: Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis, is not usually associated with urethritis and urethral discharge. It causes painless genital ulcers (chancres). Treponema pallidum cannot be visualized with Gram stain but requires special dark-field microscopy or serological testing for diagnosis.

 

Option D. Neisseria gonorrhoeae: Gonorrhea commonly presents with urethral discharge and can be visualized on a Gram stain, appearing as Gram-negative intracellular diplococci. It also grows readily on culture media such as Thayer-Martin agar.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of nongonococcal urethritis and cannot be visualized with Gram stain or cultured on routine media.
  • In cases of urethritis with negative Gram stain and culture, Chlamydia trachomatis should be strongly considered.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents for a routine gynecological examination. She reports that her mother took a medication called diethylstilbestrol (DES) during pregnancy. Which of the following conditions is this patient at an increased risk for due to her mother's exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clear cell adenocarcinoma

 

  • Diethylstilbestrol (DES) was a synthetic estrogen used between the 1940s and 1970s to prevent miscarriage and premature labor.
  • Daughters of women who were exposed to DES during pregnancy are at an increased risk of developing clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina and cervix.
  • This is a rare but serious condition that has been strongly associated with in-utero DES exposure.
  • These women may also have other reproductive tract abnormalities, such as vaginal adenosis, and an increased risk of infertility or ectopic pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometrial carcinoma: Incorrect. Endometrial carcinoma is not linked to DES exposure. It is more commonly associated with factors like unopposed estrogen exposure, obesity, and polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).

 

Option B. Sarcoma botryoides: Incorrect. Sarcoma botryoides is a subtype of rhabdomyosarcoma that typically affects children and presents as a grape-like mass in the vagina or bladder. It is not related to DES exposure.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma: Incorrect. Squamous cell carcinoma is more commonly associated with HPV infection and is not linked to DES exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Daughters of women exposed to diethylstilbestrol (DES) during pregnancy are at an increased risk for developing clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina and cervix.
  • These women require regular gynecologic monitoring due to their elevated cancer risk.

choices.text: Decreased cerebellar function due to neurodegeneration
Genetic anticipation due to trinucleotide repeat expansion
Mitochondrial inheritance pattern of the disorder
Reduced penetrance of the mutant allele in successive generations

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents with worsening gait instability and frequent falls. He has a history of progressive difficulty with balance and coordination since early childhood. His younger sibling, now 12 years old, also recently started showing similar symptoms at an earlier age. On physical examination, the patient exhibits dysarthria, loss of deep tendon reflexes, and bilateral lower extremity weakness. Other examination finding are shown. Which of the following best explains the earlier onset of symptoms in the patient's sibling?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Genetic anticipation due to trinucleotide repeat expansion

 

  • Friedreich's ataxia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a GAA trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FXN gene. 
  • The disease is characterized by progressive ataxia, dysarthria, and loss of proprioception, with early onset during childhood or adolescence. 
  • The phenomenon of genetic anticipation refers to the tendency for the symptoms of certain genetic disorders to appear at an earlier age and often with increased severity in successive generations. 
  • In trinucleotide repeat disorders like Friedreich's ataxia, anticipation occurs due to an increase in the number of repeats with each successive generation, leading to earlier onset of symptoms in younger family members.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased cerebellar function due to neurodegeneration: This describes part of the pathology of Friedreich's ataxia but does not explain the earlier onset of symptoms in successive generations (which is due to anticipation).

 

Option C. Mitochondrial inheritance pattern of the disorder: Friedreich's ataxia is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, not through mitochondrial inheritance, which would be transmitted exclusively through the maternal line.

 

Option D. Reduced penetrance of the mutant allele in successive generations: Reduced penetrance refers to individuals carrying a mutation but not expressing the phenotype. This is not relevant here, as both the patient and his sibling exhibit symptoms, and the key issue is the earlier onset in successive generations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Friedreich's ataxia is a trinucleotide repeat disorder associated with genetic anticipation, where successive generations experience earlier onset and potentially more severe symptoms due to an expansion in the number of GAA repeats in the FXN gene.

questions.text: Which of these intra-venous therapies is preferred while performing damage control resuscitation in traumatic hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Blood products

 

  • Blood products, including packed red blood cells, plasma, and platelets, are the preferred choice in damage control resuscitation (DCR) because they provide essential clotting factors, maintain oxygen-carrying capacity, and help avoid dilutional coagulopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ringer’s Lactate: Ringer's Lactate is a crystalloid solution used for fluid resuscitation. While it can be used in the initial management of hemorrhagic shock, it does not contain clotting factors or carry oxygen and can lead to dilutional coagulopathy if used excessively.

 

Option B. Normal Saline: Normal Saline is another crystalloid solution. Similar to Ringer’s Lactate, it can be used for initial volume expansion but is associated with hyperchloremic acidosis and does not contain blood clotting factors or oxygen-carrying capacity.

 

Option C. Colloids: Colloids, such as hydroxyethyl starch, are sometimes used for volume expansion, but they can interfere with hemostasis and do not provide oxygen-carrying capacity or clotting factors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During damage control resuscitation in traumatic hemorrhage, the preferred intravenous therapy is blood products, as they help maintain hemostasis, oxygenation, and coagulation without causing dilutional coagulopathy.

questions.text:
A public health engineer is evaluating the use of septic tanks as a solution for wastewater management in a rural community. The community lacks a public sewerage system, and the engineer is explaining how septic tanks function. Which of the following statements are true about the functioning and characteristics of a septic tank?

 

  1. Treatment of household sewage
  2. Suitable in presence of public sewerage system
  3. Aerobic oxidation occurs outside the septic tank
  4. Anaerobic digestion takes place inside the septic tank
  5. Retention period is approximately 6 hours
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3 and 4

 

  • The following statements accurately describe the functioning of a septic tank:
    • 1. Treatment of household sewage: Correct. Septic tanks are designed to provide primary treatment of household sewage, particularly in rural or remote areas where there is no access to public sewerage systems.
    • 3. Aerobic oxidation occurs outside the septic tank: Correct. After the effluent leaves the septic tank, it flows into a drain field or soak-away area, where aerobic bacteria further break down the organic matter in the presence of oxygen.
    • 4. Anaerobic digestion takes place inside the septic tank: Correct. Inside the septic tank, anaerobic bacteria decompose organic matter in the absence of oxygen, which helps break down sludge and organic waste.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Suitable in presence of public sewerage system: Incorrect. Septic tanks are not suitable when a public sewerage system is available. They are used as an alternative when such a system is absent.

 

5. Retention period is approximately 6 hours: Incorrect. The retention period in a septic tank can vary but is typically 24 hours for effective treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SEPTIC TANK:

 

  • Is a water-tight masonary tank into which household sewage is admitted for treatment
  • Is a satisfactory method of disposing liquid and excreta wastes from individual dwellings, small groups of houses or institutions which have ‘adequate water supply but do not have access to a public sewerage system’
  • Design features of a septic tank: – Ideal retention period: 24 hours
  • Steps of purification in a septic tank:
    • Anaerobic digestion: Takes place in septic tank proper
  • Aerobic oxidation: Takes place in sub-soil (outside septic tank)

questions.text:
A pediatrician is reviewing mortality trends among children aged between 1-4 years based on verbal autopsy reports from the years 2020-2024. She wants to educate parents on the primary causes of death to improve preventive measures in her community. From the list provided below, which sequence correctly represents the leading causes of death in a ascending order for this age group?

 

  1. Neonatal infections
  2. Prematurity
  3. Malaria
  4. Birth asphyxia
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2>1>4

 

  • According to the verbal autopsy report of 2020-2024, leading cause of death among 1–4-year-old children in a developing country like India in descending order is Prematurity, neonatal infections & birth asphyxia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leading causes of under 5 mortality and neonatal mortality are:
  1. Prematurity
  2. Neonatal infections
  3. Birth asphyxia

choices.text: All zone 1 injury to be treated conservatively
Zone 3 injury, whether blunt or penetrative, should always be explored
Zone 2 injury with expanding hematoma should be treated surgically
Mattox maneuver is when the ascending colon is mobilized to visualize the IVC

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding retroperitoneal trauma:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zone 2 injury with expanding hematoma should be treated surgically
 

  • Zone 2 hematomas occur in the flank region and typically involve the kidneys.
  • Most Zone 2 hematomas can be managed conservatively unless the hematoma is expanding.
  • If expansion occurs, surgical intervention is necessary to prevent further complications or hemorrhage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. All zone 1 injury to be treated conservatively: Zone 1 refers to the central retroperitoneal area, where vital structures like the abdominal aorta and IVC are located. Since these structures are crucial and any injury here can be life-threatening, all Zone 1 hematomas should be surgically explored rather than treated conservatively.

 

Option B. Zone 3 injury, whether blunt or penetrative, should always be explored: Zone 3 involves the pelvic area. Blunt trauma to this zone is typically managed conservatively using pelvic binders or external fixation. Exploration is usually avoided due to the high risk of causing additional harm. Surgical exploration is indicated only in cases of expanding hematomas or severe trauma.

 

Option D. Mattox maneuver is when the ascending colon is mobilized to visualize the IVC. The Mattox maneuver is a surgical technique that mobilizes the left-sided abdominal organs medially to allow visualization of the abdominal aorta. This is performed in trauma cases or emergencies to gain access to the retroperitoneum and the aorta.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Retroperitoneal injuries are managed differently depending on the zone of injury.
    • Zone 1 (Midline Retroperitoneum): Injuries in this area involve major vessels and require immediate surgical exploration.
    • Zone 2 (Lateral Retroperitoneum): Injuries can usually be managed conservatively unless the hematoma is expanding, in which case surgery is indicated.
    • Zone 3 (Pelvic Region): Most injuries in this zone are managed conservatively due to the risk of complications during surgery, except when there are expanding hematomas or severe injuries.

questions.text: A 26-year-old previously healthy man has noticed blood in his urine for the past 2 days. He reports no dysuria, frequency, or hesitancy of urination. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory findings show a serum urea nitrogen level of 42 mg/dL and creatinine level of 4.5 mg/dL. A renal biopsy specimen is obtained; the immunofluorescence pattern of staining with antibody against human IgG is shown in the figure. Which of the following serologic findings is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti–glomerular basement membrane antibody

 

  • The linear pattern of staining shown in the figure indicates the presence of anti–glomerular basement membrane antibodies (directed against the non-collagenous domain of the α3 chain of type IV collagen).

  • Such antibodies are typically seen in Goodpasture syndrome, a form of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (GN) that has a bimodal pattern of occurrence in younger and older men.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis B surface antibody: Incorrect. Hepatitis B is associated with membranous nephropathy or polyarteritis nodosa, neither of which presents with the linear IgG deposition seen here.

 

Option B. Anti–streptolysin O antibody: Incorrect. This is associated with post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, which typically shows a granular immune complex deposition pattern, not the linear pattern seen in this case.

 

Option C. C3 nephritic factor: Incorrect. C3 nephritic factor is associated with membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis and dense deposit disease, which show C3 deposits, not the linear IgG deposits seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Goodpasture syndrome is characterized by anti–glomerular basement membrane antibodies that cause a linear IgG deposition pattern on immunofluorescence and result in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: The clinical test shown in the image is positive in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thoracic outlet syndrome

 

  • The test being performed in the image is known as Adson's test, which is commonly used to diagnose thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS).
  • Adson's test is a provocative test that involves the compression of the subclavian artery by structures such as a cervical rib or tight anterior and middle scalene muscles, leading to a reduction in blood flow.
  • In the test, the patient is asked to take a deep breath, extend, abduct, and externally rotate the affected arm while rotating the head to the ipsilateral side with the neck extended.
  • The radial pulse is palpated during the maneuver, and the test is considered positive if there is a significant reduction or disappearance of the pulse, suggesting compression of the subclavian vessels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fracture of the first rib: This would not involve vascular compression, and a specific fracture test or imaging would be more appropriate for diagnosis.

 

Option C. Acromioclavicular joint injury: It is typically diagnosed through localized pain and physical maneuvers specific to the joint itself (e.g., cross-arm test or O'Brien's test).

 

Option D. Clavicle fracture: This would present with local swelling, deformity, and tenderness over the fracture site. Adson's test is unrelated to clavicle fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Adson’s test is used to diagnose thoracic outlet syndrome, a condition characterized by compression of neurovascular structures (subclavian artery, vein, and brachial plexus) as they pass through the thoracic outlet.

choices.text: For hormone receptor (HR)-positive metastatic breast cancer in postmenopausal women
As a selective progesterone receptor modulator

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate indication for fulvestrant?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) For hormone receptor (HR)-positive metastatic breast cancer in postmenopausal women

 

  • Fulvestrant is a selective estrogen receptor downregulator (SERD) that is used in the treatment of hormone receptor (HR)-positive metastatic breast cancer in postmenopausal women.
  • It works by binding to estrogen receptors and promoting their degradation, thus reducing the growth-promoting effects of estrogen in breast cancer cells.
  • It is often used when other hormonal therapies, such as aromatase inhibitors or tamoxifen, are no longer effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. As a selective progesterone receptor modulator: This is incorrect. Fulvestrant specifically targets estrogen receptors, not progesterone receptors. Selective progesterone receptor modulators (e.g., mifepristone) are used for different indications, such as uterine fibroids or as abortifacients.

 

Option C. In hormone replacement therapy (HRT): This is incorrect. Fulvestrant is not used in HRT because it antagonizes estrogen receptors, which would be counterproductive in hormone replacement therapy aimed at providing estrogen.

 

Option D. In male breast cancer: While hormone therapy is sometimes used for male breast cancer, fulvestrant is not specifically indicated for this purpose. Male breast cancer is typically managed with tamoxifen or other medications that inhibit estrogen activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fulvestrant is a selective estrogen receptor downregulator (SERD) used for HR-positive metastatic breast cancer in postmenopausal women.
  • It is not used as a progesterone receptor modulator or for hormone replacement therapy (HRT).
  • It is not a standard treatment for male breast cancer, where tamoxifen is more commonly used.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with a chronic cough and shortness of breath. She has never smoked and works as a librarian. A chest CT shows a 3 cm mass in the periphery of the right lung. A biopsy of the lesion reveals glandular structures and mucin production. Molecular testing reveals a mutation in the EGFR gene. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adenocarcinoma

 

  • The patient has a peripheral lung tumor with glandular differentiation and mucin production, which is characteristic of adenocarcinoma of the lung.
  • Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer in nonsmokers and is often associated with EGFR mutations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: Incorrect. Squamous cell carcinoma is usually centrally located and associated with a history of smoking. It is characterized by keratin pearls and intercellular bridges, not glandular structures or mucin production.

 

Option B. Small cell carcinoma: Incorrect. Small cell carcinoma is strongly associated with smoking and presents with small, round cells, often centrally located in the lungs. It does not typically produce mucin or glandular structures.

 

Option C. Large cell carcinoma: Incorrect. Large cell carcinoma is a poorly differentiated lung cancer that lacks the glandular differentiation or mucin production seen in adenocarcinoma. It also tends to be located peripherally, but the biopsy findings do not match large cell carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Adenocarcinoma of the lung is the most common lung cancer in nonsmokers and is often associated with EGFR mutations.
  • It is characterized by glandular differentiation and mucin production and typically occurs in the periphery of the lungs.

choices.text: Drug B and drug C are equipotent.
Drug B is less potent but more efficacious than drug A.

questions.text: The graph shows the log dose-response curves (DRC) for four drugs: A, B, C, and D. Which of the following statements about these drugs is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Drug B is less potent but more efficacious than drug A.

 

  • Potency refers to the dose of a drug required to produce a certain effect, and is indicated by the position of the curve along the x-axis.
  • A drug whose curve is further to the left is more potent because it requires a lower dose to achieve the same effect.
  • Efficacy is reflected by the maximum response that a drug can produce, shown by the height of the curve on the y-axis.
    • Drug A has a lower maximal response than Drug B, meaning it is less efficacious.
    • Drug B reaches a higher maximum effect than Drug A, indicating higher efficacy, but Drug A achieves its response at a lower dose, making it more potent.
    • Drug B is positioned to the right of Drug A, indicating lower potency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drug A is most efficacious: This is incorrect because efficacy is determined by the maximum height of the response curve. Drug B has a higher maximal response than Drug A, making Drug B more efficacious.

 

Option B. Drug B and drug C are equipotent: This is incorrect because potency is determined by the position of the curve along the x-axis. Drug C is further to the right than Drug B, indicating that Drug C is less potent.

 

Option C. Drug D is most effective: While Drug D is the most efficacious, not most effective. DRC of the drug can tell about efficacy not effectiveness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Potency is determined by the position of the dose-response curve along the x-axis: further left means more potent.
  • Efficacy is determined by the height of the curve along the y-axis: higher means more efficacious.
  • A drug can be more potent but less efficacious than another, as shown in the comparison between Drug A and Drug B.

questions.text: An incidental finding was noted on a NCCT abdomen performed for suspected renal calculus. What would be the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cholecystectomy

 

  • The above given image shows curvilinear calcification of the gallbladder known as a "Porcelain gallbladder".
  • Cholecystectomy - Due to the increased risk of gallbladder cancer in patients with a porcelain gallbladder, prophylactic cholecystectomy is often recommended. The removal of the gallbladder can mitigate the risk of developing carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reassure: While reassurance might be the next step for benign andnon-consequential findings, a porcelain gallbladder is associated with a higherrisk of gallbladder carcinoma, and reassurance alone is not appropriate in thiscase.

 

Option C. Right Nephrectomy: This would be an incorrect and excessive step as the finding is related to the gallbladder and not the kidney. There is no indication for nephrectomy based on the finding of a porcelain gallbladder.

 

Option D. DSA and coiling: Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) and coiling are interventions used for vascular abnormalities such as aneurysms or active bleeding, not for the management of a porcelain gallbladder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The correct management for a porcelain gallbladder, characterized by gallbladder wall calcification and associated with an increased risk ofcancer, is prophylactic cholecystectomy.

 

  • This approach is to prevent the potential development of gallbladder carcinoma.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents for evaluation of persistent sciatica. He reports low back pain that radiates down the back of his left leg, which began weeks after he sustained a fall. On physical examination of the left leg, he has 4/5 strength with plantar flexion and a 1+ ankle jerk reflex. The right leg has normal strength (5/5) and full reflexes. Based on these findings, which of the following myotomes is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) S1-S2

 

  • The patient's symptoms, including radiating pain down the back of the leg (sciatica), reduced strength in plantar flexion, and a diminished ankle jerk reflex (S1 reflex), suggest involvement of the S1-S2 nerve roots. 
  • The S1 myotome is responsible for ankle plantar flexion and the Achilles reflex. Weakness in plantar flexion and a diminished ankle jerk reflex are classic findings associated with S1 radiculopathy, often due to a herniated disc compressing the nerve root at L5-S1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. L1-L2: L1-L2 myotomes are involved in hip flexion, not plantar flexion. Sciatica affecting these myotomes would cause pain in the anterior thigh, not the posterior leg.

 

Option B. T2-L4: This option is incorrect as the T2-L4 myotomes control movements of the upper thigh (L2, L3) and knee extension (L4), but not plantar flexion or the Achilles reflex.

 

Option C. S3-S4: S3-S4 myotomes are responsible for bowel, bladder, and some pelvic floor functions, not leg movement or reflexes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • S1 radiculopathy typically presents with pain radiating down the posterior leg, weakness in plantar flexion, and a diminished Achilles (ankle jerk) reflex. 
  • This is often caused by compression of the S1 nerve root, commonly due to a herniated disc at L5-S1.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with symptoms of blurred vision, severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and altered sensorium. He was found unconscious at home, and his family mentions that he had consumed illicit homemade liquor the previous evening. Physical examination reveals metabolic acidosis. Suspecting poisoning from contaminated alcohol, which of the following substances is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Methyl alcohol

 

  • The scenario described here is characteristic of a hooch tragedy, which refers to incidents of poisoning due to the consumption of illicit homemade liquor that is contaminated with methyl alcohol (methanol).
  • Methanol poisoning can result in severe metabolic acidosis, blindness, severe abdominal pain, and altered sensorium.
  • Methanol is metabolized in the liver by alcohol dehydrogenase to formaldehyde and then to formic acid, which is highly toxic to the optic nerve and central nervous system.
  • In cases of methanol poisoning, rapid intervention is necessary to prevent complications, including blindness and death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ethylene glycol: Incorrect. Ethylene glycol is another toxic alcohol often found in antifreeze. It is metabolized into glycolic acid and oxalic acid, leading to severe metabolic acidosis, renal failure, and calcium oxalate crystal deposition in the kidneys. However, it is not typically associated with illicit alcohol consumption like methanol.

 

Option B. Hypoglycin: Incorrect. Hypoglycin is a naturally occurring toxin found in unripe ackee fruit and can cause Jamaican vomiting sickness. It is not related to illicit alcohol consumption or Hooch tragedy incidents. Hypoglycin poisoning presents with severe hypoglycemia and vomiting but does not cause metabolic acidosis from alcohol toxicity.

 

Option D. Ethyl alcohol: Incorrect. Ethyl alcohol (ethanol) is the primary alcohol present in commercial and consumable alcoholic beverages. While ethanol toxicity can occur, it is less likely to cause severe metabolic acidosis compared to methanol. Illicit or contaminated alcohol is more likely to contain methanol, leading to the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Methanol poisoning is a critical consideration in cases of illicit alcohol consumption or Hooch tragedy events.
  • Methanol is metabolized into toxic metabolites, such as formaldehyde and formic acid, leading to metabolic acidosis, visual disturbances, and potential neurological damage.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with progressive forgetfulness over the past 2 months. He exhibits intermittent jerky movements in his legs. On physical examination, he has significant cognitive impairment. He has horizontal nystagmus in all directions, ataxia, and intermittent large-amplitude jerking movements. His EEG is shown below. Given this presentation, which of the following genetic changes is most likely responsible for the patient's underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Codon 129 polymorphism in PRNP gene

 

  • The clinical presentation, including rapid cognitive decline, myoclonus, ataxia, and horizontal nystagmus, is indicative of Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD), a prion disease. 
  • The PRNP gene, responsible for encoding prion protein, has a codon 129 polymorphism, which is associated with susceptibility to CJD and related disorders. 
  • The symptoms align with the neurodegenerative effects of prion diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. V122I mutation in TTR gene: This mutation is linked to transthyretin amyloidosis, which primarily presents with neuropathy and cardiac issues, rather than the neurological symptoms presented in this case.

 

Option C. G2019S mutation in LRRK2 gene: This mutation is associated with familial and sporadic Parkinson’s disease, characterized by tremors and rigidity rather than the rapid cognitive decline and myoclonus observed here.

 

Option D. H63D mutation in HFE gene: This mutation is linked to hereditary hemochromatosis, which typically leads to iron overload and associated complications, but does not explain the neurological symptoms seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases presenting with rapidly progressive dementia and myoclonus, the PRNP gene polymorphism at codon 129 is a crucial factor to consider, indicating a potential diagnosis of Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease.

questions.text: Match each device listed in Column A with the maximum FiO2 it delivers, as shown in Column B
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

1. High Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC) - b. 90% -100 % FiO2
2. Non-Rebreather Mask (NRBM)- c. Up to 80% FiO2
3. Hudson Mask - d. 40-60% FiO2
4. Nasal Cannula at 3 L/min Oxygen Flow - a. 30-35% FiO2

 

Explanation:

 

  • High Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC) can deliver up to 100 % FiO2 depending on the device settings and patient's inspiratory flow rate, offering a high level of oxygen delivery and humidification.
  • Non-Rebreather Mask (NRBM) provides up to 80% FiO2 when properly fitted and the reservoir bag is kept inflated, ensuring a high concentration of oxygen is available for the patient.
  • Hudson Mask, also known as a simple mask, can deliver FiO2 levels between 40-60% based on the oxygen flow rate.
  • Nasal Cannula at 3 L/min Oxygen Flow typically provides 32% FiO2, making it suitable for patients requiring low to moderate additional oxygen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oxygen delivery devices are an essential aspect of managing patients with respiratory distress or hypoxemia.

questions.text: Fibrous ankylosis is caused by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) TB arthritis

 

  • Tuberculous arthritis is a manifestation of extrapulmonary tuberculosis, where the bacteria Mycobacterium tuberculosis infects the joints.
  • This condition leads to chronic synovitis and the formation of a granulomatous tissue response in the joint.
  • TB arthritis often affects the hip and knee joints, leading to erosion of bone and cartilage.
  • The resultant fibrous tissue formation around the joint can lead to fibrous ankylosis, restricting movement.
  • This is a significant characteristic of TB arthritis, making it a prominent cause of this type of ankylosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Septic Arthritis: Septic arthritis is an infection in the joint space, usually caused by bacteria, though it can also be due to fungi or viruses. The infection causes acute inflammation, leading to pain, swelling, and redness. If not treated promptly, septic arthritis can lead to significant joint destruction and deformities. Chronic cases can result in joint instability and secondary complications like fibrous ankylosis due to scarring from the inflammatory process. However, it is typically more associated with irreversible damage rather than isolated fibrous ankylosis.

 

Option C. Behçet’s Disease: Behçet’s disease is a systemic vasculitis characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, uveitis, and skin lesions. It can cause arthritis, typically non-erosive, affecting the knees, ankles, and wrists. The arthritis is usually transient and does not typically lead to permanent joint damage or fibrous ankylosis. While joint pain and swelling can occur, Behçet's disease does not generally result in fibrous ankylosis in the same way TB arthritis does.

 

Option D. Psoriatic Arthritis: Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis. It can lead to both peripheral and axial joint involvement and is characterized by flares of inflammation. Over time, it can cause erosive changes in the joints and sometimes leads to fusion of joints (ankylosis), particularly in the spine. While psoriatic arthritis can lead to ankylosis, it is more typically associated with bony ankylosis due to erosive changes rather than purely fibrous ankylosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • TB arthritis is the most directly associated with fibrous ankylosis due to the chronic inflammatory processes and tissue scarring it induces around the affected joint.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with a soft, painless swelling in the scrotal area that becomes more prominent during the day. On physical examination, the swelling is found to be transilluminant. Which of the following swellings is not expected to transilluminate brightly?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lymphadenopathy

 

  • Unlike the other swellings, lymphadenopathy does not transilluminate because lymph nodes are solid structures rather than fluid-filled.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vaginal hydrocele: This is a fluid-filled swelling in the scrotum that brilliantly transilluminates due to the presence of clear fluid.

 

Option B. Epididymal cyst: These are benign cysts that arise from the epididymis and contain clear fluid, which allows for brilliant transillumination.

 

Option C. Meningocele: This is a congenital defect where meninges protrude through a defect in the spine or skull, and it typically transilluminates brightly due to the fluid content within the meningeal sac.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Only fluid-filled swellings such as hydroceles, cysts, and meningoceles transilluminate brightly, while solid masses like lymphadenopathy do not.
  • Understanding the differential diagnosis of transilluminating masses helps narrow down potential causes in clinical practice.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with progressive pain and stiffness in the joints of her hands. Physical examination reveals swelling and limited range of motion in the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints bilaterally, with sparing of the distal interphalangeal joints. Ulnar deviation is noted. She reports that the stiffness is particularly severe in the morning but improves throughout the day. Which of the following HLA subtypes is most strongly associated with this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HLA-DR4

 

  • The patient's symptoms—pain and stiffness affecting the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints, with distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint sparing—along with morning stiffness and ulnar deviation, are highly indicative of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). 
  • RA typically spares the DIP joints and instead affects the MCP and PIP joints. HLA-DR4 is the HLA subtype most strongly associated with rheumatoid arthritis, an autoimmune disease that leads to chronic inflammation and progressive joint damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HLA-B27: This HLA subtype is linked to seronegative spondyloarthropathies, including ankylosing spondylitis and psoriatic arthritis, which can involve DIP joints.

 

Option B. HLA-B8: HLA-B8 is associated with conditions like myasthenia gravis and Graves' disease, but not rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Option C. HLA-BW22: This HLA subtype is not associated with rheumatoid arthritis or related autoimmune conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis typically affects the MCP and PIP joints, sparing the DIP joints, and is strongly associated with HLA-DR4.
  • This autoimmune disease presents with morning stiffness and progressive joint deformities such as ulnar deviation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with reddish urine. Laboratory results show a hemoglobin level of 7.8 g/dL, elevated serum LDH, and unconjugated bilirubin. A peripheral smear reveals pancytopenia. Flow cytometry is done and shown. Which of the following is unlikely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Positive Direct Coombs Test (DCT)

 

  • The patient's presentation, including elevated LDH and unconjugated bilirubin, suggests hemolytic anemia rather than aplastic anemia. 
  • While a positive Direct Coombs Test (DCT) can indicate autoimmune hemolytic anemia, it is unlikely that a positive result would be found if the primary issue were aplastic anemia, as the peripheral smear findings and clinical picture align more with hemolysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mesenteric vein thrombosis: This can occur in hypercoagulable states, including some types of hemolytic anemia, making it a possible complication.

 

Option B. Dysphagia: Dysphagia can occur in various contexts but is less likely to be directly related to the hemolytic process without additional systemic or neurological involvement.

 

Option C. Aplastic anemia: While aplastic anemia presents with pancytopenia, the specific hemolytic indicators in this case suggest that this diagnosis is less likely when combined with the findings of hemolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients presenting with hemolytic anemia and evidence of increased hemolysis (elevated LDH and unconjugated bilirubin), a positive Direct Coombs Test is unlikely if the primary pathology is aplastic anemia, emphasizing the importance of differentiating between hemolytic anemia and aplastic anemia in clinical practice.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and hypoalbuminemia. Biopsy of his small intestine shows disrupted epithelial tight junctions. Which of the following proteins is most likely involved in maintaining the structure and function of the tight junctions in this patient’s epithelial cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Claudin

 

  • Claudin is a key component of tight junctions, also known as zonula occludens, which are responsible for regulating paracellular transport and maintaining the epithelial barrier.
  • Tight junctions are crucial in tissues like the gastrointestinal tract, where they prevent the passage of harmful substances between epithelial cells.
  • Claudins, along with other proteins like occludin, are integral to the formation and function of tight junctions.
  • Disruption in these proteins, such as seen in this patient, leads to increased intestinal permeability, resulting in conditions like chronic diarrhea and malabsorption syndromes, evidenced by the patient's hypoalbuminemia and weight loss.
  • The biopsy showing disruption of the tight junctions further indicates that the primary defect lies in these structural proteins, particularly claudin, leading to the patient’s clinical presentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Connexin: Incorrect. Connexins are proteins that form gap junctions, which are responsible for communication between cells by allowing the passage of ions and small molecules. These proteins are not involved in tight junctions and do not play a role in maintaining the epithelial barrier. Therefore, connexin is not related to the pathology of this patient's condition.

 

Option B. Desmoglein: Incorrect. Desmogleins are components of desmosomes, which are cell structures that function in cell-cell adhesion. Desmosomes provide mechanical strength to tissues like the skin and heart. While they are important for cellular adhesion, they do not regulate paracellular transport or maintain the tight junction barrier as claudins do. This makes desmoglein unrelated to the patient’s issue of intestinal permeability.

 

Option D. Integrin: Incorrect. Integrins are transmembrane proteins that mediate the adhesion of cells to the extracellular matrix. They are involved in cell-extracellular matrix interactions, rather than cell-cell adhesion or tight junction formation. Thus, integrins do not maintain the epithelial barrier or regulate paracellular transport as claudins do.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Claudins are critical proteins in tight junctions (zonula occludens) that help maintain epithelial barrier integrity by regulating paracellular transport.
  • Disruption of claudins can lead to increased intestinal permeability, resulting in conditions like chronic diarrhea and malabsorption.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding high-quality CPR for adults? 

 

  1. Push hard (5-6cm depth)
  2. Push fast (100-120/min frequency)
  3. Allow for complete chest recoil
  4. Minimize interruptions in compressions ≤20 seconds
  5. Rotate compressor every 5 min. or earlier if fatigued
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3

 

  • High-quality CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation) for adults involves several key components that are essential for improving the likelihood of survival and outcomes after cardiac arrest.

 

These components include:

 

  1. Adequate Compression Depth: Compressions should be at least 5 cm (2 inches) deep but not more than 6 cm (2.4 inches).
  2. Proper Compression Rate: The rate of compressions should be between 100 and 120 compressions per minute.
  3. Allow Complete Chest Recoil: It's crucial to let the chest return to its normal position completely after each compression to allow the heart to refill with blood.
  4. Minimize Interruptions: Interruptions in chest compressions should be kept to less than 10 seconds to maximize blood flow during CPR.
  5. Avoid Excessive Ventilation: Over-ventilation can be harmful. It is recommended to avoid excessive ventilation to prevent increasing intrathoracic pressure and reducing venous return to the heart.
  6. Rotation of Compressors: To prevent fatigue and maintain the quality of compressions, it is recommended to rotate the compressor every 2 minutes or sooner if the compressor is tired.
  7. Compression-Ventilation Ratio: If no advanced airway is in place, a compression-to-ventilation ratio of 30:2 should be used.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • High-quality CPR for adults requires all the specified techniques to ensure optimal outcomes.
  • Compressing at a depth of 5-6 cm and a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute, allowing for complete chest recoil, minimizing interruptions in compressions to under 10 seconds, and avoiding excessive ventilation are all recommended practices to maximize the effectiveness of cardiopulmonary resuscitation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with a 6-mm basal cell carcinoma on the tip of his nose. He is scheduled to undergo excision of the tumor in the operating room with repair of the defect using skin and subcutaneous tissue from his earlobe. Which of the following terms most appropriately describes this form of reconstructive surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Composite graft

 

  • A composite tissue graft contains tissue in addition to the epidermis and dermis. Depending on the donor site, it can contain subcutaneous fat, cartilage, and even muscle.
  • This makes it ideal for deeper defects in which a partial-thickness or full-thickness skin graft would give a poor cosmetic outcome.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Free flap and B. Pedicle flap: A flap is a vascularized piece of tissue that is mobilized from its original site to another location. A free tissue flap involves severing the original blood supply with anastomosis to blood vessels in the recipient site. The remaining defect in this patient is too small to warrant the need for a flap.

 

Option C. Full-thickness graft: Full thickness graft contains the entire thickness of skin, but not any other tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A composite tissue graft contains tissue in addition to the epidermis and dermis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman at 24 weeks gestation presents for a routine prenatal visit. She is pregnant with monochorionic twins. During the ultrasound, there is a concern for a complication specific to this type of twin pregnancy.  Which of the following complications is specific to monochorionic twins?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome

 

  • Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) is a specific complication of monochorionic twin pregnancies, where the twins share a single placenta.
  • TTTS occurs due to abnormal vascular connections within the shared placenta, leading to unequal blood flow between the twins.
  • One twin (the donor) becomes volume-depleted and experiences oligohydramnios and growth restriction, while the other twin (the recipient) becomes volume-overloaded, often developing polyhydramnios and heart complications.
  • TTTS is unique to monochorionic twins due to their shared placental circulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neural tube defects: Incorrect. Neural tube defects are not specific to monochorionic twins and can occur in any pregnancy. They are related to issues with early fetal development, not the chorionicity of the pregnancy.

 

Option B. Polyhydramnios: Incorrect. Polyhydramnios can occur in any pregnancy and is not specific to monochorionic twins. While it can be a feature in TTTS (affecting the recipient twin), it is not specific to monochorionic pregnancies by itself.

 

Option C. Selective fetal growth restriction: Incorrect. Selective fetal growth restriction (sFGR) can occur in both monochorionic and dichorionic twin pregnancies. It refers to one twin having significant growth restriction compared to the other, but this is not exclusive to monochorionic twins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) is a specific complication of monochorionic twin pregnancies, where abnormal vascular connections within the shared placenta result in unequal blood flow between the twins, leading to complications in both the donor and recipient twins.

choices.text: Tidal volume should be set at 4-6 ml/kg of ideal body weight (IBW).
Respiratory rate should be initially set at 12-16 breaths per minute.
Initial FiO2 should be set at 100% and reduced as tolerated to avoid oxygen toxicity.
PEEP should be set at 5 cm H2O and not adjusted.

questions.text: A 57-year-old patient develops acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) after being admitted for severe pneumonia. He is being prepared for mechanical ventilation in the intensive care unit. Which of the following statements about lung-protective ventilatory settings is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) PEEP should be set at 5 cm H2O and not adjusted

 

  • PEEP is initially set at 5 cm H2O to prevent alveolar collapse at end expiration.
  • However, in the setting of cardiac surgery and concerns about impairing ventricular filling, careful titration of PEEP above the initial setting is advised to optimize oxygenation and ventilation without compromising hemodynamics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tidal volume should be set at 4-6 ml/kg of ideal body weight (IBW): True. The recommended initial tidal volume for mechanical ventilation is 4-6 ml/kg based on the patient’s ideal body weight to prevent barotrauma and volutrauma.

 

Option B. Respiratory rate should be initially set at 12-16 breaths per minute: True. A respiratory rate of 12 to 16 breaths per minute is a common initial setting which can be adjusted based on the patient's gas exchange and acid-base status.

 

Option C. Initial FiO2 should be set at 100% and reduced as tolerated to avoid oxygen toxicity: True. Starting with an FiO2 of 100% is a typical approach in critically ill patients to ensure adequate oxygenation. The FiO2 is usually titrated down to avoid oxygen toxicity, depending on arterial blood gases and oxygen saturation.

Educational Objective:

 

  • When initiating mechanical ventilation, it is critical to start with safe settings tailored to the patient’s lung mechanics and underlying pathology.
  • The initial PEEP setting should be low but requires careful adjustment, to balance lung recruitment and cardiac output.

choices.text: The Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act - 2012
The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition, and Redressal) Act - 2013
The Pre-conception and Pre-natal Diagnostic Techniques (Prohibition of Sex Selection) [PNDT] Act - 2002
The Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act - 2005

questions.text: The following laws have been enacted in India to protect the rights of women and children. Identify the pair that is incorrectly matched with its year of enactment:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The Pre-conception and Pre-natal Diagnostic Techniques (Prohibition of Sex Selection) [PNDT] Act - 2002

 

  • This is incorrect because the Pre-conception and Pre-natal Diagnostic Techniques (Prohibition of Sex Selection) [PNDT] Act was actually enacted in 1994.
  • This act aims to prevent sex-selective abortions and curb the declining female sex ratio by regulating the use of pre-natal diagnostic techniques.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act - 2012: Correct. The POCSO Act was enacted in 2012 to protect children from sexual abuse and exploitation.

 

Option B. The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition, and Redressal) Act - 2013: Correct. This act was enacted in 2013 to address sexual harassment faced by women in workplaces and to ensure a safe working environment.

 

Option D. The Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act - 2005: Correct. The Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act came into effect in 2005 and provides protection to women against domestic abuse and violence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The PNDT Act was enacted in 1994 to prevent sex-selective practices.
  • The POCSO Act (2012) and Sexual Harassment Act (2013) address child protection and workplace safety, respectively.
  • The Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act (2005) provides a legal framework for addressing domestic violence against women.

choices.text: Hypoplasia or absence of clavicles
Craniosynostosis with premature fusion of sutures
Absence of radius and thumb
Multiple exostoses (bony outgrowths) on long bones

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to concerns about delayed eruption of his permanent teeth and abnormal appearance of his shoulders. Physical examination reveals a wide, flat skull, midface hypoplasia, and the ability to bring his shoulders together in front of his chest. X-rays of the chest are shown below. Which of the following skeletal abnormalities is most characteristic of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypoplasia or absence of clavicles

 

  • The X-ray image of the chest in this case shows underdeveloped or absent clavicles, which is a hallmark feature of cleidocranial dysostosis (also known as cleidocranial dysplasia).
  • In a normal chest X-ray, the clavicles (collarbones) are clearly visible as long, horizontal bones at the top of the rib cage, just beneath the shoulders.
  • However, in this patient, the clavicles appear hypoplastic (underdeveloped) or absent, allowing the patient to approximate their shoulders in front of the chest—a characteristic finding in this condition.
  • This feature allows affected individuals to approximate their shoulders in front of their chest, which is a classic finding.
  • The condition also presents with other skeletal anomalies, including a wide, flat skull (brachycephaly), midface hypoplasia, and delayed eruption of permanent teeth.
  • The skeletal abnormalities stem from mutations in the RUNX2 gene, which is critical for osteoblast differentiation and proper bone formation, particularly impacting the development of the clavicles and craniofacial bones.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Craniosynostosis with premature fusion of sutures: Incorrect. Craniosynostosis involves the premature fusion of skull sutures, leading to restricted skull growth and an abnormal head shape. In contrast, cleidocranial dysostosis is characterized by delayed closure of fontanelles, resulting in a broad, flat skull, not early suture closure.

 

Option C. Absence of radius and thumb: Incorrect. The absence of the radius and thumb is typically seen in radial ray anomalies, which are features of conditions like Holt-Oram syndrome or Fanconi anemia. These are not characteristic findings in cleidocranial dysostosis, which primarily affects the clavicles and skull bones.

 

Option D. Multiple exostoses (bony outgrowths) on long bones: Incorrect. Multiple exostoses are a hallmark of hereditary multiple exostoses (osteochondromatosis), where patients develop benign bony outgrowths. This is not seen in cleidocranial dysostosis, where skeletal involvement is more focused on the clavicles and craniofacial bones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cleidocranial dysostosis is characterized by hypoplasia or absence of clavicles, which allows for excessive shoulder mobility, delayed closure of the fontanelles, and dental abnormalities such as delayed tooth eruption.
  • It is caused by mutations in the RUNX2 gene, which is essential for normal bone formation and osteoblast differentiation.
  • Recognizing these skeletal features is critical for diagnosing the condition.

choices.text: Deletion of 17p involving the TP53 gene
Hypermutation of the immunoglobulin heavy chain variable region (IGHV)

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the clinic with fatigue and night sweats. On physical examination, he has cervical lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly. Laboratory studies reveal lymphocytosis with the peripheral blood smear image as shown. Flow cytometry confirms the presence of clonal CD5+ CD19+ B cells. A bone marrow biopsy shows infiltration with small, mature lymphocytes. He is diagnosed with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). Which of the following is most strongly associated with poor prognosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Deletion of 17p involving the TP53 gene

 

  • This patient has CLL, and his prognosis depends on various genetic and molecular factors. A deletion of 17p, which involves the TP53 gene, is associated with poor prognosis because it affects the tumor suppressor gene TP53, leading to resistance to standard chemotherapy and more aggressive disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Expression of CD23: Incorrect. Expression of CD23 is common in CLL and helps distinguish it from other B-cell malignancies, but it is not a marker of poor prognosis.

 

Option C. Presence of trisomy 12: Incorrect. Trisomy 12 is a cytogenetic abnormality seen in CLL and is generally associated with an intermediate prognosis, not a poor prognosis.

 

Option D. Hypermutation of the immunoglobulin heavy chain variable region (IGHV): Incorrect. Hypermutation of the IGHV region is associated with a better prognosis in CLL, not a poor prognosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Deletion of 17p, involving the TP53 gene, is strongly associated with a poor prognosis in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).
  • This mutation leads to a more aggressive disease and poorer treatment response.
